column2: muscle wasting,patches in throat,high fever,extra marital contacts
column11: A common discomfort or ache felt in the region of your lower spine, from just below the ribs down to the buttocks. It can be a dull ache, sharp pain, or stiffness.
column12: Medically, lower back pain (or lumbago) is an extremely prevalent condition. It can be acute (sudden onset, short duration) or chronic (lasting more than 3 months). Most cases are mechanical, meaning they relate to how the back moves, but some can be due to more serious underlying conditions. Common Mechanical Causes: Muscle Strain or Ligament Sprain: Often due to improper lifting, sudden movements, or overuse. This is the most common cause. Herniated (Slipped) Disc: When the soft cushioning disc between vertebrae bulges or ruptures, pressing on nearby nerves (can cause sciatica). Degenerative Disc Disease: Age-related wear and tear on the spinal discs. Osteoarthritis: Breakdown of cartilage in the facet joints of the spine. Spinal Stenosis: Narrowing of the spinal canal, often due to bone spurs, putting pressure on nerves. Spondylolisthesis: One vertebra slips forward over another. Less Common (but serious) Causes: Sciatica: Nerve pain radiating down the leg due to compression of the sciatic nerve. Kidney Stones or Kidney Infection: Referred pain to the lower back. Ankylosing Spondylitis: An inflammatory arthritis primarily affecting the spine. Spinal Infections: Osteomyelitis, discitis. Tumors: Primary or metastatic cancer in the spine. Cauda Equina Syndrome: A rare but severe compression of spinal nerves requiring emergency treatment (often with weakness, numbness in groin, bowel/bladder dysfunction). Lifestyle factors like obesity, lack of exercise, and poor posture contribute.

column2: patches in throat,high fever,extra marital contacts
column11: A small, flat spot or discoloration on the skin that is not raised or depressed. It's simply a change in skin color. Think of a freckle or a small birthmark.
column12: Medically, a macule is a primary skin lesion defined as a circumscribed (well-defined) flat area of change in skin color, less than 1 cm in diameter, without elevation or depression of the surface. It is detectable only by a change in color. If it's larger than 1 cm, it's called a patch. Causes: Melanin changes: Freckles (ephelides): Increased melanin production. Moles (nevi): Benign melanocytic proliferation. Lentigines (sun spots/age spots): Increased melanocytes due to sun exposure. Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation/hypopigmentation: Changes after skin injury or inflammation. Vitiligo: Loss of melanocytes, resulting in hypopigmented macules/patches. Vascular changes: Petechiae: Tiny red or purple spots due to minor hemorrhage. Telangiectasias: Dilated small blood vessels (spider veins). Capillary malformations (port-wine stains): Congenital vascular lesions. Other: Tinea Versicolor: Fungal infection causing lighter or darker macules/patches. Measles or Rubella rash: Early stages appear as macules. Drug eruptions.

column2: muscle wasting,high fever,extra marital contacts
column11: A severe and persistent mood disorder characterized by overwhelming sadness, loss of interest in activities, and feelings of hopelessness that significantly disrupt daily life. It's more than just a temporary feeling of being down.
column12: Medically, Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), or clinical depression, is a serious mental health condition characterized by a persistent depressed mood or loss of interest/pleasure (anhedonia) for at least two weeks, along with at least four additional symptoms from a specific list. These symptoms cause significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning. (Please refer to symptom #30, "Depression," as the general and medical explanations are identical for this term, providing a comprehensive list of criteria.)

column2: muscle wasting,patches in throat,extra marital contacts
column11: A general feeling of discomfort, illness, or uneasiness, often the first symptom of an illness. It's a sense of not feeling "right."
column12: Medically, malaise is a non-specific symptom referring to a generalized feeling of being unwell, vaguely unwell, or a subjective sense of discomfort, weakness, or fatigue. It often precedes the onset of more specific symptoms of an illness. It's a common prodromal (early warning) symptom for many conditions: Infections: Viral infections (common cold, flu, COVID-19, mononucleosis), bacterial infections (strep throat, UTIs, pneumonia), parasitic infections. The body's immune response triggers cytokines that cause systemic symptoms like malaise. Chronic Diseases: Early stages of chronic conditions like diabetes, hypothyroidism, heart failure, kidney disease, or cancer. Inflammatory Conditions: Autoimmune diseases (lupus, rheumatoid arthritis). Stress, Anxiety, Depression: Psychological factors can manifest as physical malaise. Nutritional Deficiencies: Anemia, vitamin deficiencies. Medication Side Effects: Many drugs can cause malaise. Fatigue or Overtraining. It's a very general symptom and requires other accompanying symptoms or context for diagnosis.

column2: muscle wasting,patches in throat,high fever
column11: The most serious type of skin cancer, which starts in the cells that produce melanin (pigment). It can appear as a new mole or a change in an existing one, often irregular in shape, color, or size.
column12: Medically, melanoma is a malignant neoplasm (cancer) of melanocytes, the cells responsible for producing skin pigment. It is the most aggressive and potentially life-threatening form of skin cancer due to its high propensity for metastasis (spreading to other parts of the body) if not detected and treated early. Risk Factors: Excessive UV exposure (sunlight, tanning beds), fair skin, history of sunburns, numerous moles, atypical moles, family history of melanoma, weakened immune system. Appearance (ABCDEs of Melanoma): Asymmetry: One half doesn't match the other. Border Irregularity: Edges are ragged, notched, or blurred. Color Variation: Uneven color, shades of brown, black, tan, and sometimes red, white, or blue. Diameter: Greater than 6 mm (size of a pencil eraser), though smaller melanomas can occur. Evolving: Changes in size, shape, color, elevation, or any new symptom (itching, bleeding). Diagnosis typically involves a skin biopsy. Treatment includes surgical removal, and for advanced stages, immunotherapy, targeted therapy, radiation, or chemotherapy.

column2: muscle wasting,patches in throat,high fever,extra marital contacts
column11: A feeling of sickness in the stomach, often accompanied by an urge to vomit. It's an unpleasant sensation that can range from mild queasiness to severe sickness.
column12: Medically, nausea is a subjective, unpleasant sensation that is often accompanied by autonomic symptoms such as increased salivation, pallor, sweating, and tachycardia. It is a common symptom of many conditions and is often a precursor to vomiting. Common Causes: Gastrointestinal Issues: Gastroenteritis ("stomach flu"): Viral or bacterial infection of the GI tract. Food Poisoning: Ingestion of contaminated food. Indigestion/Gastritis/Peptic Ulcer Disease. Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS). Appendicitis, Gallstones, Pancreatitis. Bowel Obstruction. Medications: Many drugs can cause nausea as a side effect (e.g., chemotherapy, antibiotics, opioids, iron supplements, some antidepressants). Pregnancy: Morning sickness. Migraine Headaches. Motion Sickness/Vertigo: Inner ear disturbances. Pain: Severe pain from any cause. Anxiety/Stress. Metabolic Disorders: Diabetic ketoacidosis, kidney failure, liver failure. Infections (systemic): Any significant infection can cause nausea. Head Injury. Brain Tumors: Especially if causing increased intracranial pressure. Heart Attack: Can present with nausea, especially in women.

column2: muscle wasting,patches in throat,high fever,extra marital contacts
column11: Discomfort or stiffness in the neck region, which can sometimes spread to the shoulders or arms, or cause headaches.
column12: Medically, neck pain (or cervicalgia) is a common musculoskeletal complaint. It can be acute or chronic and may be localized or radiate to other areas. The neck (cervical spine) is complex, supporting the head's weight while allowing extensive movement, making it vulnerable to injury and degeneration. Common Causes: Muscle Strain/Sprain: Most common, often due to poor posture (e.g., "tech neck"), sleeping in an awkward position, sudden movements, or overuse. Whiplash: Injury to the neck from a sudden, forceful back-and-forth movement. Cervical Spondylosis (Osteoarthritis of the Neck): Age-related wear and tear on the discs and joints. Herniated (Slipped) Disc: A disc in the neck bulges or ruptures, pressing on nerves (can cause pain, numbness, tingling, weakness in arm/hand - cervical radiculopathy). Spinal Stenosis: Narrowing of the spinal canal in the neck. Nerve Compression: "Pinched nerve" in the neck. Stress and Tension: Can lead to muscle tension in the neck and shoulders. Fibromyalgia. Less Common (but serious) Causes: Meningitis: Severe headache with stiff neck, fever, photophobia. Spinal Cord Compression. Tumors. Infections: Discitis, osteomyelitis. Rheumatoid Arthritis (affecting neck joints).

column2: patches in throat,high fever,extra marital contacts
column11: Recurrent patterns of thinking that are pessimistic, self-critical, or focused on problems, failures, or worries. This can include feeling hopeless, worthless, or dwelling on bad outcomes.
column12: Medically, "negative thoughts" are a core cognitive symptom across a range of mental health conditions, particularly depressive disorders, anxiety disorders, and some personality disorders. While everyone experiences negative thoughts occasionally, when they are pervasive, intrusive, or lead to significant distress and functional impairment, they become clinically significant. In Depression: Characterized by thoughts of worthlessness, guilt, hopelessness, helplessness, rumination (repetitive thinking about negative things), suicidal ideation. Often rooted in a negative view of self, the world, and the future. In Anxiety Disorders: Dominated by anxious apprehension, catastrophic thinking, overestimation of threat, specific worries (e.g., health anxiety, social anxiety). In Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD): Characterized by intrusive, unwanted thoughts (obsessions) that cause distress. In PTSD: Intrusive thoughts and flashbacks related to traumatic events. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is a common therapeutic approach that helps identify and challenge these negative thought patterns. They are often linked to neurochemical imbalances and maladaptive coping mechanisms.

column2: muscle wasting,high fever,extra marital contacts
column11: Waking up drenched in sweat, even when your bedroom is cool. It's more than just sweating a bit because you're warm under the covers.
column12: Medically, night sweats are episodes of excessive perspiration during sleep that soak clothing or bedding, requiring a change of attire or linens. They are a significant symptom because they often indicate an underlying medical condition, especially if recurrent and severe. Common Causes: Infections: Tuberculosis (TB): A classic symptom. Endocarditis (heart valve infection), Osteomyelitis (bone infection), Abscesses. HIV/AIDS. Mononucleosis. Chronic bacterial or viral infections. Hormonal Changes: Menopause (Hot Flashes): Very common cause in women. Hyperthyroidism (Overactive Thyroid): Increased metabolism. Pheochromocytoma: Rare adrenal gland tumor. Cancers: Lymphoma (especially Hodgkin's lymphoma): A classic "B symptom" (fever, night sweats, weight loss). Leukemia. Other solid tumors. Medications: Antidepressants (SSRIs). Aspirin and NSAIDs (less common). Some diabetes medications. Hormone therapy. Hypoglycemia (Low Blood Sugar): Body releases adrenaline to raise blood sugar, causing sweating. Anxiety/Stress. Sleep Apnea: Disrupted breathing during sleep.

column11: Swelling of a node, usually referring to a lymph node (a small, bean-shaped gland part of the immune system). This feels like a lump under the skin.
column12: Medically, "nodal swelling" is synonymous with lymphadenopathy or enlarged lymph nodes. (Please refer to symptom #36, "Enlarged lymph nodes," as the general and medical explanations are identical for this term.) It indicates an active immune response, most commonly to infection (viral, bacterial), but can also be a sign of inflammation, autoimmune disease, or malignancy (lymphoma, leukemia, metastatic cancer). column2: fatigue,weight loss,restlessness,lethargy,irregular sugar level,blurred and distorted vision,obesity,excessive hunger,increased appetite,polyuria
column11: Having an excessive amount of body fat, to the point where it can negatively affect your health. It's usually measured by body mass index (BMI).
column12: Medically, obesity is defined as an excessive accumulation of body fat that presents a risk to health. It is typically diagnosed using the Body Mass Index (BMI), a measure calculated from a person's weight and height (BMI=weight?(kg)/(height?(m))2). BMI Classifications (WHO): Overweight: BMI 25.0 to 29.9 Obese Class I: BMI 30.0 to 34.9 Obese Class II: BMI 35.0 to 39.9 Obese Class III (Morbid Obesity): BMI ? 40.0 Obesity is a complex, multifactorial disease influenced by genetics, environment, metabolism, and behavior. It is a major risk factor for numerous chronic diseases, including: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus Cardiovascular Diseases: Hypertension (high blood pressure), coronary artery disease, stroke, heart failure. Certain Cancers: Colon, breast, endometrial, kidney, liver, ovarian, pancreatic, prostate, and gallbladder cancers. Musculoskeletal Problems: Osteoarthritis (especially knees and hips), back pain. Sleep Apnea. Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD). Gallstones. Infertility. Depression and Anxiety. Management often involves lifestyle changes (diet, exercise), behavioral therapy, medications, and sometimes bariatric surgery.

column2: fatigue,weight loss,restlessness,lethargy,irregular sugar level,blurred and distorted vision,obesity,excessive hunger,increased appetite,polyuria
column11: Experiencing discomfort, stinging, or sharp pain when passing stool.
column12: Medically, pain during bowel movements (or dyschezia if difficult defecation is implied, or proctalgia if rectal pain) is a common symptom that can arise from issues within the anus, rectum, or surrounding structures. Common Causes: Anal Fissure: A small tear in the lining of the anus, often caused by passing hard, large stools. Characterized by sharp, tearing pain during and after defecation, often with bright red blood on stool or toilet paper. Hemorrhoids: Swollen, inflamed veins in the rectum or anus. Can cause pain, itching, bleeding, and discomfort, especially with straining. Constipation: Straining to pass hard stools can cause pain and exacerbate existing anal conditions. Proctitis: Inflammation of the rectum, often due to inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's, ulcerative colitis), infection (STIs), or radiation. Perianal Abscess/Fistula: A collection of pus or an abnormal tunnel near the anus. Causes severe pain, swelling, and sometimes fever. Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD): Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis can cause rectal inflammation and pain. Foreign Body in Rectum. Rectal Prolapse: Part of the rectum slips out of the anus. Less common: Anal cancer.

column2: weight loss,restlessness,lethargy,irregular sugar level,blurred and distorted vision,obesity,excessive hunger,increased appetite,polyuria
column11: Discomfort or aching around the anus or rectum.
column12: Medically, pain in the anal region (or proctalgia) is a common complaint with various possible etiologies, often overlapping with pain during bowel movements. Common Causes: Anal Fissure: (See above, also causes pain outside defecation). Hemorrhoids: (See above). Perianal Abscess/Fistula: A significant cause of severe, throbbing pain, often with redness, swelling, and fever. Proctalgia Fugax: Brief, sudden, severe spasms of pain in the rectum, often at night, without an identifiable cause. Levator Ani Syndrome: Chronic pain and tenderness in the pelvic floor muscles (levator ani muscles). Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS): Can cause referred rectal pain. Coccydynia: Tailbone pain that can radiate to the anal area. Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs): Such as herpes or gonorrhea, causing proctitis or perianal lesions. Infections: Perianal cellulitis. Less common: Anal cancer, solitary rectal ulcer syndrome.

column2: fatigue,restlessness,lethargy,irregular sugar level,blurred and distorted vision,obesity,excessive hunger,increased appetite,polyuria
column11: Any discomfort, aching, or sharpness felt in or around the eye.
column12: Medically, eye pain (or ophthalmalgia) can range from a superficial irritation to a deep, throbbing ache, and its cause can be ocular (within the eye) or orbital (within the eye socket) or referred. It's often accompanied by other symptoms like redness, light sensitivity, or vision changes. Superficial Eye Pain (often from the surface of the eye): Foreign Body: Something in the eye (dust, eyelash). Corneal Abrasion: Scratch on the clear front surface of the eye. Conjunctivitis ("Pink Eye"): Inflammation of the conjunctiva (membrane lining the eyelid and eye surface), often viral or bacterial. Causes redness, itching/grittiness, discharge. Dry Eyes: Insufficient tear production. Blepharitis: Inflammation of the eyelids. Stye (Hordeolum): Bacterial infection of an oil gland in the eyelid. Deep/Orbital Eye Pain (more serious, often from inside the eye or surrounding structures): Glaucoma (Acute Angle-Closure): Sudden, severe pain, redness, blurred vision, halos around lights, nausea, due to rapid increase in eye pressure. A medical emergency. Optic Neuritis: Inflammation of the optic nerve, often with pain worsened by eye movement and vision loss. Can be associated with multiple sclerosis. Uveitis: Inflammation of the middle layer of the eye (uvea). Scleritis/Episcleritis: Inflammation of the white outer layer of the eyeball. Sinusitis: Inflammation of the sinuses can cause pain behind the eyes. Migraine Headaches. Orbital Cellulitis: Infection of the tissues around the eye, a serious emergency. Trauma to the eye.

column11: A general term for aching, stiffness, or soreness felt in a joint. (This is identical to symptom #54, "Joint pain").
column12: Medically, pain in a joint (or arthralgia) can be caused by various factors, including inflammation (arthritis), injury, or degeneration. (Please refer to symptom #54, "Joint pain," for a comprehensive general and medical explanation.)

column2: fatigue,weight loss,restlessness,irregular sugar level,blurred and distorted vision,obesity,excessive hunger,increased appetite,polyuria
column11: Discomfort or aching experienced in the arms or legs, which can be mild or severe, and may involve muscles, bones, or nerves.
column12: Medically, pain in limbs (also known as extremity pain) is a broad symptom. It can be categorized by the tissue type involved (musculoskeletal, neuropathic, vascular) or the underlying mechanism. Musculoskeletal Causes: Muscle Strains/Sprains: Overuse, injury. Tendinitis/Bursitis: Inflammation around joints (e.g., tennis elbow, Achilles tendinitis). Arthritis: Osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, gout (can affect peripheral joints). Fibromyalgia: Widespread musculoskeletal pain. Bone Fractures/Stress Fractures. Shin Splints. Neuropathic (Nerve) Causes: Peripheral Neuropathy: Damage to nerves, often causing burning, tingling, numbness, or shooting pains (e.g., diabetic neuropathy, B12 deficiency, chemotherapy-induced). Radiculopathy: "Pinched nerve" originating from the spine (e.g., sciatica in the leg, cervical radiculopathy in the arm). Carpal Tunnel Syndrome/Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome: Nerve compression in the wrist or ankle. Vascular (Blood Vessel) Causes: Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD): Narrowing of arteries, causing claudication (cramping pain in legs with exertion, relieved by rest). Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): Blood clot in a deep vein, causing pain, swelling, warmth (often in one leg). Raynaud's Phenomenon: Spasm of small arteries. Other Causes: Infections: Cellulitis, osteomyelitis. Compartment Syndrome: Swelling within a muscle compartment, compressing nerves and blood vessels. Restless Legs Syndrome: Unpleasant sensations and urge to move legs. Tumors: Bone tumors, soft tissue sarcomas.

column2: fatigue,weight loss,restlessness,lethargy,blurred and distorted vision,obesity,excessive hunger,increased appetite,polyuria
column11: Discomfort or aching specifically in the stomach region, which is the upper part of the abdomen. It often feels like burning, gnawing, or a dull ache.
column12: Medically, pain in the stomach usually refers to epigastric pain (pain in the upper central abdomen). While commonly associated with "stomach" problems, it can also originate from nearby organs. Common Causes (related to the stomach itself): Gastritis: Inflammation of the stomach lining. Peptic Ulcer Disease: Sores in the stomach (gastric ulcer) or the first part of the small intestine (duodenal ulcer). Often described as a gnawing or burning pain, relieved by food or antacids, but returning hours later. Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD): Acid reflux can cause burning epigastric pain. Indigestion (Dyspepsia): As discussed earlier. Gastroparesis: Delayed stomach emptying. Other Causes (often felt in stomach area): Gallstones/Cholecystitis: Pain in the right upper abdomen that can radiate to the epigastrium, often after fatty meals. Pancreatitis: Inflammation of the pancreas, causing severe epigastric pain radiating to the back. Heart Attack: Can present with epigastric pain, especially in women. Bowel Obstruction. Functional Dyspepsia: Pain without a clear anatomical cause.

column2: fatigue,weight loss,restlessness,lethargy,irregular sugar level,obesity,excessive hunger,increased appetite,polyuria
column11: A sensation that your heart is beating too fast, too hard, irregularly, skipping beats, or fluttering in your chest. It feels like your heart is calling attention to itself.
column12: Medically, palpitations are subjective sensations of the heart beating. While often benign, they can be a symptom of underlying cardiac arrhythmias or other medical conditions. Physiological (Normal) Causes: Stress, Anxiety, Panic Attacks: Adrenaline release. Strenuous Exercise. Caffeine, Nicotine, Alcohol. Certain Illicit Drugs (e.g., cocaine, amphetamines). Dehydration. Fever. Pregnancy. Medical Conditions: Arrhythmias (Heart Rhythm Disorders): Premature Atrial Contractions (PACs) or Premature Ventricular Contractions (PVCs): "Skipped beats." Supraventricular Tachycardia (SVT): Rapid, regular heart rate. Atrial Fibrillation/Flutter: Irregularly irregular heartbeat. Ventricular Tachycardia: More serious, rapid, and potentially life-threatening. Hyperthyroidism (Overactive Thyroid): Increased metabolic rate and heart stimulation. Anemia: Heart works harder to deliver oxygen. Hypoglycemia (Low Blood Sugar). Electrolyte Imbalances: Especially potassium, magnesium. Heart Failure. Valvular Heart Disease. Certain Medications: Decongestants, asthma inhalers, thyroid hormones. If palpitations are frequent, prolonged, associated with dizziness, chest pain, or shortness of breath, they warrant medical evaluation.

column2: fatigue,weight loss,restlessness,lethargy,irregular sugar level,blurred and distorted vision,excessive hunger,increased appetite,polyuria
column11: Lips that are extremely dry, cracked, and possibly peeling, often making them feel tight and uncomfortable.
column12: Medically, parched lips (or cheilitis sicca when pathologically dry) are primarily a sign of dehydration. The lips are sensitive to moisture loss because their skin is thinner and lacks sebaceous glands. Most Common Cause: Dehydration from insufficient fluid intake, excessive fluid loss (e.g., vomiting, diarrhea, fever, heavy sweating), or uncontrolled diabetes. Environmental Factors: Exposure to dry, cold, or windy weather; sun exposure. Mouth Breathing: Especially while sleeping. Certain Medications: Diuretics, isotretinoin (for acne), anticholinergics. Nutritional Deficiencies: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2), iron, zinc. Systemic Diseases: Sjogren's syndrome (autoimmune, causes dry mouth/eyes), hypothyroidism. Allergic Contact Cheilitis: Reaction to lip products, toothpaste, etc. Licking Lips Excessively: Can create a cycle of temporary relief followed by worse dryness.

column11: Visible white, red, or discolored spots or areas on the inside of the throat, especially on the tonsils or back of the pharynx.
column12: Medically, "patches in the throat" typically refer to abnormal lesions, exudates, or discolorations on the pharyngeal or tonsillar mucosa. Their appearance (color, texture, distribution) can help narrow down the cause. White Patches: Streptococcal Pharyngitis ("Strep Throat"): Bacterial infection, often with white spots or streaks of pus on tonsils. Mononucleosis (Mono): Viral infection, can cause white patches, often with significant swelling of tonsils. Oral Thrush (Candidiasis): Fungal infection (Candida albicans), causes creamy white patches that can be scraped off, revealing red, raw tissue underneath. Common in infants, immunocompromised individuals, or after antibiotic/steroid use. Diphtheria: (Rare due to vaccination) Causes a thick, gray membrane. Leukoplakia: White patches that cannot be scraped off, often due to chronic irritation (e.g., smoking), can be precancerous. Red Patches/Inflammation: Viral Pharyngitis: Most common cause of sore throat, diffuse redness. Follicular Tonsillitis: Red, inflamed tonsils with white or yellow spots. Herpangina: Viral infection causing small red spots and blisters/ulcers. Other: Peritonsillar Abscess: Collection of pus behind the tonsil, causing severe unilateral pain, difficulty swallowing, muffled voice. Squamous Cell Carcinoma: Oral or throat cancer, can appear as a red or white patch that doesn't heal. I will continue with the next batch. Let me know if you have any questions! column11: Experiencing discomfort or pain when taking steps or putting weight on your legs or feet.
column12: Medically, painful walking (or gait dysfunction with pain) is a common symptom with a wide range of underlying causes, often involving the musculoskeletal system, nervous system, or vascular system of the lower limbs. Musculoskeletal Causes: Arthritis: Osteoarthritis (hip, knee, ankle, foot), rheumatoid arthritis, gout. Pain is typically worse with movement and weight-bearing. Muscle Strains/Sprains: In legs, hips, or feet. Tendinitis/Bursitis: Inflammation of tendons (Achilles, patellar) or bursae (hip, knee). Plantar Fasciitis: Pain in the heel/arch of the foot, often worse with first steps in the morning. Stress Fractures: Small cracks in bones, common in feet or lower legs due to repetitive stress. Shin Splints. Bunions, Hammertoes, Calluses: Foot deformities causing pain with pressure. Lower Back Pain/Sciatica: Pain originating from the spine can radiate down the leg and cause difficulty walking due to nerve compression. Vascular Causes: Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD): Intermittent claudication ? cramping pain in the calves, thighs, or buttocks that occurs during walking and is relieved by rest, due to insufficient blood flow to the muscles. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): Blood clot in a leg vein, causing pain and swelling, making walking painful. Neurological Causes: Peripheral Neuropathy: Nerve damage in the feet/legs can cause pain, burning, numbness, or loss of sensation leading to an altered gait. Spinal Stenosis: Narrowing of the spinal canal can cause leg pain and weakness during walking (neurogenic claudication). Infections: Cellulitis, osteomyelitis. Footwear: Ill-fitting shoes. Trauma.

column11: A small, raised bump on the skin that contains pus. It looks like a small pimple with a white or yellowish center.
column12: Medically, a pustule is a circumscribed, elevated lesion containing pus. Pus is a thick fluid composed of dead white blood cells, cellular debris, and bacteria. Pustules are typically seen in inflammatory skin conditions, often associated with bacterial infection. Common Causes: Acne Vulgaris: The most common cause, especially on the face, chest, and back. Pustules are a type of inflamed acne lesion. Folliculitis: Inflammation and infection of hair follicles, often bacterial (e.g., Staph aureus) or fungal, forming pus-filled bumps around hair follicles. Rosacea: A chronic inflammatory skin condition, can cause pustules, especially on the face. Impetigo: A contagious bacterial skin infection, particularly common in children, often forming pustules that can crust over. Pustular Psoriasis: A rare form of psoriasis characterized by widespread pustules. Contact Dermatitis: Severe allergic reactions can sometimes present with pustules. Drug Eruptions: Certain medications can cause pustular rashes. The presence of pus indicates an inflammatory response, often with an infectious component.

column11: Breathing much faster than normal, even when at rest, often accompanied by shallow breaths.
column12: Medically, rapid breathing is known as tachypnea (an increased respiratory rate) or hyperpnea (an increase in depth and rate of breathing). It is usually a compensatory mechanism or a sign of increased physiological demand or distress. Common Causes: Respiratory Conditions: Asthma/COPD Exacerbation: Airways narrow, body tries to get more oxygen. Pneumonia/Bronchitis: Lung infection. Pulmonary Embolism: Blood clot in lungs, causing sudden shortness of breath and rapid breathing. Pneumothorax: Collapsed lung. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). Cardiovascular Conditions: Heart Failure: Fluid buildup in lungs makes breathing difficult. Heart Attack. Metabolic Acidosis: The body tries to "blow off" excess acid (CO2) by increasing breathing rate and depth (Kussmaul breathing, e.g., in Diabetic Ketoacidosis, kidney failure). Fever/Infection (Sepsis): Increased metabolic rate and body's response to infection. Anemia: Body tries to compensate for reduced oxygen-carrying capacity. Anxiety/Panic Attack: Hyperventilation. Pain: Acute severe pain. Hypoxia: Lack of oxygen. Drug Overdose/Recreational Drug Use.

column11: Any noticeable change in the skin's texture or color, usually appearing as red, irritated patches, bumps, blisters, or scales. They can be itchy, painful, or asymptomatic.
column12: Medically, a rash (or dermatological eruption) is a general term for an outbreak of skin lesions. Rashes are categorized by their appearance (e.g., maculopapular, vesicular, pustular, urticarial, scaly) and distribution. They can be caused by infections, allergies, autoimmune diseases, or other irritants. Common Causes: Allergies/Irritants: Contact Dermatitis: Allergic reaction to substances (poison ivy, nickel, detergents, cosmetics). Hives (Urticaria): Itchy welts from allergic reactions (food, drugs, insect bites) or other triggers. Drug Eruptions: Rashes caused by medication side effects. Infections: Viral Rashes: Measles, rubella, chickenpox (varicella), shingles (herpes zoster), roseola, fifth disease, hand-foot-and-mouth disease, viral exanthem from common cold/flu. Bacterial Rashes: Impetigo, cellulitis, scarlet fever. Fungal Rashes: Ringworm (tinea corporis), athlete's foot (tinea pedis), candidiasis. Parasitic Infestations: Scabies, lice. Autoimmune Diseases: Eczema (Atopic Dermatitis): Chronic itchy, inflamed skin. Psoriasis: Red, scaly patches. Lupus: Butterfly rash on the face, discoid lupus. Heat Rash (Miliaria). Insect Bites. Sunburn. Systemic Illnesses: Can sometimes manifest with a rash (e.g., Lyme disease).

column11: Small, reddish dots or bumps appearing on various parts of the skin.
column12: Medically, "red spots over the body" is a non-specific description. The precise appearance, size, and distribution of these spots are crucial for diagnosis. Common Types of Red Spots: Petechiae: Pinpoint (1-2 mm) red or purple spots, flat, non-blanching (don't disappear when pressed). Caused by tiny hemorrhages. Can indicate low platelet count, clotting disorders, severe infection (sepsis), vasculitis. Purpura: Larger (>2 mm) red or purple spots, flat, non-blanching, also due to bleeding under the skin. Can be due to similar causes as petechiae but more extensive. Macules/Papules (part of a maculopapular rash): Small, flat red spots (macules) or slightly raised red bumps (papules). Typical of many viral rashes (e.g., measles, rubella, roseola, viral exanthem of cold/flu, COVID-19 rashes). Folliculitis: Small red bumps centered around hair follicles, often with a pustule. Cherry Angiomas: Small, benign bright red bumps, common with aging. Insect Bites: Small, itchy red bumps. Hives (Urticaria): Itchy, raised red welts that blanch. Drug eruptions. Heat rash. Fungal infections (e.g., Tinea Corporis can have red, scaly patches). Any new, widespread, unexplained, or rapidly spreading red spots, especially with fever, should be evaluated by a doctor.

column11: A persistent red discoloration of the skin around the nostrils and possibly extending onto the cheeks.
column12: Medically, redness around the nose (or perinasal erythema) can be caused by various dermatological conditions, often involving inflammation or vascular changes. Common Causes: Rosacea: A chronic inflammatory skin condition primarily affecting the face, causing redness, visible blood vessels, papules, and pustules, often around the nose and central face. Rhinophyma (thickened, bumpy nose) is a severe complication. Seborrheic Dermatitis: A common inflammatory skin condition causing red, flaky, itchy patches, often in oily areas like around the nose, eyebrows, and scalp. Eczema/Contact Dermatitis: Irritation or allergic reaction to products (facial cleansers, cosmetics) or environmental factors. Perioral Dermatitis: A rash, often around the mouth, but can extend to the nose, characterized by small red bumps and some scaling. Lupus (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus - SLE): Can cause a "butterfly rash" (malar rash) that often includes the bridge of the nose and cheeks. Sunburn: Acute redness from sun exposure. Acne Vulgaris: Inflamed pimples can cause localized redness. Broken Capillaries (Telangiectasias): Small, visible blood vessels. Over-wiping/blowing the nose: During a cold or allergies.

column11: The white part of your eye appears red or bloodshot.
column12: Medically, redness of the eye (or ocular hyperemia/conjunctival injection) is caused by the dilation or inflammation of blood vessels in the conjunctiva (the clear membrane covering the white part of the eye and lining the eyelids) or episclera/sclera. Common Causes: Conjunctivitis ("Pink Eye"): The most common cause. Inflammation of the conjunctiva, often viral (very common, watery discharge) or bacterial (pus-like discharge), or allergic (itchy, watery eyes). Allergies: Allergic conjunctivitis, triggered by pollen, dust, etc. Dry Eyes: Insufficient tear production, leading to irritation and redness. Blepharitis: Inflammation of the eyelids, often with redness at the lid margins. Subconjunctival Hemorrhage: A burst blood vessel on the surface of the eye, causing a bright red patch. Looks dramatic but is usually harmless and resolves on its own. Foreign Body/Irritants: Dust, smoke, chemicals, contact lens irritation. Contact Lens Overwear/Poor Hygiene. More Serious Causes (often with pain, blurred vision, light sensitivity): Glaucoma (Acute Angle-Closure): Sudden, severe eye pain, redness, blurred vision, halos. Emergency. Uveitis: Inflammation inside the eye. Scleritis/Episcleritis: Inflammation of the white part of the eye. Corneal Abrasion/Ulcer: Scratch or open sore on the cornea. Iritis: Inflammation of the iris.

column11: Coughing up phlegm or mucus that has a brownish or reddish-brown color, resembling rust.
column12: Medically, rusty sputum is a significant sign, typically indicating the presence of old blood or red blood cell breakdown products (like hemosiderin) in the respiratory secretions. It's often associated with specific types of lung infections. Common Causes: Pneumonia (especially Pneumococcal Pneumonia): A classic symptom. The bacteria Streptococcus pneumoniae causes inflammation and red blood cell leakage into the alveoli, leading to rusty-colored sputum. Bronchitis: Can sometimes be seen in chronic bronchitis. Lung Cancer: Can cause bloody or rust-colored sputum. Pulmonary Embolism: Can cause sudden onset of bloody or rusty sputum (hemoptysis). Heart Failure (Pulmonary Edema): Can lead to pink, frothy, or rusty-tinged sputum due to fluid and red blood cells in the lungs. Bronchiectasis: Chronic inflammation and dilation of airways can lead to recurrent infections and sometimes bloody/rusty sputum. Rusty sputum always warrants medical investigation, particularly if accompanied by fever, chest pain, or shortness of breath.

column2: vomiting,dehydration,diarrhoea
column3: stop eating solid food for while
column4: try taking small sips of water
column11: Areas of skin that appear dry, flaky, or peeling, often with a rough texture.
column12: Medically, scaling skin (or desquamation) is the shedding of the outermost layer of the epidermis (stratum corneum) in flakes or sheets. It's a common sign of various dermatological conditions where there is abnormal keratinization (skin cell production and maturation). Common Causes: Dry Skin (Xerosis): Most common cause, especially in low humidity or with excessive washing. Eczema (Dermatitis): Inflammatory conditions causing dry, itchy, red, and scaly patches (e.g., atopic dermatitis, contact dermatitis). Psoriasis: A chronic autoimmune disease characterized by thick, silvery scales on red patches, often on elbows, knees, scalp. Seborrheic Dermatitis: Red, greasy, scaly patches, typically on the scalp (dandruff), face (around nose, eyebrows), chest. Fungal Infections: Ringworm (tinea corporis), athlete's foot (tinea pedis), tinea versicolor, causing scaly, often itchy patches. Actinic Keratosis: Precancerous scaly patches from sun damage. Ichthyosis: A group of genetic disorders causing extremely dry, scaly skin. Sunburn: Peeling after a severe sunburn. Medication Side Effects.

column11: Pain that radiates along the path of the sciatic nerve, which runs from your lower back, through your hips and buttocks, and down each leg. It typically affects only one side of the body.
column12: Medically, sciatica is a symptom, not a diagnosis, indicating nerve root irritation or compression of the sciatic nerve (which is actually a bundle of nerves originating from the lower lumbar and sacral spinal cord roots L4, L5, S1, S2, S3). Most Common Causes: Herniated (Slipped) Lumbar Disc: The jelly-like center of a spinal disc bulges out and presses on the nerve root. Spinal Stenosis: Narrowing of the spinal canal, compressing the nerve roots. Spondylolisthesis: One vertebra slips forward over another. Piriformis Syndrome: The piriformis muscle (in the buttock) spasms or tightens, irritating the sciatic nerve. Lumbar Degenerative Disc Disease: As discs degenerate, they can lose height and compress nerves. Trauma to the lower back/pelvis. Less common: Spinal tumors, infections. Symptoms: Often described as a sharp, shooting, burning pain that radiates down the leg, sometimes with numbness, tingling ("pins and needles"), or muscle weakness in the affected leg or foot. Pain is often worsened by coughing, sneezing, or prolonged sitting. I will continue with the next batch. Please let me know if there are any specific terms that are unclear! Got it. column11: Difficulty speaking clearly, where words sound mumbled, unclear, or run together. It can make it hard for others to understand what you're saying.
column12: Medically, dysarthria is a motor speech disorder characterized by difficulty articulating words due to weakness, paralysis, or incoordination of the muscles used for speech (lips, tongue, jaw, vocal cords, respiratory muscles). It is distinct from aphasia (difficulty with language comprehension or production). Common Causes (Neurological): Stroke: Damage to brain areas controlling speech muscles. This is a common and serious cause, especially if sudden onset. Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA): A "mini-stroke" with temporary symptoms. Alcohol Intoxication or Drug Use: Affects coordination. Head Injury/Concussion: Brain trauma. Neurodegenerative Diseases: Parkinson's Disease: Often causes quiet, monotonous, and sometimes slurred speech (hypophonia). Multiple Sclerosis (MS): Affects nerve pathways. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) / Motor Neuron Disease: Weakness of speech muscles. Huntington's Disease. Brain Tumors: Depending on location. Bell's Palsy: Though primarily facial paralysis, severe cases can affect lip movement for speech. Severe Fatigue or Sleep Deprivation. Certain Medications: Sedatives, muscle relaxants.

column2: cough,high fever,breathlessness,family history,mucoid sputum
column11: Tiny, dark specks, usually appearing under the nail. They often look like splinters.
column12: Medically, these are typically splinter hemorrhages. They appear as thin, red to brownish-black lines running lengthwise under the nail plate. They are caused by tiny blood clots that damage small blood vessels (capillaries) in the nail bed. Common Causes: Trauma: The most frequent cause, often from minor injury to the nail (e.g., catching a finger, repetitive microtrauma from certain activities). Nail Psoriasis: Can cause splinter hemorrhages. Certain Medications: Anticoagulants (blood thinners). More Serious (but less common) Causes: Infective Endocarditis: A serious infection of the heart's inner lining or valves. Splinter hemorrhages in this context are due to tiny clots (emboli) breaking off from the infected heart valves and lodging in capillaries elsewhere. Often accompanied by fever, fatigue, heart murmur. Systemic Vasculitis: Inflammation of blood vessels. Other Systemic Diseases: Lupus, antiphospholipid syndrome. If associated with fever, new heart murmur, or other systemic symptoms, or if occurring without obvious trauma, medical evaluation is warranted.

column2: fatigue,high fever,breathlessness,family history,mucoid sputum
column11: Pain, scratchiness, or irritation of the throat that often worsens when swallowing.
column12: Medically, a pharyngitis (inflammation of the pharynx) or tonsillitis (inflammation of the tonsils) is a common symptom. It's often caused by infections or irritation. Common Causes: Viral Infections (Most Common): Common Cold/Flu/Other Respiratory Viruses (e.g., COVID-19): Often accompanied by runny nose, cough, sneezing. Mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr Virus): Can cause severe sore throat with swollen tonsils (often with white patches) and fatigue. Bacterial Infections: Streptococcal Pharyngitis ("Strep Throat"): Caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. Can lead to rheumatic fever if untreated. Often presents with sudden onset, fever, painful swallowing, red tonsils, sometimes white spots/streaks, no cough. Diphtheria: (Rare due to vaccination) Causes a thick gray membrane in the throat. Allergies: Postnasal drip from allergies can irritate the throat. Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)/Laryngopharyngeal Reflux (LPR): Stomach acid irritating the throat. Environmental Irritants: Dry air, smoke, pollution, chemical fumes. Voice Misuse/Overuse: Yelling, prolonged speaking. Less common: Peritonsillar abscess (severe unilateral pain, difficulty opening mouth), epiglottitis (severe, life-threatening inflammation of epiglottis).

column2: fatigue,cough,breathlessness,family history,mucoid sputum
column11: Problems with speaking, ranging from difficulty finding words, forming sentences, or articulating sounds clearly.
column12: Medically, "speech difficulties" is a broad term encompassing several specific disorders: Dysarthria: Difficulty with the physical articulation of speech due to muscle weakness or incoordination (see symptom #91 "Slurred speech"). Aphasia: Difficulty with language itself (comprehension, speaking, reading, writing). This is due to damage to the language centers of the brain. Broca's Aphasia (Expressive): Difficulty producing speech, but comprehension is relatively preserved. Wernicke's Aphasia (Receptive): Fluent but nonsensical speech, with impaired comprehension. Dysphonia: Voice quality problems (e.g., hoarseness, breathiness) due to issues with the vocal cords (see symptom #48 "Hoarseness"). Apraxia of Speech: Difficulty planning and sequencing the muscle movements needed for speech, despite normal muscle strength. Common Causes: Stroke/TIA: Very common causes of both dysarthria and aphasia. Head Trauma. Neurodegenerative Diseases: Parkinson's, ALS, MS, Huntington's, Alzheimer's (especially affecting language). Brain Tumors. Infections: Encephalitis, meningitis. Developmental Disorders: In children (e.g., language delay, stuttering). Genetic Conditions. Alcohol/Drug Intoxication. Certain Medications.

column2: fatigue,cough,high fever,family history,mucoid sputum
column11: Any kind of discolored mark or raised bump appearing on the skin of the face, such as pimples, blemishes, freckles, or darker patches.
column12: Medically, "spots on the face" is a very general description covering a vast array of dermatological lesions. The specific characteristics (color, size, texture, distribution, associated symptoms) are crucial for diagnosis. Common Causes: Acne Vulgaris: Blackheads, whiteheads, papules, pustules, cysts. Freckles (Ephelides) & Lentigines (Sun/Age Spots): Pigmented macules due to sun exposure. Moles (Nevi): Benign pigmented lesions. Post-Inflammatory Hyperpigmentation (PIH): Dark spots left after acne or inflammation. Melasma: Symmetrical brown/gray-brown patches, often on cheeks, forehead, upper lip, due to hormonal changes and sun. Rosacea: Redness, papules, pustules, visible blood vessels. Seborrheic Dermatitis: Red, flaky, greasy patches, often around nose, eyebrows. Perioral Dermatitis: Small red bumps around mouth/nose. Eczema/Dermatitis: Dry, itchy, red patches. Hives (Urticaria). Warts: Viral skin growths. Milia: Tiny white cysts. Telangiectasias (Spider Veins): Small dilated blood vessels. Infections: Impetigo, fungal infections, viral rashes (e.g., chickenpox, measles). Skin Cancers: Basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma (any new or changing lesion, especially if irregular, should be checked).

column2: fatigue,cough,high fever,breathlessness,mucoid sputum
column11: Difficulty moving your neck, often accompanied by pain, especially when trying to turn your head from side to side or up and down.
column12: Medically, a stiff neck (or torticollis if head is twisted/tilted) is a common complaint, usually due to muscle strain or spasm. Common Causes (Musculoskeletal): Muscle Strain/Spasm: Most frequent cause. Often from poor posture (e.g., "tech neck"), sleeping in an awkward position, sudden movements, stress, or minor injury. Whiplash: Injury from a sudden jolt to the neck. Cervical Spondylosis (Neck Arthritis): Degenerative changes in the neck spine. Herniated Cervical Disc: A "slipped disc" in the neck can cause stiffness and pain, potentially radiating to the arm. Less Common (but serious) Causes: Meningitis: Inflammation of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord. Characterized by a severe stiff neck (nuchal rigidity) that makes it difficult or impossible to touch the chin to the chest, often accompanied by fever, severe headache, confusion, and light sensitivity. A medical emergency. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: Bleeding around the brain, can cause sudden, severe headache and neck stiffness. Spinal Infection (e.g., osteomyelitis, discitis): Infection in the bones or discs of the neck. Tumors in the neck or spine. Certain Medications: Some antipsychotics can cause dystonia leading to neck stiffness.

column2: fatigue,cough,high fever,breathlessness,family history
column11: Any discomfort, aching, or sharpness felt in the general abdominal area. (This is identical to symptom #77, "Pain in stomach," and #7, "Belly pain").
column12: Medically, "stomach pain" is a lay term for abdominal pain. Its precise location, character, and accompanying symptoms are key for diagnosis. (Please refer to symptoms #7, "Belly pain," and #77, "Pain in stomach," for a comprehensive general and medical explanation, as the causes are identical.)

column2: fatigue,cough,high fever,breathlessness,family history,mucoid sputum
column11: Visible puffiness or enlargement of the ankles, often affecting both legs. The skin might look stretched or shiny.
column12: Medically, swollen ankles (or ankle edema) result from the accumulation of excess fluid in the interstitial tissues of the ankle region. It's often a sign of peripheral edema and can be unilateral (one ankle) or bilateral (both ankles). Common Causes (often bilateral): Standing or Sitting for Prolonged Periods: Gravity causes fluid to pool. Pregnancy: Hormonal changes, increased blood volume, and pressure on veins. Obesity. Venous Insufficiency: Valves in leg veins are weak, leading to blood pooling. Heart Failure: The heart's reduced pumping efficiency causes fluid backup, leading to swelling, especially in dependent areas. Often accompanied by shortness of breath, fatigue. Kidney Disease/Failure: Impaired ability to excrete excess fluid and sodium. Liver Disease (Cirrhosis): Reduced production of albumin (a protein that keeps fluid in blood vessels) and portal hypertension. Medications: Many drugs can cause ankle swelling (e.g., calcium channel blockers for blood pressure, NSAIDs, corticosteroids, some diabetes drugs, estrogens). Nutritional Deficiencies: Severe protein deficiency. Unilateral Causes (one ankle): Injury/Trauma: Sprain, fracture. Infection: Cellulitis. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): Blood clot in a leg vein, causing sudden, painful swelling. Medical emergency. Arthritis: Gout, septic arthritis.

column2: cough,high fever,breathlessness,family history,mucoid sputum
column11: Veins or arteries that appear larger, bulging, or more prominent than usual, often visible just under the skin.
column12: Medically, "swollen blood vessels" can refer to several distinct conditions depending on whether it's an artery or a vein, and the underlying cause. Swollen Veins (most common interpretation): Varicose Veins: Enlarged, twisted veins, typically in the legs, due to weakened valves that allow blood to pool. They are common, often visible, and can cause aching, heaviness, or itching. Thrombophlebitis: Inflammation of a vein, often accompanied by a blood clot (thrombus). Superficial Thrombophlebitis: Affects veins just under the skin, often feels like a painful, red, hard cord. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): Blood clot in a deep vein, causing swelling, pain, warmth (often in one leg). This is serious due to the risk of pulmonary embolism. Phlebitis: Inflammation of a vein without a clot. Swollen Arteries (less common, usually more serious): Aneurysm: A localized balloon-like bulge in an artery wall due to weakening. Can be anywhere (aortic, cerebral, popliteal) and are often asymptomatic until rupture, which is life-threatening. Arteritis/Vasculitis: Inflammation of artery walls (e.g., giant cell arteritis can cause tender, swollen temporal artery on the scalp, with headache and vision loss). Pseudoaneurysm: Collection of blood leaking from an artery that forms a pulsating hematoma. The location, pulsatility, and associated symptoms are crucial for distinguishing these.

column2: fatigue,high fever,breathlessness,family history,mucoid sputum
column11: A noticeable enlargement or distension of the abdomen, often making your belly feel tight, full, or bloated.
column12: Medically, swelling of the stomach (or abdominal distension/bloating) can be caused by gas, fluid, or masses within the abdominal cavity or organs. Common Causes (Often Benign): Gas/Bloating: Excess intestinal gas due to diet (fermentable foods), swallowing air, or digestive issues (e.g., Irritable Bowel Syndrome - IBS). Constipation: Accumulation of stool in the colon. Overeating. Food Intolerances: Lactose intolerance, gluten sensitivity. Hormonal Fluctuations: Especially in women (premenstrual bloating). More Significant Causes: Ascites: Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity (space between abdominal organs). Most commonly caused by liver cirrhosis (impaired fluid regulation) or heart failure. Can also be due to certain cancers or kidney disease. Bowel Obstruction: Blockage in the intestines prevents passage of food/stool and causes gas/fluid buildup. A medical emergency. Organomegaly: Enlargement of an abdominal organ (e.g., enlarged liver (hepatomegaly), enlarged spleen (splenomegaly) from various diseases). Abdominal Mass/Tumor: Benign or malignant growth (e.g., ovarian cyst/tumor, uterine fibroids, abdominal cancer). Cyst: Ovarian cyst, pancreatic cyst. Pregnancy. Peritonitis: Inflammation of the peritoneum (lining of the abdomen), often from infection, causing severe pain and distension. I will continue with the final batch of symptoms. column2: headache,chest pain,dizziness,loss of balance,lack of concentration
column11: A general term for an enlargement or puffiness in any part of the body, caused by a buildup of fluid. The affected area might look bloated, feel tight, or even leave a dent when pressed (pitting).
column12: Medically, edema is the accumulation of excessive fluid in the interstitial spaces (the spaces between cells) of tissues. It can be localized (affecting one specific area) or generalized (affecting the entire body, also known as anasarca). The presence of pitting (a dent left after pressure) versus non-pitting edema can offer clues to the cause. Localized Swelling Causes: Injury/Trauma: Sprains, fractures, contusions. Infection: Cellulitis (bacterial skin infection), abscess. Inflammation: Localized allergic reactions, insect bites, arthritis (swelling in the joint). Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): A blood clot in a deep vein, typically in one leg, causing sudden, painful swelling. This is a medical emergency. Lymphedema: Impairment of the lymphatic system, leading to fluid retention, often in an arm or leg, after surgery (e.g., lymph node removal for cancer) or infection. Generalized Swelling (Bilateral, often in dependent areas like legs/ankles, or face/abdomen): Heart Failure (Congestive Heart Failure): The heart's inability to pump blood efficiently leads to fluid backup, causing swelling in legs, feet, and sometimes the abdomen (ascites) or lungs (pulmonary edema). Kidney Disease/Failure: Impaired kidney function means the body can't effectively remove excess fluid and sodium, leading to fluid retention, often around the eyes (periorbital edema) and in legs. Liver Disease (Cirrhosis): Severe liver damage reduces the production of albumin (a protein that helps keep fluid in blood vessels) and can lead to portal hypertension, resulting in widespread swelling, especially ascites. Thyroid Disease (Hypothyroidism): Can cause non-pitting edema (myxedema). Malnutrition/Severe Protein Deficiency: Low albumin levels. Medications: Many drugs, including some blood pressure medications (calcium channel blockers), NSAIDs, corticosteroids, and certain diabetes medications, can cause fluid retention. Pregnancy: Common due to increased blood volume and pressure on veins. Prolonged Standing/Sitting: Gravity-dependent pooling.

column2: chest pain,dizziness,loss of balance,lack of concentration
column11: When your abdomen looks or feels larger and fuller than normal, often making your clothes feel tight. It can be due to gas, fluid, or something else.
column12: Medically, abdominal distension or a "swollen belly" can be caused by the accumulation of gas, fluid, or the presence of an abnormal mass or enlarged organ. It can be acute (sudden) or chronic. Common (Often Benign) Causes: Gas and Bloating: Excess intestinal gas from food choices (e.g., high-fiber foods, carbonated drinks), air swallowing, or digestive issues like Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS). Constipation: Build-up of stool in the colon. Overeating. Food Intolerances: Lactose intolerance, celiac disease. Hormonal Changes: Common during menstruation or pregnancy. More Significant Causes: Ascites: Accumulation of fluid within the peritoneal cavity. This is a serious sign, most often linked to liver cirrhosis, but also can be caused by heart failure, kidney failure, or certain cancers. Bowel Obstruction: A blockage in the intestines preventing the passage of gas or stool, leading to significant distension, pain, nausea, and vomiting. This is a medical emergency. Organomegaly: Enlargement of organs like the liver (hepatomegaly) or spleen (splenomegaly) due to various diseases. Abdominal Mass/Tumor: Any growth, benign or malignant (e.g., large ovarian cyst, uterine fibroids, abdominal cancer). Pregnancy: Physiological cause. Peritonitis: Inflammation of the abdominal lining, often from infection, causing severe pain and distension.

column2: headache,dizziness,loss of balance,lack of concentration
column11: Joints that appear larger than normal, often feeling stiff, warm, or painful. This happens when fluid builds up inside or around the joint.
column12: Medically, joint swelling (effusion if fluid is within the joint capsule, or periarticular edema if around the joint) is a key sign of joint inflammation or injury. It can affect a single joint (monoarticular) or multiple joints (polyarticular). Common Causes: Arthritis (Inflammatory Conditions): Osteoarthritis: Degenerative joint disease, can cause mild swelling, stiffness, and pain, often worse with activity. Rheumatoid Arthritis: An autoimmune disease causing chronic inflammation, often affecting small joints symmetrically (hands, wrists, feet), leading to painful swelling, stiffness (especially morning stiffness), and deformity. Gout: A type of inflammatory arthritis caused by uric acid crystal deposition, leading to sudden, severe, painful swelling (often in the big toe, but can affect other joints). Psoriatic Arthritis: Associated with psoriasis, causes joint inflammation and swelling. Reactive Arthritis. Injury/Trauma: Sprains, strains, fractures, tears to ligaments/meniscus (e.g., knee injury). Often causes acute, localized swelling. Infection (Septic Arthritis): Bacterial infection of a joint, causing acute, severe pain, swelling, warmth, redness, and often fever. This is a medical emergency. Bursitis/Tendinitis: Inflammation of fluid-filled sacs (bursae) or tendons near the joint, leading to swelling and pain. Lyme Disease: Can cause migratory joint pain and swelling. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE): Autoimmune disease causing joint pain and swelling. Overuse or Repetitive Strain.

column2: headache,chest pain,loss of balance,lack of concentration
column11: When the glands (most commonly referring to lymph nodes) feel sore or painful to the touch. This usually indicates they are also swollen.
column12: Medically, "tender glands" almost always refers to tender lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy). Lymph nodes are small, bean-shaped organs that are part of the immune system, filtering lymph fluid and housing immune cells. When they are tender, it's typically a sign of inflammation or infection. Common Causes: Infections (Most Common): When your body fights an infection, lymph nodes swell and become tender as immune cells proliferate within them. Viral Infections: Common cold, flu, mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr virus), HIV, measles, rubella. Often causes widespread lymph node tenderness. Bacterial Infections: Strep throat, ear infections, skin infections (e.g., cellulitis, impetigo), infected tooth, tuberculosis. Tenderness is often localized to the nodes draining the infected area (e.g., neck nodes with a sore throat). Inflammatory Conditions: Autoimmune diseases like lupus or rheumatoid arthritis can cause lymph node enlargement and tenderness. Allergic Reactions. Less Common (but serious) Causes: Cancers: Lymphoma (cancer of the lymphatic system), leukemia, or metastatic cancer (cancer that has spread from another part of the body to the lymph nodes). These nodes are often hard, non-tender, and fixed, but can occasionally be tender, especially if growing rapidly or infected. The location of the tender nodes often helps narrow down the cause (e.g., neck nodes for head/neck infections, axillary nodes for arm/breast issues, inguinal nodes for leg/genital issues).

column2: headache,chest pain,dizziness,lack of concentration
column11: A prickling, "pins and needles" feeling on the skin, often accompanied by numbness or a burning sensation.
column12: Medically, a tingling sensation is called paresthesia. It's an abnormal sensation, typically caused by temporary or persistent irritation or damage to nerves. Transient (Temporary) Causes (Very Common and Harmless): Compression of a Nerve: Sitting in an awkward position, falling asleep on an arm, causing a limb to "fall asleep." The tingling occurs as blood flow and nerve function return. Direct Trauma to a Nerve: Hitting your "funny bone" (ulnar nerve). Hyperventilation: Rapid breathing leading to changes in blood gas levels. Persistent (Chronic) Causes (More Serious): Peripheral Neuropathy: Damage to the peripheral nerves (nerves outside the brain and spinal cord). This is a very common cause and can be due to: Diabetes: Diabetic neuropathy is a leading cause. Vitamin Deficiencies: Especially B vitamins (B1, B6, B12). Autoimmune Diseases: Lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, Guillain-Barr?? syndrome. Alcoholism. Toxins/Heavy Metals. Medications: Certain chemotherapy drugs, some antibiotics. Kidney or Liver Disease. Nerve Compression Syndromes: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Compression of the median nerve in the wrist. Sciatica: Compression of the sciatic nerve in the lower back (tingling down the leg). Cervical Radiculopathy: "Pinched nerve" in the neck causing arm/hand tingling. Stroke or TIA: Sudden onset tingling, especially on one side of the body, can be a neurological emergency. Multiple Sclerosis (MS): Demyelination of nerves in the brain and spinal cord. Migraine with Aura. Electrolyte Imbalances.

column2: headache,chest pain,dizziness,loss of balance
column11: Making deep, involuntary sounds of pain, discomfort, or exertion, which are not typical for the person.
column12: Medically, "unusual groaning" can fall under the umbrella of abnormal vocalizations or a symptom of distress. The context is critical. Involuntary Vocalizations: Pain: People in severe acute or chronic pain may groan involuntarily, especially with movement. Respiratory Distress: Groaning can be a sign of increased work of breathing, especially in infants with respiratory distress (grunting due to closing of vocal cords to increase pressure in lungs). Delirium or Confusion: Patients who are confused, agitated, or delirious may make unusual vocalizations including groaning. Neurological Conditions: Some neurological conditions (e.g., certain types of seizures, stroke affecting vocalization centers, advanced dementia) can lead to involuntary vocalizations, including groaning. Sleep Disorders: Groaning during sleep (catathrenia) is a rare parasomnia. Psychiatric Conditions: In extreme distress or certain psychiatric states. It's a non-specific sign of significant discomfort or an underlying physiological or neurological issue, warranting investigation, especially if new or persistent.

column2: headache,chest pain,dizziness,loss of balance,lack of concentration
column11: Any body movements that are involuntary, repetitive, or appear strange and out of character for the person. This can include jerks, tremors, twists, or fidgeting.
column12: Medically, "unusual movements" often refer to movement disorders, which are neurological conditions causing abnormal voluntary or involuntary movements. These disorders are often due to dysfunction in the basal ganglia, cerebellum, or other brain regions involved in motor control. Common Types of Movement Disorders: Tremor: Rhythmic, involuntary, oscillating movement of a body part (e.g., essential tremor, Parkinsonian tremor). Chorea: Brief, irregular, abrupt, involuntary movements that flow from one body part to another (e.g., Huntington's disease). Dystonia: Sustained or repetitive muscle contractions causing twisting, abnormal postures, or repetitive movements (e.g., cervical dystonia affecting the neck). Myoclonus: Sudden, brief, shock-like jerks (e.g., hiccups, sleep jerks, or indicative of epilepsy or metabolic disorders). Tics: Sudden, repetitive, non-rhythmic movements (motor tics) or sounds (vocal tics) (e.g., Tourette syndrome). Ataxia: Lack of coordination, causing clumsy, unsteady movements and gait (e.g., cerebellar damage, alcohol intoxication). Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS): Unpleasant sensations in the legs leading to an irresistible urge to move them, especially at rest. Causes: Neurological Conditions: Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease, Multiple Sclerosis, Stroke, Brain Tumors, Encephalitis. Medications: Many drugs, particularly antipsychotics (can cause tardive dyskinesia), anti-epileptics, and some antidepressants, can induce movement disorders. Drug/Alcohol Withdrawal or Intoxication. Metabolic Disorders: Liver failure, kidney failure. Infections: Post-streptococcal chorea. Genetic Factors. Functional Movement Disorders: Movements that appear neurological but are not caused by underlying neurological disease.

column2: chest pain,dizziness,loss of balance,lack of concentration
column11: The forceful expulsion of stomach contents through the mouth. It's often preceded by nausea.
column12: Medically, emesis (or vomiting) is the forceful expulsion of gastric contents. It's a complex reflex coordinated by the "vomiting center" in the brainstem, in response to various stimuli. It's distinct from regurgitation (non-forceful expulsion) and belching. Common Causes: Gastroenteritis ("Stomach Flu"): Viral or bacterial infection of the GI tract. Food Poisoning: Ingestion of toxins or bacteria. Migraine Headaches. Motion Sickness/Vertigo: Inner ear disturbance. Pregnancy (Morning Sickness). Medications: Side effect of many drugs (e.g., chemotherapy, opioids, antibiotics, general anesthesia). Excessive Alcohol Consumption. Overeating. More Serious Causes: Gastrointestinal Issues: Appendicitis: Especially in early stages. Gallstones/Cholecystitis: Inflammation of the gallbladder. Pancreatitis: Inflammation of the pancreas. Peptic Ulcer Disease. Bowel Obstruction: Can cause projectile vomiting, sometimes feculent. Medical emergency. Gastroparesis: Delayed stomach emptying (e.g., in diabetics). Neurological Conditions: Increased intracranial pressure (brain tumors, hemorrhage, hydrocephalus) can cause projectile vomiting without nausea. Meningitis, concussion. Metabolic Disorders: Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA), kidney failure. Systemic Infections: Sepsis. Heart Attack: Can present with nausea and vomiting, especially in women. Drug Overdose. Persistent vomiting can lead to dehydration, electrolyte imbalances (hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis), and Mallory-Weiss tears (esophageal tears from forceful vomiting).

column2: headache,dizziness,loss of balance,lack of concentration
column11: When your eyes produce an excessive amount of tears, causing them to water or tear up.
column12: Medically, excessive tearing is called epiphora. It can be due to either overproduction of tears or, more commonly, impaired drainage of tears through the lacrimal (tear) drainage system. Overproduction of Tears (Reflex Tearing): Irritation/Foreign Body: Dust, smoke, chemicals, eyelashes, foreign object in the eye. Allergies (Allergic Conjunctivitis): Pollen, pet dander, causing itchy, red, watery eyes. Dry Eyes: Paradoxically, very dry eyes can trigger a reflex overproduction of poor-quality tears to compensate. Conjunctivitis ("Pink Eye"): Inflammation of the conjunctiva, often viral. Corneal Abrasion/Ulcer: Scratch or infection on the cornea. Inflammation: Blepharitis (eyelid inflammation), uveitis. Environmental Factors: Wind, bright light, cold. Impaired Drainage of Tears (Obstruction): Blocked Tear Ducts (Nasolacrimal Duct Obstruction): Common in infants (congenital) and adults (due to infection, inflammation, trauma, or age-related narrowing). Eyelid Malpositions: Ectropion: Eyelid turns outward, preventing tears from draining into the puncta (tear drainage holes). Entropion: Eyelid turns inward, causing eyelashes to rub the eye and irritate it, and mispositioning the puncta. Punctal Stenosis: Narrowing of the tear drainage holes. Trauma to the tear drainage system. Tumors pressing on tear ducts.

column2: headache,chest pain,loss of balance,lack of concentration
column11: A feeling of reduced strength or energy, making it hard to perform daily activities. It can be generalized (affecting the whole body) or localized to a specific muscle group or limb.
column12: Medically, weakness refers to a demonstrable decrease in muscle strength. It is distinct from fatigue (tiredness) or malaise (general discomfort), though they often co-occur. It can be focal (e.g., weakness in one arm) or generalized. Neurological Causes (Damage to nerves or brain pathways): Stroke/TIA: Sudden, unilateral weakness (hemiparesis). Medical emergency. Spinal Cord Injury/Compression: Weakness below the level of injury. Peripheral Neuropathy: Damage to peripheral nerves (e.g., diabetic neuropathy, Guillain-Barr?? syndrome), causing distal weakness (hands/feet). Nerve Compression: "Pinched nerve" (radiculopathy) from a herniated disc, causing weakness in a specific muscle distribution. Neurodegenerative Diseases: ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis), Multiple Sclerosis, Myasthenia Gravis (weakness worse with activity, improves with rest), Parkinson's disease. Brain Tumors. Muscular Causes (Muscle diseases): Myopathies: Inherited (e.g., muscular dystrophies) or acquired (e.g., inflammatory myopathies like polymyositis, dermatomyositis, or drug-induced myopathy). Often causes proximal weakness (difficulty raising arms, standing from a chair). Electrolyte Imbalances: Especially low potassium (hypokalemia) or high calcium (hypercalcemia). Systemic Causes: Severe Infections: Sepsis, flu. Endocrine Disorders: Hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, Addison's disease. Anemia: Reduced oxygen delivery to muscles. Chronic Diseases: Heart failure, kidney failure, liver disease, cancer. Nutritional Deficiencies. Medication Side Effects: Statins, corticosteroids. Severe Fatigue/Sleep Deprivation.

column11: An increase in your body weight, which can be due to an increase in fat, muscle, or fluid.
column12: Medically, weight gain is an increase in total body mass. While often due to a caloric surplus (eating more calories than expended), it can also be a symptom of underlying medical conditions, especially if unexplained or rapid. Common Causes (Lifestyle/Physiological): Increased Caloric Intake / Reduced Physical Activity: The most common cause. Aging: Metabolism slows, muscle mass decreases, fat mass increases. Hormonal Fluctuations: Pregnancy, menopause, menstruation (water retention). Stress: Can lead to increased cortisol (promotes fat storage) and comfort eating. Lack of Sleep: Affects appetite-regulating hormones (ghrelin, leptin). Quitting Smoking: Nicotine boosts metabolism. Medical Causes (Unexplained Weight Gain): Fluid Retention (Edema/Ascites): As discussed under "Swelling" and "Swollen belly." Can indicate heart failure, kidney disease, or liver cirrhosis. Rapid weight gain (e.g., 2-3 lbs/day or 5 lbs/week) should be evaluated. Endocrine Disorders: Hypothyroidism (Underactive Thyroid): Slowed metabolism, fatigue, and weight gain. Cushing's Syndrome: Excess cortisol, leading to central obesity ("moon face," "buffalo hump," abdominal fat) and thin limbs. Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): Hormonal imbalance in women, often with insulin resistance, leading to weight gain. Medications: Many classes of drugs can cause weight gain: Antidepressants (SSRIs, TCAs). Antipsychotics. Corticosteroids (prednisone). Some diabetes medications (insulin, sulfonylureas, thiazolidinediones). Beta-blockers. Certain contraceptives. Depression. Tumors: Large benign or malignant masses.

column11: A noticeable decrease in your body weight, either intentionally (through diet/exercise) or unintentionally. When it's unintentional, it's often a cause for concern.
column12: Medically, weight loss refers to a reduction in total body mass, whether from fat, muscle, or fluid. Unintentional weight loss (also known as involuntary or unexplained weight loss) is particularly significant, generally defined as losing more than 5% of body weight over 6-12 months, or a more rapid, significant loss. This often signals an underlying medical condition. Common Causes (Intentional/Lifestyle): Diet and Exercise: Deliberate efforts to reduce weight. Increased Physical Activity. Medical Causes (Unintentional Weight Loss): Cancers (Malignancies): A classic "B symptom" (fever, night sweats, weight loss) in lymphomas, and common in many solid tumors (e.g., lung, colon, pancreatic, stomach cancer). Cancer cells have high metabolic demands and release factors that cause cachexia (wasting). Gastrointestinal Disorders: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD): Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis (malabsorption, inflammation). Celiac Disease: Malabsorption due to gluten sensitivity. Peptic Ulcer Disease (Severe). Pancreatitis. Chronic Diarrhea/Malabsorption Syndromes. Endocrine Disorders: Hyperthyroidism (Overactive Thyroid): Increased metabolism, leading to weight loss despite increased appetite. Diabetes Mellitus (Type 1 or uncontrolled Type 2): Inability to utilize glucose, leading to breakdown of fat and muscle. Addison's Disease. Chronic Infections: HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis (TB), chronic fungal infections. Chronic Organ Failure: Heart failure, kidney failure, COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease). Neurological Disorders: Advanced dementia (difficulty eating), Parkinson's disease (dysphagia, increased energy expenditure from tremors). Psychiatric Conditions: Severe depression, anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa. Medications: Some medications can cause appetite suppression or malabsorption. Substance Abuse: Alcoholism, illicit drug use. Unexplained weight loss warrants thorough medical investigation. This completes the list of symptoms you provided. column11: Anxiety is a feeling of worry, nervousness, or unease, often about something with an uncertain outcome. It's a normal human emotion, but when it's persistent or overwhelming, it can be distressing.
column12: Medically, anxiety is a complex response involving the central nervous system and various neurochemical pathways. It's characterized by physiological arousal (e.g., increased heart rate, rapid breathing, muscle tension) and psychological distress (e.g., excessive worry, apprehension). Pathological anxiety, distinct from normal apprehension, can be a core feature of anxiety disorders (e.g., Generalized Anxiety Disorder, Panic Disorder, Social Anxiety Disorder) or a symptom of underlying medical conditions (e.g., hyperthyroidism, arrhythmias, drug withdrawal). Neurotransmitter imbalances, particularly involving serotonin, norepinephrine, and GABA, are often implicated.

column11: Shortness of breath, also called breathlessness or dyspnea, is the uncomfortable feeling of not being able to get enough air. It can feel like a tightness in your chest or that you're gasping for air.
column12: Dyspnea is a subjective sensation of difficulty breathing. Physiologically, it can result from increased respiratory drive (e.g., hypoxia, hypercapnia, acidosis), increased work of breathing (e.g., airway obstruction, reduced lung compliance from restrictive lung disease, or increased pulmonary venous pressure from heart failure), or respiratory muscle weakness. Common medical causes include respiratory conditions (e.g., asthma, COPD, pneumonia, pulmonary embolism), cardiac conditions (e.g., heart failure, myocardial infarction), anemia, anxiety, or metabolic disorders.

column10: Depressive (assuming this refers to a general feeling of depression or low mood)
column11: Feeling depressive means experiencing a persistent low mood, sadness, loss of interest or pleasure in activities, and often a lack of energy. It's more than just temporary sadness and can interfere with daily life.
column12: A depressive state, when meeting diagnostic criteria for duration and severity, is indicative of a mood disorder such as Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia), or part of Bipolar Disorder. From a medical perspective, it involves neurobiological changes, including dysregulation of neurotransmitters (serotonin, norepinephrine, dopamine), altered brain structure and function in areas controlling mood, cognition, and motivation (e.g., prefrontal cortex, hippocampus, amygdala), and hormonal imbalances (e.g., HPA axis dysfunction). Genetic predisposition, psychological factors, and environmental stressors also play significant roles.

column11: Dizziness is a broad term describing various sensations, such as feeling lightheaded, woozy, unsteady, or a sensation of spinning (vertigo). It can make you feel off-balance or like you might faint.
column12: Dizziness is a common complaint with diverse etiologies. It can be classified into: Vertigo: An illusion of motion, usually spinning, caused by asymmetric input from the vestibular system (inner ear or central nervous system pathways). Examples include Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV), Meniere's disease, labyrinthitis, or stroke affecting the brainstem/cerebellum. Presyncope: Feeling lightheaded or faint without losing consciousness, due to transient global cerebral hypoperfusion (e.g., orthostatic hypotension, arrhythmias, vasovagal syncope). Disequilibrium: A sense of unsteadiness or imbalance while walking, often without a head sensation, due to impaired proprioception, visual input, cerebellar dysfunction, or musculoskeletal issues. Non-specific Dizziness: Vague lightheadedness not fitting other categories, often associated with anxiety, hyperventilation, or medication side effects.

column11: "Abnormal" means something is not typical, usual, or healthy. If you feel an "abnormal sensation," it's something your body usually doesn't do, like tingling or numbness where it shouldn't be. If it's an "abnormal finding," it means something a doctor sees or a test shows that isn't normal.
column12: In a medical context, "abnormal" denotes a deviation from expected physiological parameters, anatomical norms, or typical sensory experiences. Abnormal Sensations (Paresthesia/Dysesthesia): Paresthesia refers to abnormal, non-painful sensations like tingling, pricking, or numbness, often due to nerve irritation or damage (e.g., peripheral neuropathy from diabetes, vitamin deficiency, nerve compression like carpal tunnel syndrome). Dysesthesia refers to unpleasant, abnormal sensations. Abnormal Findings: This can refer to anything discovered during a physical exam (e.g., an abnormal heart murmur, enlarged organ, unusual skin lesion), or an abnormal result from a diagnostic test (e.g., abnormal blood count, elevated liver enzymes, a mass on imaging). The medical explanation is highly dependent on the specific type and location of the abnormality.
