column2: chills,vomiting,fatigue,high fever,headache,constipation,abdominal pain,diarrhoea,toxic look (typhos),belly pain
column11: A sudden, intense, piercing, or stabbing discomfort in your chest area. It can be brief or prolonged and might worsen with breathing or movement.
column12: Sharp chest pain is a symptom that always warrants careful evaluation due to the potential for serious underlying causes, though many causes are benign. Cardiac (Heart-related): Myocardial Infarction (Heart Attack): While often described as crushing or pressure, sharp pain can occur. Usually accompanied by shortness of breath, sweating, radiation to arm/jaw. Pericarditis: Inflammation of the sac around the heart, causing sharp, pleuritic pain (worsens with deep breath/lying flat, improves sitting up/leaning forward). Angina: Less typical for sharp pain, but severe spasm can feel sharp. Pulmonary (Lung-related): Pleurisy/Pleuritis: Inflammation of the lung lining, causing sharp, stabbing pain that worsens with deep breaths or cough. Pneumonia: Lung infection, often with sharp pain, cough, fever, shortness of breath. Pneumothorax: Collapsed lung, causing sudden sharp pain, often with shortness of breath. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): Blood clot in the lung, causing sudden sharp pain, shortness of breath, fast heart rate. A medical emergency. Gastrointestinal: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)/Esophageal Spasm: Can mimic cardiac pain, often a burning or squeezing, but can be sharp. Peptic Ulcer Disease: Can cause sharp epigastric pain that sometimes radiates to the chest. Musculoskeletal: Costochondritis/Tietze's Syndrome: Inflammation of the cartilage connecting ribs to the breastbone. Pain is sharp, localized, tender to touch, often worsens with movement or deep breath. Muscle Strain: In the chest wall. Rib Fracture. Other: Herpes Zoster (shingles) before rash appears, anxiety/panic attacks. Distinguishing life-threatening causes is paramount.

column2: chills,vomiting,fatigue,high fever,headache,nausea,abdominal pain,diarrhoea,toxic look (typhos),belly pain
column11: Any discomfort or aching sensation felt on one side of your body, usually referring to the flank (area between ribs and hip) or side of the abdomen.
column12: Side pain (flank pain or unilateral abdominal/thoracic pain) has a wide differential diagnosis depending on the exact location and character. Renal/Urinary: Kidney Stones (Renal Colic): Often severe, sharp, cramping pain in the flank that radiates to the groin, often with nausea/vomiting, blood in urine. Pyelonephritis: Kidney infection, usually with flank pain, fever, chills, dysuria. Gastrointestinal: Diverticulitis: Typically left lower quadrant pain, but can be higher on the side. Appendicitis: Can sometimes present with right flank pain if the appendix is retrocecal. Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS): Can cause cramping pain anywhere in the abdomen/flank. Musculoskeletal: Muscle Strain: In the abdominal or back muscles. Rib Fracture/Costochondritis: Can cause localized sharp pain in the side of the chest. Neurological: Herpes Zoster (shingles) can cause sharp, burning pain in a dermatomal pattern on the side. Nerve impingement from the spine. Other: Pleurisy (inflammation of lung lining on one side), pneumonia. Location, quality of pain, and associated symptoms are key to diagnosis.

column2: chills,vomiting,fatigue,high fever,headache,nausea,constipation,diarrhoea,toxic look (typhos),belly pain
column11: Seeing red blood in your bowel movements, either on the toilet paper, in the toilet bowl, or mixed with the stool. It can also appear dark, tarry, and black.
column12: Blood in stool indicates bleeding somewhere in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. The appearance of the blood often suggests the source. Bright Red Blood (Hematochezia): Usually indicates bleeding from the lower GI tract (colon, rectum, anus). Hemorrhoids: Most common cause, swollen veins in the anus/rectum, typically bright red blood on toilet paper or dripping. Anal Fissures: Small tears in the lining of the anus, causing sharp pain and bright red blood. Diverticulosis/Diverticulitis: Bleeding from diverticula (small pouches in the colon). Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD): Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease. Infections: Bacterial colitis. Polyps/Cancer: Colorectal polyps or colorectal cancer. Dark, Tarry Stool (Melena): Indicates bleeding from the upper GI tract (esophagus, stomach, small intestine) that has been digested. Peptic Ulcer Disease: Ulcers in the stomach or duodenum. Esophageal Varices: Enlarged veins in the esophagus (due to liver disease). Gastritis: Inflammation of the stomach lining. Mallory-Weiss Tear: Tear in the esophageal lining (often from forceful vomiting). All blood in stool should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.

column2: chills,vomiting,fatigue,high fever,headache,nausea,constipation,abdominal pain,toxic look (typhos),belly pain
column11: Food or liquid coming back up into your mouth or throat without effort, usually without the forceful contractions of vomiting. It might taste like the food you just ate.
column12: Regurgitation is the effortless return of stomach or esophageal contents into the pharynx or mouth, distinct from vomiting (which is forceful). Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD): The most common cause, where stomach acid and contents flow back into the esophagus due to a weakened lower esophageal sphincter. Often accompanied by heartburn. Esophageal Motility Disorders: Achalasia: Impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter and lack of peristalsis in the esophagus, leading to food retention and regurgitation. Diffuse Esophageal Spasm. Structural Abnormalities: Zenker's Diverticulum: A pouch in the upper esophagus where food can collect and then be regurgitated, often undigested and hours after eating. Esophageal Strictures: Narrowing of the esophagus. Hiatal Hernia: Part of the stomach pushes up through the diaphragm. Rumination Syndrome: A behavioral disorder where recently ingested food is regurgitated, re-chewed, and then re-swallowed or spit out. Differentiation from vomiting is important for diagnosis.

column2: chills,vomiting,fatigue,high fever,headache,nausea,constipation,abdominal pain,diarrhoea,belly pain
column11: Throwing up blood. The vomit might look bright red (fresh blood) or like coffee grounds (older, partially digested blood).
column12: Vomiting blood (hematemesis) is a serious medical emergency indicating bleeding in the upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract (esophagus, stomach, duodenum). Bright Red Blood: Usually indicates rapid, active bleeding. Esophageal Varices: Ruptured enlarged veins in the esophagus, often due to severe liver disease (e.g., cirrhosis). This is a life-threatening cause. Mallory-Weiss Tear: A tear in the lining of the esophagus at the junction with the stomach, often caused by forceful vomiting or retching. Peptic Ulcer Disease: Bleeding from an ulcer in the stomach or duodenum. "Coffee Ground" Emesis: Indicates slower bleeding or blood that has been in contact with stomach acid for some time. Bleeding Peptic Ulcer. Gastritis: Severe inflammation of the stomach lining. Esophagitis: Severe inflammation of the esophagus. Other: Gastric cancer, vascular malformations. Hematemesis always requires immediate medical attention to identify the source of bleeding and stabilize the patient.

column2: chills,vomiting,fatigue,high fever,headache,nausea,constipation,abdominal pain,diarrhoea,toxic look (typhos)
column11: Swelling, usually in your legs, ankles, or feet, caused by fluid buildup in the body's tissues. The swollen area might look puffy or feel heavy.
column12: Peripheral edema is the accumulation of excess fluid (interstitial fluid) in the extracellular space, most commonly affecting the dependent parts of the body (legs, ankles, feet) due to gravity. Cardiac Causes: Congestive Heart Failure (CHF): The heart's inability to pump blood effectively leads to fluid backup in the venous system, causing bilateral, pitting (leaves an indentation when pressed) edema. Right-sided Heart Failure: Specifically causes peripheral edema. Renal Causes: Kidney Disease/Failure: Impaired kidney function leads to fluid and sodium retention. Edema can be generalized, including peri-orbital (around eyes). Nephrotic Syndrome: Kidney disorder causing significant protein loss in urine, leading to low blood albumin and generalized edema. Hepatic Causes: Liver Cirrhosis: Impaired liver function leads to reduced albumin production (which helps keep fluid in vessels) and increased portal hypertension, causing ascites (abdominal fluid) and peripheral edema. Vascular Causes: Chronic Venous Insufficiency: Damaged leg veins allow blood to pool, leading to chronic, often unilateral, leg swelling. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): Blood clot in a deep leg vein, causing acute, often unilateral, painful swelling. Medical emergency. Lymphatic Causes (Lymphedema): Impaired lymphatic drainage due to surgery (e.g., lymph node dissection), infection, or congenital conditions, leading to chronic, non-pitting swelling. Medications: Calcium channel blockers, NSAIDs, corticosteroids, estrogens. Other: Standing for long periods, obesity, severe malnutrition.

column2: chills,vomiting,fatigue,high fever,headache,nausea,constipation,abdominal pain,diarrhoea,toxic look (typhos),belly pain
column11: A baby who is unusually fussy, crying a lot, difficult to calm down, and seems generally uncomfortable or unhappy for prolonged periods without an obvious reason.
column12: Irritability in an infant is a non-specific but important symptom, as it can indicate discomfort, pain, hunger, or underlying illness. Common/Benign Causes: Colic: Unexplained, prolonged crying in an otherwise healthy infant, typically in the first few months of life. Hunger/Thirst: Fatigue/Overtiredness: Discomfort: Wet diaper, too hot/cold, tight clothing. Gas/Constipation. Reflux (GERD): Acid reflux can cause discomfort, especially when lying flat. Infections: Ear Infection (Otitis Media): Pain when lying down or sucking. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI). Viral Infections: Common cold, flu, RSV. Meningitis/Sepsis: Serious infections can cause extreme irritability, lethargy, fever, poor feeding. Other Medical Conditions: Food Allergies/Intolerances: E.g., cow's milk protein allergy. Hernias: Inguinal hernia (can become incarcerated and painful). Intussusception: Bowel telescoping into itself, causing sudden, severe, intermittent pain and crying, often with "currant jelly" stools. Medical emergency. Teething. Trauma: Accidental or non-accidental injury. Persistent or severe irritability, especially with fever, poor feeding, lethargy, or vomiting, warrants prompt medical evaluation.

column2: chills,vomiting,fatigue,high fever,headache,nausea,constipation,abdominal pain,diarrhoea,toxic look (typhos),belly pain
column11: Your eyelid moves or twitches in a way you can't control, or it might droop, get stuck, or close improperly.
column12: Abnormal eyelid movement can involve the position, blinking, or involuntary movements of the eyelid. Ptosis (Eyelid Drooping): Neurological: Damage to cranial nerve III (oculomotor nerve) or sympathetic nerves (Horner's syndrome), or neuromuscular disorders like Myasthenia Gravis. Muscular: Age-related stretching of the levator palpebrae muscle, or muscular dystrophies. Eyelid Spasms/Twitching (Myokymia): Minor, localized, involuntary contractions of the orbicularis oculi muscle. Usually benign, often triggered by stress, fatigue, caffeine, or eye irritation. Blepharospasm: Involuntary, forceful contractions of the orbicularis oculi muscle, causing persistent eye closure. Can be a focal dystonia, often debilitating. Hemifacial Spasm: Involuntary twitching of muscles on one side of the face, including the eyelid, often caused by blood vessel compression of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). Ectropion/Entropion: Eyelid turning outward (ectropion) or inward (entropion), affecting blinking and causing irritation. Thyroid Eye Disease: Can cause eyelid retraction (lid pulled up), leading to a "staring" appearance. Underlying neurological conditions need to be ruled out, especially for new-onset ptosis or severe/persistent spasms.

column2: chills,fatigue,high fever,headache,nausea,constipation,abdominal pain,diarrhoea,toxic look (typhos),belly pain
column11: You feel like you need to pee but you can't empty your bladder completely, or you can't pee at all. This can be very uncomfortable and painful.
column12: Urinary retention is the inability to completely empty the bladder. It can be acute (sudden, painful inability to urinate) or chronic (long-term incomplete emptying). Obstructive Causes: Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) in males: Enlarged prostate gland pressing on the urethra. Most common cause in older men. Urethral Stricture: Narrowing of the urethra from scarring. Bladder Stones/Tumors: Can obstruct the bladder outlet. Fecal Impaction: Severe constipation can press on the urethra. Pelvic Organ Prolapse in females: Cystocele (bladder prolapse) can kink the urethra. Neurological Causes: Disruption of nerve signals between the brain and bladder. Spinal Cord Injury. Stroke. Multiple Sclerosis. Parkinson's Disease. Diabetic Neuropathy. Medications: Many drugs can cause urinary retention (e.g., anticholinergics, antihistamines, decongestants, opioids, some antidepressants). Infection/Inflammation: Severe UTIs, prostatitis, periurethral abscess. Acute urinary retention is a medical emergency requiring prompt catheterization.

column11: Any vaginal bleeding that happens between your regular menstrual periods. It's also called spotting or breakthrough bleeding.
column12: Intermenstrual bleeding (IMB) or abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) refers to any bleeding that occurs outside of the normal menstrual cycle. It's a common gynecological complaint with various causes. Hormonal Imbalances: Common with hormonal contraception (e.g., breakthrough bleeding on birth control pills, especially when starting or changing types), perimenopause, or anovulation (lack of ovulation). Ovulation Bleeding: Some women experience light spotting around the time of ovulation due to a transient drop in estrogen. Infections: Cervicitis (inflammation of the cervix), endometritis (inflammation of the uterine lining), or sexually transmitted infections (STIs) like chlamydia or gonorrhea. Structural Lesions: Cervical Polyps: Benign growths on the cervix. Uterine Fibroids: Non-cancerous growths in the uterus. Endometrial Polyps: Growths in the uterine lining. Cervical Ectropion: Normal cells from inside the cervix are present on the outside. Early Pregnancy Complications: Implantation bleeding, threatened miscarriage, ectopic pregnancy. Trauma: Vaginal or cervical trauma. Malignancy (Less Common but Serious): Cervical cancer, endometrial cancer. Any new or persistent IMB, especially post-menopausal bleeding, warrants investigation to rule out malignancy. Evaluation often involves a pelvic exam, Pap test, STI screening, ultrasound, and sometimes biopsy. That completes all the symptoms from all the images you've provided! column2: joint pain,vomiting,yellowish skin,dark urine,nausea,loss of appetite,abdominal pain,diarrhoea,mild fever,yellowing of eyes,muscle pain
column11: Feeling like you can't get enough air, or that your breathing is labored and difficult. It might make you feel winded even with minimal activity.
column12: Shortness of breath, or dyspnea, is a subjective sensation of uncomfortable breathing. It's a common symptom of various cardiopulmonary, metabolic, and psychological conditions. Cardiopulmonary Causes: Respiratory: Asthma, COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease), pneumonia, bronchitis, pulmonary embolism (blood clot in lung), pneumothorax (collapsed lung), pleural effusion (fluid around lung), lung cancer. Cardiac: Congestive heart failure, myocardial infarction (heart attack), arrhythmias, valvular heart disease. Other Causes: Anemia: Reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of blood. Anxiety/Panic Attacks: Hyperventilation. Obesity: Increased respiratory effort. Deconditioning: Lack of physical fitness. Metabolic Acidosis: Kidney failure, diabetic ketoacidosis. The suddenness of onset, accompanying symptoms (chest pain, cough, fever), and associated medical history are crucial for diagnosis.

column2: vomiting,yellowish skin,dark urine,nausea,loss of appetite,abdominal pain,diarrhoea,mild fever,yellowing of eyes,muscle pain
column11: A range of emotional, mental, and physical changes that indicate a low mood or loss of pleasure. These are often signs that someone might be feeling down or struggling with depression, even if it's not a full clinical diagnosis.
column12: Depressive symptoms encompass a cluster of signs and symptoms that characterize a depressive episode. These include, but are not limited to, persistent sadness, loss of interest or pleasure (anhedonia), changes in appetite or sleep, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, difficulty concentrating, and recurrent thoughts of death or suicide. Causes: Imbalance in neurotransmitters (serotonin, norepinephrine, dopamine), genetic predisposition, chronic stress, trauma, hormonal changes (e.g., postpartum, thyroid disorders), certain medications, and chronic medical illnesses (e.g., cancer, heart disease). Conditions: When these symptoms are severe enough and persist for at least two weeks, they may meet criteria for Major Depressive Disorder. Depressive symptoms can also be part of other conditions like Bipolar Disorder, Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia), or Adjustment Disorder. Assessment involves clinical interview, symptom scales, and ruling out medical mimics. Treatment options include psychotherapy (CBT, IPT), pharmacotherapy (antidepressants), and lifestyle interventions.

column2: joint pain,yellowish skin,dark urine,nausea,loss of appetite,abdominal pain,diarrhoea,mild fever,yellowing of eyes,muscle pain
column11: A persistent feeling of sadness, hopelessness, and loss of interest in activities you once enjoyed, lasting for weeks or longer. It's more than just feeling "down" for a few days.
column12: Depression, clinically known as Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), is a serious mood disorder characterized by a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. It is a diagnosis made based on specific criteria from the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders). Key Diagnostic Criteria: Presence of at least five symptoms for a two-week period, including either depressed mood or anhedonia, and at least four additional symptoms (e.g., significant weight change, sleep disturbance, psychomotor agitation or retardation, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness/guilt, diminished concentration, recurrent thoughts of death/suicide). Pathophysiology: Involves complex interactions of genetic, biological (neurotransmitter dysregulation, structural brain changes, inflammation), psychological, and environmental factors. Differential Diagnosis: Must be distinguished from normal grief, other mood disorders, and medical conditions (e.g., hypothyroidism, anemia) or medication side effects that can mimic depressive symptoms. Treatment is multifaceted and may involve psychotherapy, antidepressant medications, brain stimulation therapies (for severe/resistant cases), and supportive care.

column2: joint pain,vomiting,dark urine,nausea,loss of appetite,abdominal pain,diarrhoea,mild fever,yellowing of eyes,muscle pain
column11: A feeling of lightheadedness, unsteadiness, giddiness, or a sensation of spinning (vertigo). It can make you feel off-balance and potentially lead to falls.
column12: Dizziness is a common, often vague, symptom that can describe several distinct sensations: Vertigo: The sensation of spinning or moving, or that the world around you is spinning. It typically indicates a problem with the vestibular system (inner ear or its central connections). Peripheral Vertigo: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV - short episodes triggered by head movements), Meniere's disease (recurrent episodes with hearing loss and tinnitus), Vestibular Neuritis/Labyrinthitis (acute, often severe, viral infection of inner ear nerve). Central Vertigo: Less common, due to brainstem or cerebellar lesions (e.g., stroke, MS), often with other neurological symptoms. Presyncope/Lightheadedness: Feeling faint or like you're about to pass out, often due to temporary reduction in blood flow to the brain. Causes include orthostatic hypotension (drop in BP on standing), arrhythmias, dehydration, or vasovagal syncope. Disequilibrium: Feeling unsteady or off-balance, often without a sensation of spinning or lightheadedness. Causes include peripheral neuropathy, cerebellar dysfunction, visual impairment, or musculoskeletal issues. Non-specific Dizziness: Vague sensation, often associated with anxiety, hyperventilation, or medication side effects. Accurate characterization of the sensation is crucial for diagnosis.

column2: joint pain,vomiting,yellowish skin,nausea,loss of appetite,abdominal pain,diarrhoea,mild fever,yellowing of eyes,muscle pain
column11: Any movement of your body that you cannot control or that appears unusual, unintentional, or out of place. It can range from subtle twitches to large, uncontrolled motions.
column12: Abnormal movements are involuntary movements that can arise from dysfunction in various parts of the brain, particularly the basal ganglia, cerebellum, or motor cortex, or from peripheral nerve/muscle disorders. These are often categorized as movement disorders. Types: Tremor: Rhythmic, oscillating movement (e.g., essential tremor, Parkinsonian tremor). Tics: Sudden, rapid, repetitive, non-rhythmic movements or vocalizations (e.g., Tourette's syndrome). Dystonia: Sustained or repetitive muscle contractions leading to twisting and repetitive movements or abnormal postures (e.g., cervical dystonia, blepharospasm). Chorea: Brief, irregular, abrupt, unpredictable, non-rhythmic movements (e.g., Huntington's disease). Athetosis: Slow, writhing, continuous movements. Myoclonus: Sudden, brief, shock-like jerks or twitches. Ataxia: Lack of muscle coordination causing clumsy, unsteady movements (cerebellar dysfunction). Causes: Neurodegenerative diseases (Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease), stroke, brain injury, certain medications (e.g., antipsychotics causing tardive dyskinesia), metabolic disorders, genetic conditions, and sometimes stress. Diagnosis involves detailed neurological examination and often imaging or specialized tests.

column2: joint pain,vomiting,yellowish skin,dark urine,loss of appetite,abdominal pain,diarrhoea,mild fever,yellowing of eyes,muscle pain
column11: Difficulty falling asleep, staying asleep, or waking up too early and being unable to get back to sleep, leading to not feeling refreshed.
column12: Insomnia is a sleep disorder characterized by difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep, or by non-restorative sleep, despite adequate opportunity for sleep, resulting in impaired daytime functioning. It can be acute (lasting days to weeks) or chronic (lasting 3 months or more). Acute Insomnia: Often triggered by stress, travel, illness, or temporary changes in sleep environment. Chronic Insomnia: Primary Insomnia: No identifiable underlying medical or psychiatric cause. Secondary Insomnia: More common, caused by: Medical Conditions: Chronic pain, heart failure, respiratory conditions (asthma, COPD, sleep apnea), restless legs syndrome, thyroid disorders. Psychiatric Conditions: Depression, anxiety disorders, bipolar disorder. Medications: Decongestants, stimulants, certain antidepressants, corticosteroids. Substance Use: Caffeine, alcohol (initially sedating, but causes sleep fragmentation), nicotine, illicit drugs. Poor Sleep Hygiene: Irregular sleep schedule, noisy environment, excessive screen time before bed. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) is often the first-line treatment, alongside addressing underlying causes.

column2: joint pain,vomiting,yellowish skin,dark urine,nausea,abdominal pain,diarrhoea,mild fever,yellowing of eyes,muscle pain
column11: A sensation of pressure, squeezing, heaviness, or constriction in your chest that can feel uncomfortable or alarming.
column12: Chest tightness is a common symptom with a diverse range of potential causes, including cardiac, pulmonary, gastrointestinal, musculoskeletal, and psychological. Cardiac Causes: Angina/Myocardial Ischemia: Typically described as pressure, squeezing, or heaviness, often radiating to the arm, jaw, or back, and worsened by exertion. Pericarditis: Inflammation of the heart's outer lining, causing sharp pain that can also feel like tightness. Pulmonary Causes: Asthma/COPD Exacerbation: Bronchoconstriction and inflammation lead to a feeling of tightness and difficulty breathing. Pneumonia/Bronchitis: Inflammation of lung tissue or airways. Pneumothorax: Collapsed lung, sudden onset of tightness and sharp pain. Pulmonary Embolism: Blood clot in the lung artery, often with sudden shortness of breath and chest pain. Gastrointestinal Causes: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD): Acid reflux can cause a burning or squeezing sensation that mimics cardiac pain. Esophageal Spasm: Involuntary contractions of the esophagus. Musculoskeletal Causes: Costochondritis: Inflammation of the cartilage connecting ribs to the breastbone, causing localized tenderness and tightness. Muscle Strain/Injury: In the chest wall. Psychological Causes: Anxiety/Panic Attacks: Very common cause, often accompanied by hyperventilation, palpitations, and fear. Differentiation is crucial, especially to rule out cardiac emergencies.

column2: joint pain,vomiting,yellowish skin,dark urine,nausea,loss of appetite,diarrhoea,mild fever,yellowing of eyes,muscle pain
column10: Difficulty : (Assuming "Difficulty Breathing" or Dyspnea, as it's common and fits contextually with chest tightness)
column11: Feeling like you can't get enough air, that your breaths are labored, or that you're struggling to inhale or exhale sufficiently.
column12: Difficulty breathing, or dyspnea, is the subjective sensation of an uncomfortable awareness of one's own breathing. It is a cardinal symptom of many serious medical conditions. Cardiopulmonary: Respiratory: Asthma, COPD, pneumonia, acute bronchitis, pulmonary embolism, pneumothorax, interstitial lung disease, pleural effusion. Cardiac: Congestive heart failure, myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, valvular heart disease. Other Causes: Anemia: Reduced oxygen-carrying capacity. Anxiety/Panic Attacks: Often associated with hyperventilation. Obesity/Deconditioning: Increased respiratory effort. Metabolic Acidosis: Due to kidney failure or diabetic ketoacidosis. Neuromuscular Disorders: Weakness of respiratory muscles (e.g., ALS, Myasthenia Gravis, Guillain-Barré Syndrome). Upper Airway Obstruction: Foreign body, anaphylaxis, epiglottitis. The speed of onset, duration, severity, and associated symptoms are critical for determining the underlying cause and urgency of treatment.

column11: Your voice sounds rough, raspy, breathy, strained, or deeper than usual, or you might have difficulty speaking loudly.
column12: Hoarse voice (dysphonia) is caused by abnormal vibration of the vocal cords, typically due to problems with the larynx (voice box) or its nerve supply. Acute Causes (Most Common): Laryngitis: Inflammation of the vocal cords, usually viral (e.g., common cold, flu), causing acute hoarseness, often with sore throat, cough. Vocal Cord Strain/Abuse: Overuse (shouting, singing), improper vocal technique, can cause acute hoarseness or even vocal cord nodules/polyps with chronic abuse. Chronic Causes: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)/Laryngopharyngeal Reflux (LPR): Chronic acid irritation of the vocal cords. Smoking: Irritation and inflammation, increased risk of laryngeal cancer. Vocal Cord Nodules/Polyps/Cysts: Benign growths on vocal cords, often from voice misuse. Vocal Cord Paralysis/Paresis: Damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (e.g., from surgery, stroke, tumor in neck/chest). Thyroid Disorders: Hypothyroidism can cause a deep, hoarse voice. Neurological Conditions: Parkinson's disease, MS (can affect voice control). Laryngeal Cancer: Persistent hoarseness is a key symptom, especially in smokers/heavy drinkers. Hoarseness lasting more than 2-3 weeks, especially without a clear acute cause or in smokers, should be evaluated by a doctor. column2: itching,fatigue,lethargy,yellowish skin,dark urine,loss of appetite,abdominal pain,yellow urine,yellowing of eyes,malaise,receiving blood transfusion,receiving unsterile injections
column11: A feeling of pain, scratchiness, or irritation in your throat, which often worsens when you swallow.
column12: A sore throat (pharyngitis or tonsillitis) is commonly caused by inflammation of the pharynx or tonsils. Viral Infections (most common): Viruses like those causing the common cold, flu, mononucleosis, or COVID-19. Often accompanied by runny nose, cough, hoarseness, and mild fever. Bacterial Infections: Strep throat (Streptococcal pharyngitis) is a common bacterial cause, characterized by sudden onset, severe pain, difficulty swallowing, fever, and sometimes white patches on tonsils. It requires antibiotic treatment to prevent complications like rheumatic fever. Allergies: Post-nasal drip from allergies can irritate the throat. Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)/Laryngopharyngeal Reflux (LPR): Stomach acid refluxing into the throat, causing chronic irritation and a sore throat, often worse in the morning or after meals. Irritants: Dry air, smoking, air pollution, chemical fumes, or vocal strain. Less Common: Abscess (peritonsillar abscess), certain autoimmune conditions, or rarely, tumors.

column12: Vaginal itching (pruritus vulvae) is a common symptom that can arise from infections, irritants, skin conditions, or systemic diseases. column11: Any movements of your body or limbs that you can't control or stop, happening without your intention.
column12: Involuntary movements are unwanted, unintentional movements that can affect any part of the body. They are a hallmark of various neurological disorders, often involving the basal ganglia, cerebellum, or other motor control pathways. Tremor: Rhythmic, oscillating movements (e.g., essential tremor, Parkinsonian tremor). Dystonia: Sustained or repetitive muscle contractions causing twisting and repetitive movements or abnormal postures (e.g., cervical dystonia, writer's cramp). Chorea: Brief, irregular, abrupt, unpredictable, non-rhythmic movements (e.g., Huntington's disease). Tics: Sudden, rapid, repetitive, non-rhythmic movements or vocalizations (e.g., Tourette's syndrome). Myoclonus: Sudden, brief, shock-like jerks. Ataxia: Lack of muscle coordination leading to unsteady, clumsy movements (e.g., cerebellar ataxia). Akathisia: Inner restlessness with a compulsion to move. Tardive Dyskinesia: Involuntary movements (often oral-facial) caused by long-term use of certain medications, particularly antipsychotics. Restless Legs Syndrome: An irresistible urge to move the legs, often accompanied by unpleasant sensations. Causes range from neurodegenerative diseases, stroke, medications, metabolic imbalances, to genetic disorders. A neurological assessment is crucial.

column11: Any discomfort, aching, throbbing, or sharp sensation felt anywhere in your arm, from your shoulder to your hand.
column12: Arm pain is a common symptom with diverse origins, including musculoskeletal, neurological, and vascular issues, and sometimes referred pain from other areas. Musculoskeletal: Muscle Strain/Tendinopathy: Overuse or injury to muscles or tendons (e.g., biceps tendinitis, triceps tendinitis). Bursitis: Inflammation of bursae (e.g., shoulder bursitis, elbow bursitis). Arthritis: In the shoulder, elbow, or wrist joints (e.g., osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis). Fractures/Dislocations: Of bones in the arm. Rotator Cuff Injuries: Pain in the shoulder that can radiate down the arm. "Tennis Elbow" (Lateral Epicondylitis)/"Golfer's Elbow" (Medial Epicondylitis): Tendinopathy around the elbow. Neurological: Cervical Radiculopathy: Nerve compression in the neck (e.g., from a herniated disc or spinal stenosis) causing pain, numbness, tingling, and weakness that radiates down the arm. Peripheral Nerve Compression/Entrapment: (e.g., cubital tunnel syndrome affecting the ulnar nerve at the elbow). Thoracic Outlet Syndrome: Compression of nerves or blood vessels in the space between your collarbone and first rib. Vascular: Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD): Less common in the arms but can cause arm pain with exertion (claudication). Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) of the arm: Blood clot in an arm vein, causing swelling, pain, and warmth. Cardiac (Referred Pain): Arm pain, especially in the left arm, can be a symptom of angina or a heart attack. Here's the first batch of 10 symptoms from image_27db89.png: Batch 1 of 10

column11: Any changes in your feelings, mood, or how you react emotionally, such as feeling unusually sad, irritable, anxious, or having mood swings.
column12: "Emotional symptoms" is a broad term encompassing a range of psychological and behavioral manifestations that can indicate underlying mental health conditions, stress, or responses to medical illness. Mood Disorders: Depressed mood, anhedonia (loss of pleasure), irritability, changes in appetite or sleep (as seen in depression). Conversely, elevated mood, euphoria, increased energy, and decreased need for sleep can indicate mania or hypomania (as seen in bipolar disorder). Anxiety Disorders: Excessive worry, panic attacks (sudden intense fear with physical symptoms), restlessness, feeling on edge. Stress Response: Irritability, difficulty concentrating, feeling overwhelmed. Adjustment Disorders: Emotional reactions to identifiable stressors. Psychotic Disorders: Delusions or hallucinations (false beliefs or sensory experiences). Medical Conditions: Hormonal imbalances (e.g., thyroid disorders), neurological conditions, chronic pain, and certain medication side effects can manifest with emotional symptoms. Substance Use: Drug abuse can significantly alter mood and behavior.

column11: Feeling unusually tired, drained, and lacking energy, even after rest. It's more profound than just ordinary tiredness and can interfere with daily activities.
column12: Fatigue is a pervasive feeling of lack of energy, tiredness, or exhaustion. It's a common, non-specific symptom that can stem from various physical, psychological, and lifestyle factors. Physiological Fatigue: Normal response to lack of sleep, overexertion, or stress. Acute Fatigue: Often accompanies acute infections (e.g., common cold, flu, COVID-19), acute illness, or short-term sleep deprivation. Chronic Fatigue: Lasting six months or more. Medical Conditions: Anemia, hypothyroidism, chronic kidney disease, heart failure, diabetes mellitus, autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis), chronic infections (e.g., Epstein-Barr virus, HIV), sleep disorders (e.g., sleep apnea, insomnia), fibromyalgia (often with widespread body aches). Psychological Conditions: Depression, anxiety, chronic stress. Lifestyle Factors: Poor diet, lack of exercise, excessive caffeine/alcohol use, certain medications. Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (Myalgic Encephalomyelitis): A complex, severe, and disabling condition characterized by profound fatigue not alleviated by rest, and other symptoms.

column11: A feeling of reduced strength in your elbow, making it difficult to bend, straighten, or rotate your forearm, or to lift things using your arm.
column12: Elbow weakness can result from issues affecting the muscles, tendons, nerves, or joints around the elbow, or be referred from the neck. Nerve Entrapment/Compression: Cubital Tunnel Syndrome: Compression of the ulnar nerve at the elbow, causing weakness in some hand muscles, numbness, and tingling in the ring and pinky fingers. Radial Nerve Palsy: Can cause weakness in wrist and finger extension. Muscle/Tendon Injuries: Muscle Strains: In the biceps, triceps, or forearm muscles. Tendinopathy: "Tennis Elbow" (lateral epicondylitis affecting forearm extensors) or "Golfer's Elbow" (medial epicondylitis affecting forearm flexors) can cause pain and perceived weakness due to pain inhibition. column11: Sudden, uncontrolled disturbances in the brain's electrical activity that can cause changes in behavior, movements, feelings, or levels of consciousness. They can manifest in many ways, from staring spells to full-body convulsions.
column12: Seizures are transient occurrences of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain. They are a symptom, and epilepsy is a disorder characterized by recurrent, unprovoked seizures. Types of Seizures: Focal Seizures: Originate in one area of the brain. Symptoms depend on the affected brain region (e.g., motor jerking, sensory disturbances, abnormal sensations or thoughts). Generalized Seizures: Involve both sides of the brain. Tonic-Clonic (Grand Mal): Characterized by stiffening (tonic) then jerking (clonic) movements, loss of consciousness. Absence (Petit Mal): Brief staring spells, common in children. Myoclonic: Sudden, brief muscle jerks. Atonic: Sudden loss of muscle tone, causing falls ("drop attacks"). Causes: Epilepsy: Chronic neurological disorder. Acute Symptomatic Seizures: Triggered by acute conditions like fever (febrile seizures in children), electrolyte imbalances (e.g., low sodium), severe hypoglycemia, head trauma, stroke, brain infections (meningitis, encephalitis), brain tumors, drug withdrawal (alcohol withdrawal), or drug overdose. Vascular Malformations. Genetic Syndromes. Diagnosis involves detailed history, neurological exam, EEG (electroencephalogram), and brain imaging (MRI).

column11: Any amount of vaginal bleeding, from a few drops (spotting) to a heavier flow, that occurs at any point during pregnancy.
column12: Vaginal bleeding during pregnancy is a common symptom that can range from benign to life-threatening, depending on the gestational age and associated symptoms. First Trimester Bleeding: Implantation Bleeding: Light spotting around the time of conception. Threatened Miscarriage: Vaginal bleeding with or without cramping, but the cervix is closed. Miscarriage (Spontaneous Abortion): Bleeding, cramping, and passage of tissue. Ectopic Pregnancy: Implantation outside the uterus, causing severe, unilateral abdominal pain, often with bleeding. Medical emergency. Molar Pregnancy: Abnormal growth of placental tissue. Cervical Changes: Inflammation (cervicitis), polyps, or minor trauma to the cervix (e.g., after intercourse). Second/Third Trimester Bleeding: Placenta Previa: Placenta covers part or all of the cervix, often causing painless bright red bleeding. Placental Abruption: Premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall, causing sudden, severe abdominal pain, dark vaginal bleeding, and uterine tenderness. Medical emergency. Preterm Labor: Bleeding can accompany contractions and cervical changes before 37 weeks. Vasa Previa: Fetal blood vessels run unprotected near the cervix. Cervical/Vaginal Lesions: Polyps, infections, or trauma. Any bleeding during pregnancy warrants immediate medical evaluation.

column11: Any signs or changes in a baby's behavior, feeding, activity, or physical appearance that suggest they are unwell or experiencing a health issue.
column12: "Symptoms of infants" is a very broad category, as infants, especially newborns, have unique physiological responses and manifestations of illness. Their symptoms are often non-specific but require high vigilance due to their vulnerability. Common/Concerning Symptoms: Fever: Any fever in an infant under 3 months is a medical emergency; in older infants, evaluation depends on height of fever and associated symptoms. Irritability: Unexplained fussiness, prolonged crying, difficulty consoling. Poor Feeding: Reduced intake, difficulty sucking/swallowing. Lethargy/Decreased Activity: Lack of responsiveness, excessive sleepiness. Vomiting/Diarrhea: Can quickly lead to dehydration. Respiratory Distress: Fast breathing, difficulty breathing, nasal flaring, grunting, retractions. Rashes. Jaundice: Yellowing of skin/eyes beyond physiological neonatal jaundice. Lack of Growth (Failure to Thrive): Not meeting growth milestones. Abnormal Movements: Seizures (can be subtle in infants). Specific Pain: Such as ear pain (pulling at ear) or abdominal pain. Due to their limited ability to communicate, any change in an infant's usual pattern or behavior should prompt medical attention.

column11: Bringing up phlegm or mucus (sputum) from your lungs or throat when you cough. The sputum can vary in color and consistency.
column12: Coughing up sputum (productive cough) indicates that the respiratory tract is producing excessive mucus or exudate due to inflammation, infection, or irritation. Infections: Acute Bronchitis: Often viral, producing clear, white, or yellowish sputum. Pneumonia: Lung infection, often producing thick, discolored sputum (yellow, green, rust-colored). Common Cold/Flu: Initial clear, then thicker sputum. Tuberculosis: Can cause chronic cough with blood-tinged sputum. Bronchiectasis: Chronic lung condition with dilated airways prone to infection, causing chronic productive cough. Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD): Chronic bronchitis component often involves daily productive cough. Cystic Fibrosis: Genetic disorder causing thick, sticky mucus production throughout the body, including the lungs. Asthma: While often a dry cough, can sometimes produce clear or white sputum, especially with airway inflammation. Post-Nasal Drip: Mucus dripping from the nose/sinuses into the throat can trigger a cough with sputum. The color, consistency, and volume of sputum, along with other symptoms (fever, shortness of breath, chest pain), help determine the cause.

column11: Discomfort or aching located anywhere on your face, which can be dull, sharp, burning, or throbbing.
column12: Facial pain is a common complaint with a wide range of causes, including neurological, dental, sinus, and musculoskeletal issues. Neurological: Trigeminal Neuralgia: Severe, sudden, shock-like or stabbing pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (jaw, cheek, forehead). Often triggered by touch, chewing. Postherpetic Neuralgia: Persistent pain after a shingles outbreak (Herpes Zoster) on the face. Migraine/Cluster Headaches: Can cause significant facial pain/pressure. Sinusitis: Inflammation of the sinuses, causing pressure, pain, and tenderness in the forehead, cheeks, or around the eyes. Often with nasal congestion and discharge. Dental/Oral Issues: Toothache, dental abscess, temporomandibular joint (TMJ) dysfunction (pain in the jaw joint and surrounding muscles, often radiating to the ear or face). Ear Infection: Referred pain from the ear to the face. Salivary Gland Disorders: Inflammation or stones in salivary glands. Musculoskeletal: Muscle tension in the face or jaw. Giant Cell Arteritis: Inflammation of arteries, can cause jaw pain, headaches, and scalp tenderness in older adults. Medical emergency if visual symptoms develop.

column2: joint pain,vomiting,fatigue,yellowish skin,dark urine,nausea,abdominal pain,yellowing of eyes
column11: Pain or pressure felt specifically in the front part of your head, often across the forehead or above the eyes.
column12: A frontal headache is a common type of headache that localizes to the frontal region of the head. Tension-Type Headache: Most common type, often described as a tight band around the head or pressure/dull ache in the forehead and temples. Usually mild to moderate and not worsened by activity. Sinus Headache: Caused by inflammation of the frontal sinuses (sinusitis), leading to pressure and pain in the forehead, often worse when bending over. Accompanied by nasal congestion, discharge, and sometimes fever. Migraine: Can manifest with frontal pain, often throbbing, severe, and accompanied by nausea, vomiting, photophobia (light sensitivity), or phonophobia (sound sensitivity). Cluster Headache: Severe, excruciating pain, often around one eye or temple, but can extend to the forehead. Occurs in clusters, with associated symptoms like tearing, nasal congestion, and eyelid drooping on the affected side. Eye Strain: From prolonged screen time or uncorrected vision. Fever: Any febrile illness can cause a generalized or frontal headache. Less Common/Serious: Brain tumor, subarachnoid hemorrhage (sudden, severe "thunderclap" headache).

column11: The medical term for the common cold, characterized by symptoms like runny nose, stuffy nose, sneezing, and sometimes a sore throat.
column12: Coryza refers specifically to the symptoms of the common cold, an acute, self-limiting viral infection of the upper respiratory tract. Viral Etiology (most common): Rhinoviruses are the most frequent cause, but also coronaviruses, adenoviruses, parainfluenza viruses, etc. Symptoms: Nasal Congestion: Swelling of nasal passages. Rhinorrhea: Runny nose, initially clear and watery, later becoming thicker. Sneezing. Sore Throat: Often an early symptom. Cough: May develop later. Mild Headache: Often frontal. Malaise/Ache all over: General feeling of unwellness. Low-grade Fever: More common in children than adults. It's typically spread by respiratory droplets and direct contact. column11: Acting in an unfriendly, aggressive, or antagonistic way towards others. This can include verbal threats, physical aggression, or a generally uncooperative and angry demeanor.
column12: Hostile behavior is a manifestation of anger and aggression that can stem from various underlying psychological, psychiatric, neurological, or physiological conditions. Psychiatric Disorders: Mood Disorders: Severe depression (especially with irritability), bipolar disorder (during manic or mixed episodes). Psychotic Disorders: Schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder (especially if associated with delusions or hallucinations). Personality Disorders: Borderline personality disorder, antisocial personality disorder. Intermittent Explosive Disorder: Recurrent behavioral outbursts representing a failure to control aggressive impulses. Neurological Conditions: Dementia: As a symptom of cognitive decline. Brain Injury/Tumors: Especially affecting frontal or temporal lobes. Stroke: Epilepsy: During or after a seizure. Substance Use/Withdrawal: Alcohol or drug intoxication or withdrawal (e.g., alcohol withdrawal, opioid withdrawal). Medical Conditions: Delirium (acute confusion), infections (e.g., UTIs in elderly), endocrine disorders, severe pain, metabolic imbalances. Environmental Factors: Stress, trauma, frustration, or perceived threats.

column11: Using illegal drugs, or misusing prescription or over-the-counter drugs, in a way that is harmful to your health or life (e.g., taking too much, too often, or for non-medical reasons).
column12: Drug abuse, now typically referred to as Substance Use Disorder (SUD) in diagnostic criteria (DSM-5), is a problematic pattern of substance use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress. It is characterized by impaired control, social impairment, risky use, and pharmacological criteria (tolerance and withdrawal). Commonly Abused Substances: Opioids (prescription pain relievers, heroin), stimulants (cocaine, methamphetamine, ADHD medications), cannabis, benzodiazepines, hallucinogens, inhalants, alcohol, nicotine. Medical Consequences: Vary widely by substance but can include: Infectious Diseases: HIV, hepatitis (from needle sharing). Cardiovascular: Arrhythmias, heart attack, stroke. Neurological: Seizures, brain damage, cognitive impairment, neuropathy. Psychiatric: Worsening or induction of depression, anxiety, psychosis. Gastrointestinal: Liver damage, pancreatitis. Respiratory: Lung damage. Overdose: Potentially fatal. Treatment involves detoxification, behavioral therapies, and often medication-assisted treatment.

column2: joint pain,vomiting,fatigue,high fever,yellowish skin,dark urine,nausea,loss of appetite,abdominal pain,yellowing of eyes,acute liver failure,coma,stomach bleeding
column11: Sudden, involuntary, painful tightening of a muscle in your leg, which can last from a few seconds to several minutes. They often occur in the calf or thigh.
column12: Leg cramps are sudden, involuntary, forceful contractions of muscles, often painful, usually in the calf, foot, or thigh. Spasms are similar, but might be less intense or more repetitive. Common/Benign Causes: Dehydration/Electrolyte Imbalance: Especially low potassium, magnesium, calcium. Muscle Fatigue/Overuse: After strenuous exercise or prolonged standing. Nocturnal Leg Cramps: Common at night, cause awakened sleep. Poor Circulation: Peripheral artery disease (PAD) can cause claudication (cramping pain with exertion). Neurological Conditions: Nerve Compression/Radiculopathy: (e.g., from a herniated disc in the back) can cause muscle spasms and cramps in the leg. Peripheral Neuropathy: Nerve damage (e.g., from diabetes). Restless Legs Syndrome: While primarily an urge to move, can involve cramp-like sensations. Motor Neuron Disease: (e.g., ALS). Medications: Diuretics, statins, beta-agonists. Other: Pregnancy, hypothyroidism, kidney failure.

column2: joint pain,vomiting,fatigue,high fever,yellowish skin,dark urine,nausea,loss of appetite,abdominal pain,yellowing of eyes,acute liver failure,coma,stomach bleeding
column11: Sudden, involuntary, and often painful tightening of muscles anywhere in the body. Spasms are generally less intense or prolonged than cramps.
column12: Cramps are sudden, involuntary, painful, and often sustained contractions of one or more muscles. Spasms are more generalized involuntary muscle contractions that may or may not be painful. This is a broader category than just leg cramps. Common Causes: Dehydration/Electrolyte Imbalance: Lack of sodium, potassium, calcium, magnesium. Muscle Fatigue/Overuse: From strenuous physical activity. Nerve Compression/Irritation: Radiculopathy, carpal tunnel syndrome, direct nerve injury. Restless Legs Syndrome: Can cause cramp-like sensations. Medication Side Effects: Diuretics, statins. Neurological Conditions: Dystonia: Sustained muscle contractions causing twisting or repetitive movements. Spasticity: Increased muscle tone causing stiffness and spasms (e.g., in multiple sclerosis, cerebral palsy, stroke). Tetanus: Severe bacterial infection causing widespread muscle spasms. Hypocalcemia: Low blood calcium can lead to muscle cramps and tetany. Motor Neuron Disease (e.g., ALS). Gastrointestinal: Abdominal cramps from IBS, gastroenteritis, or menstrual cramps. Evaluation involves considering the location, triggers, duration, and associated symptoms.

column11: Any new lump, bump, mole, wart, or discolored patch that appears on your skin, or an existing one that changes in size, shape, color, or texture.
column12: A skin growth (skin lesion or neoplasm) is an abnormal proliferation of cells on or under the skin. They can be benign (non-cancerous), pre-malignant (potentially cancerous), or malignant (cancerous). Benign Growths (most common): Moles (Nevi): Common pigmented spots. Skin Tags: Small, soft, flesh-colored growths. Seborrheic Keratoses: Waxy, "stuck-on" looking brown or black growths. Lipomas: Soft, fatty lumps under the skin. Cysts: Sacs filled with fluid or semi-solid material. Warts: Caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). Cherry Angiomas: Small, bright red bumps. Pre-malignant Growths: Actinic Keratoses: Rough, scaly patches on sun-exposed skin. Malignant Growths (Skin Cancers): Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC): Most common, slow-growing, often pearly or waxy. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC): Red, scaly, crusty, or open sore. Melanoma: Most dangerous, often arises from moles, characterized by asymmetry, irregular borders, uneven color, and increasing diameter (ABCDE rule). Any new, changing, symptomatic, or suspicious skin growth should be evaluated by a dermatologist.

column2: joint pain,fatigue,high fever,yellowish skin,dark urine,nausea,loss of appetite,abdominal pain,yellowing of eyes,acute liver failure,coma,stomach bleeding
column11: Excessive tearing or watering of your eyes, more than normal for blinking or crying.
column12: Lacrimation refers to the production of tears. Excessive lacrimation (epiphora) is often due to overproduction of tears or impaired drainage of tears. Overproduction of Tears: Eye Irritation/Inflammation: Foreign body sensation, conjunctivitis ("pink eye"), corneal abrasion, dry eyes (paradoxically, severe dry eye can trigger reflex tearing), allergies. Infections: Viral (common cold, adenovirus), bacterial. Environmental Irritants: Smoke, dust, strong winds. Allergic Reactions: Itchy, watery eyes. Impaired Tear Drainage (Blocked Tear Ducts): Nasolacrimal Duct Obstruction: Common in infants, usually resolves. Can also occur in adults due to inflammation, infection, or trauma. Eyelid Malposition: Ectropion (eyelid turned outward) can prevent tears from entering the puncta (drainage holes). Inflammation of the Tear Drainage System (Dacryocystitis). Persistent excessive tearing warrants evaluation by an ophthalmologist.

column2: joint pain,vomiting,high fever,yellowish skin,dark urine,nausea,loss of appetite,abdominal pain,yellowing of eyes,acute liver failure,coma,stomach bleeding
column11: A lump, bump, or swelling that appears on or under your eyelid.
column12: A mass on the eyelid can be benign (non-cancerous), inflammatory, or, less commonly, malignant (cancerous). Benign/Inflammatory: Stye (Hordeolum): A painful, red, tender lump on the edge of the eyelid, caused by a bacterial infection of an oil gland. Chalazion: A firm, painless lump on the eyelid, usually developing from a stye that has healed but left a blocked oil gland. Cyst: A small fluid-filled sac. Xanthelasma: Yellowish, fatty deposits on or around the eyelids, often associated with high cholesterol. Papilloma: Benign wart-like growth. Malignant (Less Common): Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC): Most common eyelid cancer, often appears as a nodule with a pearly rolled border, or a non-healing sore. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC): Less common, can appear as a red, scaly, or crusted nodule. Sebaceous Gland Carcinoma: Rare but aggressive. Melanoma: Very rare on eyelids. Any new, persistent, rapidly growing, bleeding, or suspicious eyelid mass should be evaluated by an ophthalmologist.

column11: Seeing thick, yellowish, greenish, or whitish fluid coming out of your ear. It might be accompanied by pain, fever, or reduced hearing.
column12: Pus draining from the ear (otorrhea) is a sign of infection, typically in the external ear canal or middle ear, often associated with a perforated eardrum. Otitis Externa (Swimmer's Ear): Infection of the outer ear canal, often caused by bacteria. Symptoms include pain, itching, redness, and discharge. Acute Otitis Media (AOM) with Tympanic Membrane Perforation: Middle ear infection where pressure builds up and the eardrum ruptures, releasing pus. This often provides pain relief. Symptoms include ear pain, fever, and hearing loss before the rupture, followed by discharge. Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM): Persistent discharge from a perforated eardrum, often with hearing loss, due to chronic middle ear infection. Cholesteatoma: A benign but destructive skin growth in the middle ear that can erode bone and cause persistent ear discharge, hearing loss, and sometimes dizziness. Foreign Body in Ear Canal: Can cause irritation, infection, and discharge. Any ear discharge, especially pus, warrants medical evaluation.

column11: Any discomfort, aching, or sharp pain felt in or around the vagina.
column12: Vaginal pain is a common symptom with various gynecological, infectious, and musculoskeletal causes. Infections: Yeast Infection (Candidiasis): Often with intense itching, burning, and thick discharge. Bacterial Vaginosis (BV): Can cause irritation and discharge. Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs): Herpes (painful sores), gonorrhea, chlamydia. Inflammation/Irritation (Vaginitis/Vulvovaginitis): From soaps, detergents, perfumes, douching, tight clothing, or chemical sensitivity. Atrophic Vaginitis: Thinning and drying of vaginal tissues due to low estrogen (e.g., menopause, breastfeeding), leading to dryness, itching, and pain. Sexual Dysfunction: Dyspareunia: Pain during sexual intercourse. Can be superficial or deep. Vaginismus: Involuntary spasm of vaginal muscles. Pelvic Floor Dysfunction: Tightness or spasm of pelvic floor muscles. Trauma: From childbirth, sexual assault, or injury. Cysts: Bartholin's cyst or abscess. Rare: Vulvar cancer. column2: joint pain,vomiting,fatigue,high fever,yellowish skin,nausea,loss of appetite,abdominal pain,yellowing of eyes,acute liver failure,coma,stomach bleeding
column11: Any unusual change in the color, texture, shape, or feel of your skin, or the appearance of new spots, rashes, or growths.
column12: "Abnormal appearing skin" is a broad term encompassing a vast array of dermatological manifestations, ranging from common benign conditions to serious systemic diseases or malignancies. Rashes: Can be macules (flat spots), papules (raised bumps), vesicles (blisters), pustules (pus-filled bumps), plaques (raised, flat-topped lesions), or urticaria (hives). Causes include infections (viral, bacterial, fungal), allergic reactions (contact dermatitis, drug eruptions), autoimmune diseases (lupus, psoriasis, eczema), or inflammatory conditions. Discoloration: Redness (Erythema): Due to inflammation, infection (e.g., cellulitis), or allergic reactions. Pallor: Unusually pale skin, often due to anemia or poor circulation. Jaundice: Yellowing of skin and eyes, indicating liver dysfunction or excessive red blood cell breakdown. Hyperpigmentation/Hypopigmentation: Darkening or lightening of skin (e.g., melasma, vitiligo). Texture Changes: Dryness, scaling, thickening, or thinning. Growths: New moles, warts, skin tags, or suspicious lesions that could indicate skin cancer (basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma). Infections: Bacterial (impetigo, folliculitis), fungal (ringworm, athlete's foot), viral (herpes, shingles). Any new, changing, painful, or persistent skin abnormality warrants medical evaluation.

column2: joint pain,vomiting,fatigue,high fever,yellowish skin,dark urine,loss of appetite,abdominal pain,yellowing of eyes,acute liver failure,coma,stomach bleeding
column11: A noticeable enlargement or puffiness in the neck area. This can be localized to a specific spot or more diffuse.
column12: Neck swelling can arise from various structures within the neck, including lymph nodes, salivary glands, the thyroid gland, or other soft tissues. Lymph Node Enlargement (Lymphadenopathy): Most common cause, usually due to infection (e.g., viral upper respiratory infection, strep throat, mononucleosis) or inflammation. Less commonly, can be due to malignancy (lymphoma, metastatic cancer). Thyroid Gland Issues: Goiter: Enlargement of the thyroid gland, which can be diffuse or nodular. Thyroid Nodules/Cysts/Tumors: Benign or malignant growths within the thyroid. Salivary Gland Swelling: Inflammation (sialadenitis, e.g., mumps) or stones (sialolithiasis). Infections: Abscess: Collection of pus in neck tissues. Cellulitis: Bacterial infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. Cervical Lymphadenitis: Inflamed lymph nodes due to infection. Cysts: Benign congenital cysts (e.g., branchial cleft cyst, thyroglossal duct cyst). Allergic Reaction (Angioedema): Rapid swelling of deeper skin layers. Tumors: Laryngeal, pharyngeal, or other head and neck cancers. The presence of pain, tenderness, redness, rapid growth, or associated symptoms helps in diagnosis.

column10: Skin on leg or foot looks infected
column11: The skin on your leg or foot appears red, swollen, warm, painful, and possibly has pus or open sores, suggesting a bacterial or fungal infection.
column12: Skin infection on the leg or foot commonly manifests with signs of inflammation and localized or spreading infection. Bacterial Infections: Cellulitis: A common bacterial infection of the deeper layers of skin and subcutaneous tissue, causing rapidly spreading redness, warmth, pain, and swelling. Often unilateral. Can be serious if untreated. Erysipelas: A superficial form of cellulitis with sharply defined, raised, red borders. Impetigo: Superficial skin infection, often with crusting, more common in children. Abscess: A localized collection of pus under the skin. Fungal Infections: Athlete's Foot (Tinea Pedis): Common fungal infection of the feet, causing itching, redness, scaling, and sometimes blisters. Can lead to secondary bacterial infections. Toenail Fungus (Onychomycosis): Thick, discolored, crumbling nails. Other: Diabetic Foot Ulcers: Chronic non-healing wounds, prone to infection due to neuropathy and poor circulation. Venous Stasis Ulcers: Open sores due to chronic venous insufficiency, can become infected. Individuals with diabetes, peripheral vascular disease, or compromised immune systems are at higher risk for these infections.

column2: vomiting,yellowish skin,abdominal pain,swelling of stomach,distention of abdomen,history of alcohol consumption,fluid overload
column11: Your foot or one or more of your toes appear puffy, enlarged, or distended, often making shoes feel tight.
column12: Foot or toe swelling is a common presentation of peripheral edema, but can also indicate localized inflammation or injury. Localized Causes: Injury/Trauma: Sprains, fractures, direct impact. Inflammation: Gout (acute, painful swelling of a single joint, often the big toe) or other forms of arthritis. Infection: Cellulitis, abscess, ingrown toenail with infection. Bunion/Hammertoe: Deformities that can cause localized swelling and pain. Unilateral Systemic Causes (affecting one foot/leg): Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): Blood clot in a leg vein. Chronic Venous Insufficiency: Damage to leg veins. Lymphedema: Impaired lymphatic drainage. Bilateral Systemic Causes (affecting both feet/legs): Congestive Heart Failure (CHF): Fluid backup from the heart. Kidney Disease/Failure: Impaired fluid excretion. Liver Cirrhosis: Reduced albumin production. Medications: Calcium channel blockers, NSAIDs. Prolonged Standing/Sitting. Pregnancy.

column11: One or both of your eyelids or the area around your eye looks puffy or enlarged.
column12: Swollen eye (periorbital edema) can result from inflammation, infection, fluid retention, or allergic reactions. Allergic Reactions: Common cause, often with itching, redness, and watery eyes. Can be localized (e.g., contact with allergen) or part of a systemic reaction (angioedema). Infections: Conjunctivitis ("Pink Eye"): Inflammation of the conjunctiva, often with redness, discharge, and swelling. Stye (Hordeolum)/Chalazion: Localized inflammation/infection of eyelid glands, causing a lump and swelling. Periorbital/Preseptal Cellulitis: Bacterial infection of the eyelid and skin around the eye, causing redness, warmth, pain, and swelling. Orbital Cellulitis: More serious infection behind the eye, can cause proptosis (bulging eye) and vision changes. Medical emergency. Trauma: Direct injury to the eye or surrounding area. Systemic Conditions: Kidney Disease/Nephrotic Syndrome: Can cause generalized edema, often noticeable around the eyes. Thyroid Eye Disease (Graves' Ophthalmopathy): Autoimmune condition causing inflammation and swelling of eye muscles and tissues. Congestive Heart Failure: (less common to primarily present as eye swelling). Blocked Tear Duct: Can cause swelling and redness near the inner corner of the eye.

column11: Your fingernails or toenails look unusual, such as being discolored, brittle, thickened, pitted, ridged, or separated from the nail bed.
column12: Irregular appearing nails (onychology) can provide clues to underlying dermatological, systemic, or nutritional conditions. Fungal Infection (Onychomycosis): Most common cause, especially in toenails. Causes thickening, discoloration (yellow, brown, white), brittleness, and crumbling. Trauma: Repeated minor trauma or a single significant injury can cause nail changes. Psoriasis: A chronic autoimmune skin condition that can affect nails, causing pitting, thickening, discoloration, crumbling, and onycholysis (separation of the nail from the nail bed). Lichen Planus: Inflammatory skin condition that can cause thinning, ridging, or loss of nails. Nutritional Deficiencies: Iron deficiency (spoon-shaped nails - koilonychia), zinc deficiency (Beau's lines, white spots). Thyroid Disorders: Brittle nails. Systemic Diseases: Chronic kidney disease (half-and-half nails), liver cirrhosis (Terry's nails), heart conditions (clubbing). Melanoma: Subungual melanoma (dark streak under the nail). Aging: Nails naturally thicken and become more brittle with age. Evaluation involves visual inspection, and sometimes fungal cultures or biopsy.

column2: vomiting,yellowish skin,swelling of stomach,distention of abdomen,history of alcohol consumption,fluid overload
column11: A sensation of tingling, "pins and needles," numbness, burning, or prickling on your skin, usually in your hands, feet, arms, or legs, without any visible physical cause.
column12: Paresthesia is an abnormal sensation, typically "pins and needles" or tingling, that is usually due to dysfunction or irritation of nerves. Nerve Compression/Entrapment: Peripheral Neuropathy: Damage to peripheral nerves, often symmetrical and affecting hands and feet ("stocking-glove" distribution). Common causes include diabetes, vitamin deficiencies (B12), alcohol abuse, kidney failure, autoimmune diseases. Radiculopathy: Nerve root compression in the spine (e.g., from a herniated disc in the neck causing arm paresthesia or in the lower back causing leg paresthesia). Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Compression of the median nerve in the wrist, causing tingling/numbness in the thumb, index, middle, and half of the ring finger. Cubital Tunnel Syndrome: Compression of the ulnar nerve at the elbow, causing tingling/numbness in the ring and pinky fingers. Central Nervous System Issues: Stroke, multiple sclerosis (MS), brain tumor (less common but can cause localized paresthesia). Vascular Issues: Reduced blood flow to a limb. Medication Side Effects: Certain chemotherapy drugs. Anxiety/Hyperventilation: Can cause transient tingling around the mouth and in the extremities. Migraine: Can have an aura with paresthesia. Investigation aims to identify the specific nerve(s) or area of the nervous system affected.

column2: vomiting,yellowish skin,abdominal pain,distention of abdomen,history of alcohol consumption,fluid overload
column11: Seeing whitish, yellowish-white, or stringy discharge coming from your eye, often accumulating in the corners of your eye, especially in the morning.
column12: White or yellowish-white discharge from the eye typically indicates inflammation or infection of the conjunctiva (the membrane lining the eyelids and covering the white part of the eye). Bacterial Conjunctivitis ("Pink Eye"): Common cause, characterized by thick, purulent (pus-like) discharge that can cause eyelids to stick together, especially after sleep. Often unilateral initially, then bilateral. Viral Conjunctivitis: Often causes watery discharge, but can also produce some whitish, stringy mucus. Usually starts in one eye and spreads to the other. Allergic Conjunctivitis: Often causes clear, watery discharge, but chronic irritation can lead to more mucoid (whitish, stringy) discharge, especially with itching and redness. Blepharitis: Inflammation of the eyelids, often at the base of the eyelashes, causing chronic irritation, redness, and crusting/flaky discharge, especially in the morning. Blocked Tear Duct: Can lead to chronic tearing and mild, whitish discharge from stagnant tears and secondary infection. Dry Eye Syndrome: Can cause compensatory tearing and stringy mucus. Purulent discharge strongly suggests bacterial infection.

column2: vomiting,yellowish skin,abdominal pain,swelling of stomach,history of alcohol consumption,fluid overload
column11: A feeling that there's a lump, tightness, or a foreign object stuck in your throat, even when there's nothing actually there. It doesn't usually interfere with swallowing food or liquids.
column12: A "lump in throat" sensation (globus pharyngeus or globus sensation) is a common complaint that usually has a benign cause. True anatomical lumps are less common but must be ruled out. Globus Sensation (Functional): Most common cause. A feeling of a lump or tightness that is not painful and does not interfere with swallowing food or liquids. Often worsened by stress, anxiety, or emotional upset. It's often due to increased muscle tension in the throat or esophageal spasms. Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)/Laryngopharyngeal Reflux (LPR): Acid reflux irritating the throat and upper esophagus can cause a chronic lump sensation, especially after eating or when lying down. Muscle Tension Dysphonia: Overuse or misuse of throat muscles, leading to a sense of tightness. Thyroid Disorders: An enlarged thyroid gland (goiter) or thyroid nodules can cause a palpable mass and a sensation of a lump or pressure. Zenker's Diverticulum: A pouch in the esophagus where food can collect, causing regurgitation and sometimes a lump sensation. Tumors: Although rare, persistent or progressive lump sensation, especially with true difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), pain, or weight loss, warrants evaluation for esophageal, pharyngeal, or laryngeal cancer.

column11: Passing gas from your digestive system, usually with a distinctive sound and sometimes an odor. It's a natural bodily function but can become excessive or bothersome.
column12: Flatulence refers to the expulsion of gas from the digestive tract through the anus. Intestinal gas is primarily composed of odorless gases (nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, hydrogen, and sometimes methane) and sulfur-containing gases that produce odor. Dietary Factors (Most Common): High-fiber Foods: Beans, lentils, fruits, vegetables, whole grains. FODMAPs: Fermentable Oligo-, Di-, Mono-saccharides And Polyols (e.g., in certain fruits, vegetables, dairy, sweeteners) are poorly absorbed and fermented by gut bacteria. Carbonated Drinks: Introduce swallowed air. Lactose Intolerance/Other Food Intolerances: Inability to digest certain sugars leads to fermentation. Swallowed Air (Aerophagia): Eating too fast, chewing gum, smoking, drinking through a straw. Gastrointestinal Disorders: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS): Often associated with increased gas, bloating, and abdominal pain. Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth (SIBO): Excessive bacteria in the small intestine. Malabsorption Syndromes: Celiac disease, pancreatic insufficiency. Constipation: Can worsen gas production. Changes in Gut Microbiota. While normal, excessive or symptomatic flatulence may indicate an underlying digestive issue. That completes all the symptoms from image_27d78a.png. column11: Your lips appear larger or puffier than usual. This can range from mild puffiness to significant enlargement.
column12: Lip swelling (cheilitis or angioedema of the lips) can be caused by various factors, including allergic reactions, infections, inflammation, or trauma. Allergic Reaction (Angioedema): This is a common and often concerning cause. It involves swelling of the deeper layers of the skin, often in response to allergens (foods, medications like ACE inhibitors, insect stings). It can be rapid in onset and, if severe, may extend to the tongue and throat, potentially compromising the airway. Infections: Herpes Simplex Virus (Cold Sores): Before or during an outbreak, lips can swell. Cellulitis: Bacterial infection of the skin. Inflammatory Conditions: Cheilitis Granulomatosa: A rare inflammatory condition causing persistent lip swelling. Crohn's Disease: Can manifest with oral symptoms including lip swelling. Trauma: Injury to the lips. Dental Issues: Infection or inflammation from a nearby tooth or gum. Systemic Conditions: Hypothyroidism (can cause diffuse swelling).

column11: Any abnormal spot, bump, patch, or change on your skin that wasn't there before or has changed in appearance.
column12: A skin lesion is any area of the skin that has undergone an abnormal change. These can be primary (original problem) or secondary (result from primary lesion or external factors). Primary Lesions: Macule: Flat, discolored spot (e.g., freckle). Papule: Small, raised bump (e.g., mole, wart). Nodule: Larger, deeper solid lump. Vesicle/Bulla: Small/large fluid-filled blister (e.g., herpes, chickenpox). Pustule: Pus-filled lesion (e.g., acne, folliculitis). Plaque: Flat-topped, elevated area (e.g., psoriasis). Wheal (Hives): Raised, itchy, red welts (e.g., allergic reaction). Secondary Lesions: Crusts, scales, ulcers, fissures, scars, atrophy. Causes: Infections (bacterial, viral, fungal, parasitic), inflammatory conditions (eczema, dermatitis), allergic reactions, autoimmune diseases, benign growths (moles, skin tags), pre-malignant changes (actinic keratoses), and skin cancers (basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma). Any changing, symptomatic, or suspicious lesion requires dermatological evaluation.

column11: Breakouts of bumps on your skin, commonly on the face, neck, chest, or back. These can include blackheads, whiteheads, red bumps (papules), or pus-filled bumps (pustules).
column12: Acne vulgaris is a common chronic inflammatory skin condition affecting hair follicles and sebaceous (oil) glands. Pathophysiology: Involves four main factors: Increased Sebum Production: Overactive oil glands. Follicular Hyperkeratinization: Dead skin cells and oil clog hair follicles. Bacterial Proliferation: Propionibacterium acnes (now Cutibacterium acnes) thrives in clogged follicles. Inflammation: The body's immune response to the bacteria and clogged follicle. Types of Lesions: Comedones (blackheads and whiteheads), papules (small red bumps), pustules (pus-filled bumps), nodules (large, painful solid lumps), and cysts (deep, pus-filled lesions). Triggers/Contributing Factors: Hormonal fluctuations (androgens, common in puberty, pregnancy), genetics, certain medications, stress, high glycemic diet, and mechanical irritation. Treatment ranges from topical creams, oral antibiotics, hormonal therapies, to isotretinoin for severe cases.

column11: Any difficulty, abnormality, or involuntary actions when trying to move your body, a limb, or even just coordinating movements.
column12: "Problems with movement" is a broad term encompassing a wide range of motor dysfunctions, often indicating neurological, musculoskeletal, or systemic issues. Weakness (Paresis/Paralysis): Reduced or absent muscle strength, due to nerve damage, muscle disease, stroke, or spinal cord injury. Involuntary Movements: Tremor, tics, dystonia, chorea, myoclonus (as explained previously). Ataxia: Lack of muscle coordination leading to unsteady gait, clumsy movements, or difficulty with fine motor tasks, often due to cerebellar dysfunction. Spasticity/Rigidity: Increased muscle tone causing stiffness and resistance to movement (e.g., in multiple sclerosis, cerebral palsy, Parkinson's disease). Bradykinesia: Slowness of movement (e.g., Parkinson's disease). Gait Disorders: Abnormalities in walking (e.g., shuffling, wide-based, unsteady). Balance Issues: Difficulty maintaining equilibrium. Pain-Related: Movement may be limited or altered due to pain from musculoskeletal injuries (e.g., arthritis, fractures) or nerve pain. A thorough neurological and physical examination is crucial for diagnosis.

column11: The skin on your head underneath your hair looks bumpy, scaly, reddened, or has patches of hair loss, or there's an unusual texture.
column12: An irregular appearing scalp can be a sign of various dermatological, infectious, or autoimmune conditions affecting the scalp skin and hair follicles. Dermatological Conditions: Psoriasis: Red, scaly, silvery plaques, often itchy. Seborrheic Dermatitis: Common cause of dandruff, characterized by oily, flaky, itchy patches (can be yellow/white). Eczema: Red, itchy, inflamed patches. Infections: Tinea Capitis (Ringworm of the Scalp): Fungal infection causing scaly patches, redness, and hair loss, sometimes with pustules. More common in children. Folliculitis: Bacterial infection of hair follicles, causing small, red, itchy bumps or pustules. Lice: Infestation causing intense itching and scalp irritation. Hair Loss Conditions (Alopecia): Alopecia Areata: Autoimmune condition causing patchy, non-scarring hair loss. Traction Alopecia: Hair loss from prolonged pulling/tight hairstyles. Scarring Alopecias: Inflammatory conditions that destroy hair follicles, leading to permanent hair loss and irregular scalp texture. Growths: Cysts (e.g., pilar cysts), skin tags, or skin cancers. Diagnosis often involves visual inspection, dermoscopy, and sometimes biopsy or fungal culture.

column11: Discomfort, aching, or sharp pain felt specifically around the opening of your anus or just inside it.
column12: Anal pain (proctalgia) is a common and often distressing symptom with various causes, primarily localized to the anal canal or perianal area. Hemorrhoids: Swollen veins in the anus or lower rectum. Can be internal or external. External hemorrhoids are often painful if thrombosed (blood clot forms within them). Anal Fissure: A small tear in the lining of the anal canal, often caused by hard stools or straining. Causes severe, sharp pain, especially during and after bowel movements, often with bright red blood in stool. Anal Abscess/Fistula: An abscess is a collection of pus near the anus, causing severe pain, swelling, redness, and fever. A fistula is a tunnel that forms from an abscess to the skin. Proctalgia Fugax: Brief, severe episodes of rectal pain, usually at night, due to muscle spasms. Levator Ani Syndrome: Chronic, dull ache or pressure in the rectal area, often worse with sitting. Infections: STIs (e.g., herpes, warts), fungal infections, perianal strep. Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD): Crohn's disease can affect the perianal area with fissures, fistulas, or abscesses. Constipation/Straining: Can exacerbate existing conditions or cause discomfort. Cancer: Anal cancer (less common, but important to rule out).

column11: A general sense of unwellness, malaise, or being sick, often without specific, localized symptoms, or accompanying multiple vague symptoms.
column12: "Feeling ill" is a subjective and non-specific symptom, often referred to as malaise. It indicates that the body is experiencing some form of physiological stress or illness. Infections (most common): Viral (e.g., common cold, flu, COVID-19, mononucleosis), bacterial (e.g., UTI, strep throat), or parasitic. Often accompanied by fever, fatigue, or aches. Inflammatory Conditions: Autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis), chronic inflammatory conditions. Chronic Medical Conditions: Heart failure, kidney disease, liver disease, diabetes, cancer. Fatigue: Prolonged or severe fatigue can manifest as feeling ill. Stress/Anxiety/Depression: Psychological distress can manifest with physical symptoms and a general feeling of unwellness. Medication Side Effects: Many drugs can cause a generalized feeling of unwellness. Dehydration/Nutritional Deficiencies. Persistent or worsening feelings of illness, especially with other concerning symptoms, warrant medical evaluation.
