column11: A sore or open lesion that develops inside your mouth, on your gums, tongue, inner cheeks, or lips. They can be painful, especially when eating or drinking.
column12: Mouth ulcers (aphthous ulcers or stomatitis) are breaks in the mucous membrane lining the mouth. Common Causes (Aphthous Ulcers/Canker Sores): Most common type, etiology unclear but often associated with stress, minor trauma (e.g., biting cheek), certain foods, hormonal changes, and genetic predisposition. They are typically painful, round or oval, with a white/yellow center and red border. Trauma: Accidental biting, dental work, ill-fitting dentures, sharp foods. Infections: Herpes Simplex Virus (Cold Sores): Usually on the outside of the mouth, but can occur inside. Fungal Infections: Oral thrush (candidiasis), often white patches that can be scraped off. Viral Infections: Hand, foot, and mouth disease, varicella (chickenpox). Systemic Conditions: Nutritional Deficiencies: Iron, B12, folate, zinc. Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD): Crohn's disease can cause oral ulcers. Celiac Disease: Behçet's Disease: A rare inflammatory disorder characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers. Autoimmune Diseases: Lupus, pemphigus. Medications: NSAIDs, certain chemotherapy drugs. Malignancy: Oral cancer can present as a non-healing ulcer, especially in smokers/alcohol drinkers. Any persistent (over 2 weeks) or suspicious mouth ulcer should be evaluated.

column11: A feeling of reduced flexibility or range of motion in your wrist, making it difficult to bend, straighten, or rotate your hand. It might feel "stuck" or less fluid than usual.
column12: Wrist stiffness or tightness indicates reduced mobility of the wrist joint, often due to inflammation, injury, or degenerative changes. Arthritis: Osteoarthritis: Degenerative "wear and tear" arthritis, common in older adults, can affect wrist joints. Rheumatoid Arthritis: Autoimmune inflammatory arthritis, frequently affects wrist and hand joints symmetrically, causing stiffness, pain, and swelling. Morning stiffness is characteristic. Post-Traumatic Stiffness: After a fracture, sprain, or other injury, often due to scar tissue formation or prolonged immobilization (e.g., in a cast). Tendinopathy/Tenosynovitis: Inflammation or irritation of tendons or their sheaths around the wrist (e.g., De Quervain's tenosynovitis, intersection syndrome). Ganglion Cyst: Benign, fluid-filled lump near a joint or tendon, can cause stiffness if large or pressing on structures. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: While primarily causing numbness/tingling, severe cases can affect wrist mobility. Trigger Finger/Thumb: While primarily affecting finger movement, chronic issues can lead to overall hand/wrist stiffness. Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma): Autoimmune disease causing skin thickening and joint stiffness.

column11: Any discomfort, aching, or sharp sensation felt in or around your shoulder joint. It can make it difficult to move your arm or sleep on your side.
column12: Shoulder pain is a very common musculoskeletal complaint, often arising from the complex structures of the shoulder joint (rotator cuff, bursa, tendons, ligaments, cartilage, bone) or referred from other areas. Rotator Cuff Injuries: Tendinitis/Impingement: Inflammation or irritation of the rotator cuff tendons, often due to overuse or repetitive motions, causing pain with overhead activities. Rotator Cuff Tear: Partial or full tear of one or more tendons, causing pain and weakness. Bursitis: Inflammation of the bursa (fluid-filled sac that cushions joints), typically subacromial bursitis, causing pain with movement and at rest. Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis): Causes progressive pain and significant loss of range of motion in the shoulder. Arthritis: Osteoarthritis or inflammatory arthritis (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis) can affect the shoulder joint, causing pain and stiffness. AC Joint Injury: Pain at the acromioclavicular joint (top of the shoulder), often from trauma. Biceps Tendinopathy: Pain in the front of the shoulder, sometimes radiating down the arm. Referred Pain: Cervical Radiculopathy: Nerve compression in the neck can cause pain radiating to the shoulder and arm. Heart Attack: Pain can radiate to the left shoulder and arm. Gallbladder Disease: Pain can refer to the right shoulder. Diaphragmatic Irritation: (e.g., ruptured spleen or subphrenic abscess) can cause left shoulder tip pain. Physical examination and imaging (X-ray, MRI) help determine the cause. I will wait for your confirmation before providing the next set of symptoms. column11: A common discomfort or ache felt in the lower part of your back, above the buttocks but below the ribs. It can range from dull to sharp and may limit movement.
column12: Low back pain (LBP) is a very common musculoskeletal complaint affecting the lumbar spine, sacrum, and surrounding muscles, ligaments, and nerves. It can be acute (less than 6 weeks), subacute (6-12 weeks), or chronic (over 12 weeks). Mechanical Low Back Pain (most common): Muscle Strain/Ligament Sprain: Overuse, improper lifting, or sudden movements causing injury to back muscles or ligaments. Disc Degeneration/Herniation: Wear and tear or rupture of intervertebral discs, potentially compressing nerve roots (radiculopathy), causing pain that radiates down the leg (sciatica). Osteoarthritis (Spondylosis): Degenerative changes in the spinal joints. Spinal Stenosis: Narrowing of the spinal canal, compressing nerves. Spondylolisthesis: Forward slippage of one vertebra over another. Inflammatory Back Pain: Ankylosing Spondylitis/Other Spondyloarthropathies: Chronic inflammatory conditions causing stiffness and pain, often worse in the morning and improving with activity. Non-Spinal Causes (Referred Pain): Kidney stones or infection, pancreatitis, gynecological issues (e.g., endometriosis, fibroids), or abdominal aortic aneurysm can refer pain to the back. Serious Causes (Red Flags): Trauma, cancer (metastasis), infection (osteomyelitis, discitis), cauda equina syndrome (neurological emergency). Evaluation typically involves history, physical exam, and sometimes imaging (X-ray, MRI).

column11: A feeling that a joint or part of your body is rigid, tight, or has a reduced range of motion, making it difficult to move freely. It might be worse after rest.
column12: Stiffness or decreased movement indicates reduced flexibility or range of motion in a joint, muscle, or body region. This can be due to structural changes, inflammation, pain, or neurological conditions. Joint Stiffness: Arthritis: Osteoarthritis: Often worse after inactivity ("gelling" phenomenon) but improves with movement. Inflammatory Arthritis (e.g., Rheumatoid Arthritis, Psoriatic Arthritis, Ankylosing Spondylitis): Characterized by morning stiffness lasting longer than 30-60 minutes that improves with activity. Post-Injury/Surgery: Scar tissue formation, muscle guarding, or prolonged immobilization. Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis): Progressive loss of shoulder range of motion. Muscle Stiffness: Muscle Strain/Overuse: Acute stiffness after physical activity. Fibromyalgia: Chronic widespread stiffness and aches. Polymyalgia Rheumatica: Stiffness in shoulders and hips in older adults. Neurological Conditions: Parkinson's Disease: Rigidity and bradykinesia (slowness of movement). Spasticity: Increased muscle tone in conditions like stroke, multiple sclerosis, cerebral palsy. Hypothyroidism: Can cause generalized stiffness.

column11: One or more of your joints (like knees, ankles, wrists, fingers) appear visibly puffy or enlarged due to fluid buildup or inflammation inside or around them.
column12: Joint swelling (effusion or synovitis) indicates an accumulation of fluid within the joint capsule or inflammation of the synovial membrane lining the joint. Inflammatory Arthritis: Rheumatoid Arthritis: Symmetrical, often affects small joints of hands and feet, associated with morning stiffness. Psoriatic Arthritis: Can affect any joint, often with skin psoriasis. Gout/Pseudogout: Acute, very painful swelling, usually of a single joint (e.g., big toe in gout). Infectious Arthritis (Septic Arthritis): Rapid onset of severe pain, swelling, redness, and warmth in a single joint, often with fever. Medical emergency. Osteoarthritis: Can cause mild joint swelling, often due to bony overgrowth (osteophytes) or secondary inflammation. Trauma: Sprains, fractures, or meniscal/ligament tears can cause acute joint swelling (hemarthrosis if blood is present). Bursitis/Tendinitis: While not truly joint swelling, inflammation of adjacent structures can give the appearance of swelling around a joint. Systemic Diseases: Lupus. The pattern of joint involvement, presence of pain, redness, warmth, and systemic symptoms aid in diagnosis.

column11: A persistent feeling of dryness in your mouth because you're not producing enough saliva. It might make your mouth feel sticky and cause difficulty swallowing.
column12: Dry mouth (xerostomia) is the subjective sensation of oral dryness, resulting from reduced or absent saliva flow (hyposalivation). Medication Side Effects (most common cause): Antihistamines, decongestants, antidepressants, antihypertensives, anticholinergics. Dehydration: Insufficient fluid intake. Systemic Diseases: Sjogren's Syndrome: An autoimmune disease causing chronic dryness of eyes and mouth. Diabetes Mellitus: Poorly controlled diabetes. Radiation Therapy: To the head and neck, damaging salivary glands. Nerve Damage: Affecting salivary glands. HIV/AIDS. Breathing through Mouth: Due to nasal congestion or sleep apnea. Aging: Saliva production can decrease with age. Anxiety/Stress: Can transiently reduce saliva flow. Chronic dry mouth can lead to dental problems (cavities, gum disease), oral infections (thrush), and difficulty speaking or swallowing.

column11: Having infrequent bowel movements (less than three times a week) or difficulty passing stools, which are often hard, dry, and small.
column12: Constipation is a common digestive complaint defined by infrequent bowel movements or difficult passage of stools. Dietary Factors (most common): Low fiber intake, inadequate fluid intake. Lifestyle: Lack of physical activity. Medications: Opioid pain relievers, iron supplements, antacids (aluminum or calcium), anticholinergics, certain antidepressants. Medical Conditions: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS-C): Chronic constipation often with abdominal pain that improves with bowel movements. Hypothyroidism: Slowed metabolism. Diabetes Mellitus: Can cause autonomic neuropathy affecting bowel motility. Neurological Conditions: Parkinson's disease, spinal cord injury, stroke, multiple sclerosis. Structural Issues: Bowel obstruction (less common, acute onset, severe symptoms), strictures, colon cancer (change in bowel habits, blood in stool). Pelvic Floor Dysfunction: Dyssynergic defecation. Pregnancy: Hormonal changes and pressure from the uterus. Chronic constipation can lead to hemorrhoids or anal fissures.

column11: Your belly feels full, tight, and looks noticeably swollen or bloated. It can be uncomfortable and may or may not be accompanied by visible swelling or gas.
column12: Abdominal distention is a perceived or measurable increase in abdominal girth due to gas, fluid, or masses within the abdominal cavity or bowel. Increased Intestinal Gas (Flatulence/Bloating): Most common cause, often from diet (fermentable foods), aerophagia (swallowing air), or conditions like IBS. Fluid Accumulation (Ascites): Due to liver cirrhosis (portal hypertension), heart failure, kidney disease, or certain cancers, causing generalized swelling in the abdomen. Feces (Constipation): Significant fecal impaction can cause distention and discomfort. Masses/Tumors: Large ovarian cysts, uterine fibroids, or abdominal tumors. Organ Enlargement: Enlarged liver (hepatomegaly) or spleen (splenomegaly). Ileus/Bowel Obstruction: Blockage or paralysis of the intestines, causing severe distention, pain, nausea, and vomiting. This is a medical emergency. Pregnancy: Normal physiological distention as the uterus grows. Peritonitis: Inflammation of the peritoneum (abdominal lining), often rigid abdomen.

column11: Areas of your skin become noticeably darker than your usual skin tone. This can be generalized or appear in patches.
column12: Skin darkening (hyperpigmentation) occurs due to an increase in melanin production or deposition of other pigments in the skin. Post-Inflammatory Hyperpigmentation (PIH): Common after skin injury, inflammation, or acne, where the skin produces more melanin in response to the healing process. Sun Exposure: Tanning, freckles, sunspots (lentigines). Melasma: Patchy brown or grayish-brown discoloration, often on the face, triggered by hormonal changes (pregnancy, oral contraceptives) and sun exposure. Addison's Disease: Adrenal insufficiency, causing diffuse skin darkening, especially in sun-exposed areas, scars, and mucous membranes, due to increased ACTH. Hemochromatosis: Iron overload, causing "bronze diabetes." Acanthosis Nigricans: Dark, thickened, velvety skin in folds (neck, armpits, groin), often associated with insulin resistance, diabetes, or malignancy. Medication Side Effects: Certain drugs (e.g., antimalarials, amiodarone, tetracyclines). Chronic Venous Insufficiency: Stasis dermatitis with brownish discoloration in the lower legs due to blood pooling.

column11: A subjective sensation of warmth or heat, even if your body temperature isn't necessarily high, or it can accompany a fever.
column12: "Feeling hot" can be a symptom of various conditions, ranging from physiological responses to serious medical issues. Fever (Pyrexia): The most common reason. An elevated body temperature due to infection or inflammation, causing a feeling of warmth, flushing, and sometimes chills. Hot Flashes/Flashes: Sudden, intense sensations of heat, often with sweating, facial redness, and palpitations, common during menopause or in conditions causing hormonal fluctuations. Heat Exhaustion/Heatstroke: Overheating due to prolonged exposure to high temperatures or strenuous activity. Heatstroke is a medical emergency with very high body temperature. Hyperthyroidism: Overactive thyroid gland, causing increased metabolism, leading to a sensation of being hot, sweating, and heat intolerance. Anxiety/Panic Attacks: Can trigger a "fight or flight" response with a sensation of heat and sweating. Medication Side Effects: Certain drugs can cause flushing or increase body temperature. Fevers of Unknown Origin (FUO): Persistent unexplained fever/feeling hot.

column11: Your mouth (gums, inner cheeks, palate) and/or tongue feel sore, swollen, red, or irritated. It might make eating, speaking, or swallowing uncomfortable.
column12: Inflammation of the mouth (stomatitis) and tongue (glossitis) can be caused by infections, nutritional deficiencies, systemic diseases, trauma, or irritants. Infections: Oral Thrush (Candidiasis): Fungal infection causing white patches that can be scraped off, revealing red, inflamed areas. Common in infants, immunocompromised individuals, or those on antibiotics/steroids. Herpes Simplex Virus: Primary herpetic gingivostomatitis (especially in children) causes widespread mouth sores. Bacterial Infections. Nutritional Deficiencies: Vitamin B Deficiencies (B1, B2, B3, B6, B12): Can cause glossitis (sore, red, swollen tongue), angular cheilitis (cracks at corners of mouth), or stomatitis. Iron Deficiency: Can cause glossitis. Trauma: Accidental biting, burns, sharp food edges, ill-fitting dentures. Allergic Reactions: To foods, dental materials, or oral hygiene products. Autoimmune/Inflammatory Conditions: Lichen Planus: Can affect oral mucosa with lacy white patches or erosions. Pemphigus/Pemphigoid: Rare blistering diseases. Crohn's Disease: Can have oral manifestations. Irritants: Smoking, alcohol, very hot/spicy foods. Medication Side Effects: Certain drugs can cause oral inflammation. Oral Cancer: Can present as persistent, non-healing sores or red/white patches.

column11: A feeling of numbness, reduced sensitivity, or complete inability to feel touch, temperature, or pain in a specific part of your body.
column12: Loss of sensation (anesthesia or hypoesthesia) indicates impaired nerve function, preventing sensory information from reaching the brain. Peripheral Neuropathy: Damage to peripheral nerves, causing numbness, tingling, or weakness. Common causes include diabetes, vitamin B12 deficiency, alcohol abuse, autoimmune diseases, and certain medications. Often symmetrical and affects distal extremities. Nerve Compression/Entrapment: Radiculopathy: Nerve root compression in the spine (e.g., from a herniated disc) can cause numbness in a specific dermatome (area of skin supplied by a single spinal nerve). Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Median nerve compression in the wrist, causing numbness in specific fingers. Stroke/Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA): Damage to brain areas that process sensation, causing sudden numbness, often unilateral. Multiple Sclerosis (MS): Demyelination in the brain or spinal cord can cause sensory deficits. Spinal Cord Injury: Can result in loss of sensation below the level of the injury. Local Injury/Trauma: Direct nerve damage from a cut or crush injury. Infection: Herpes zoster (shingles) can cause numbness after the rash resolves (postherpetic neuralgia). The pattern and distribution of sensory loss are crucial for pinpointing the affected nerve or area of the nervous system. This concludes the explanation of all the symptoms from the provided images. column11: A noticeable puffiness or enlargement around your jawline or in front of your ear. It might be painful or tender to the touch.
column12: Jaw swelling can originate from various structures, including salivary glands, lymph nodes, the temporomandibular joint (TMJ), bone, or soft tissues. Salivary Gland Issues: Sialadenitis: Inflammation or infection of a salivary gland (e.g., parotid or submandibular gland), often due to a blocked duct or bacterial/viral infection (e.g., mumps). Causes pain, tenderness, and swelling, especially when eating. Sialolithiasis: A stone in a salivary duct, causing swelling and pain, particularly during meals. Lymph Node Enlargement (Lymphadenopathy): Swollen lymph nodes under the jaw or in the neck, typically due to infection (e.g., strep throat, viral URI) or, less commonly, malignancy. Dental Issues: Dental Abscess: Infection in a tooth or gum, causing localized swelling and severe pain that can spread to the jaw. Impacted Wisdom Tooth: Can cause swelling and pain. Temporomandibular Joint (TMJ) Dysfunction: Inflammation or disorder of the jaw joint, causing pain, clicking, and sometimes swelling near the ear. Trauma: Fracture of the jawbone or soft tissue injury. Infections: Cellulitis or other soft tissue infections. Tumors/Cysts: Benign or malignant growths in the jaw bone, soft tissues, or glands. Allergic Reaction (Angioedema): Rapid swelling due to an allergic reaction.

column11: Stools that are black, tarry, and often foul-smelling. This indicates bleeding higher up in the digestive tract.
column12: Melena is black, tarry, sticky stool with a characteristic foul odor, caused by the digestion of blood in the upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract. The black color results from the oxidation of hemoglobin by digestive enzymes and bacteria as blood passes through the intestines. Sources of Bleeding (Upper GI): Peptic Ulcers: Most common cause, open sores in the stomach or duodenum. Esophageal Varices: Enlarged veins in the esophagus, often due to severe liver disease, which can rupture and bleed profusely. Gastritis/Esophagitis: Inflammation of the stomach or esophageal lining. Mallory-Weiss Tear: A tear in the esophageal lining, often from severe vomiting. Angiodysplasia: Abnormal blood vessels in the GI tract. Cancers: Esophageal or stomach cancer. Melena signifies significant blood loss and is a medical emergency requiring prompt evaluation and intervention.

column2: chills,fatigue,cough,high fever,breathlessness,sweating,malaise,chest pain,fast heart rate,rusty sputum
column11: Having less hair than usual on your head (thinning or bald patches) or body.
column12: Too little hair, or alopecia, refers to hair loss from the scalp or body. It can be diffuse (generalized thinning) or localized (patchy), and temporary or permanent. Androgenetic Alopecia (Pattern Baldness): Most common type, genetic predisposition, often affects the top of the head in men and general thinning in women. Telogen Effluvium: Temporary hair shedding often triggered by stress, severe illness (e.g., fever), childbirth, surgery, or significant weight loss. Hair typically regrows. Alopecia Areata: Autoimmune condition causing patchy, non-scarring hair loss. Thyroid Disorders: Both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism can cause diffuse hair thinning. Nutritional Deficiencies: Iron, zinc, biotin, or protein deficiency. Medications: Chemotherapy, blood thinners, certain antidepressants, retinoids. Scalp Infections: Fungal infections like Tinea Capitis can cause patchy hair loss with scaling. Traction Alopecia: Hair loss from prolonged pulling on hair (tight braids, ponytails). Chronic Illness: Any severe or chronic illness can contribute to hair loss. Aging: Natural hair thinning occurs with age.

column2: chills,fatigue,cough,high fever,breathlessness,sweating,malaise,phlegm,chest pain,fast heart rate,rusty sputum
column11: A feeling of soreness, restricted movement, or inability to easily turn your head from side to side or up and down.
column12: Neck stiffness or tightness (cervical rigidity) is a common complaint often arising from musculoskeletal issues, but can also indicate more serious conditions. Musculoskeletal (most common): Muscle Strain/Spasm: Often due to poor posture, prolonged computer use, sleeping in an awkward position, or stress. Cervical Spondylosis (Neck Arthritis): Degenerative changes in the neck vertebrae and discs, causing chronic stiffness and sometimes nerve compression (radiculopathy). Whiplash Injury: From sudden head movement (e.g., car accident). Infections: Meningitis: Inflammation of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord, causing severe neck stiffness (nuchal rigidity), headache, fever, and sensitivity to light. This is a medical emergency. Tonsillitis/Pharyngitis: Severe throat infections can cause referred pain and stiffness in the neck. Abscesses: Deep neck space infections. Inflammatory Conditions: Polymyalgia rheumatica. Less Common: Certain tumors, referred pain from a heart attack (very rare). The presence of fever, severe headache, confusion, or weakness suggests a more serious underlying cause.

column2: chills,fatigue,cough,high fever,breathlessness,sweating,malaise,phlegm,chest pain,fast heart rate,rusty sputum
column11: Feeling unusually hungry, eating more than normal, or having a constant urge to eat, even after meals.
column12: Excessive appetite, or polyphagia, is an abnormally strong or increased desire for food. It can be a symptom of various medical conditions, psychological factors, or lifestyle habits. Endocrine Disorders: Diabetes Mellitus (especially uncontrolled Type 1): Despite eating, glucose can't enter cells efficiently, leading to cellular starvation and increased hunger. Often accompanied by increased thirst and frequent urination. Hyperthyroidism: Overactive thyroid gland, increasing metabolism and calorie burning, leading to increased appetite and weight loss despite increased food intake. Medications: Certain drugs like corticosteroids, some antidepressants, and antipsychotics can increase appetite. Psychological/Behavioral: Stress/Anxiety: Emotional eating. Depression: Atypical depression can cause increased appetite and weight gain. Bulimia Nervosa: Binge eating followed by compensatory behaviors. Other Conditions: Hypoglycemia: Low blood sugar, can cause acute hunger, shakiness, sweating. Gastrointestinal Conditions: Malabsorption syndromes (e.g., celiac disease, parasitic infections) can lead to increased hunger if nutrients aren't absorbed effectively. Pregnancy: Increased metabolic demands. Evaluation involves reviewing medical history, medications, and relevant blood tests.

column2: fatigue,cough,high fever,breathlessness,sweating,malaise,phlegm,chest pain,fast heart rate,rusty sputum
column11: Your muscles feel rigid, hard, or difficult to move, especially after rest or inactivity. It's different from muscle weakness and can limit flexibility.
column12: Muscle stiffness or tightness (myotonia or rigidity) can be a symptom of various neurological, musculoskeletal, or systemic conditions. It can affect specific muscles or be generalized. Musculoskeletal: Overuse/Strain: Common after strenuous exercise or unaccustomed activity. Muscle Spasms/Cramps: Acute, painful contractions. Fibromyalgia: Chronic widespread muscle pain and stiffness, often accompanied by fatigue. Polymyalgia Rheumatica: Inflammatory condition causing stiffness and pain, particularly in shoulders and hips, often worse in the morning. Neurological Conditions: Parkinson's Disease: Characterized by rigidity (lead-pipe or cogwheel), bradykinesia, and tremor. Spasticity: Increased muscle tone and hyperactive reflexes resulting from damage to the brain or spinal cord (e.g., stroke, multiple sclerosis, cerebral palsy). Dystonia: Sustained muscle contractions leading to twisting, repetitive movements, or abnormal postures. Tetanus: Severe bacterial infection causing painful muscle spasms and rigidity. Systemic Conditions: Hypothyroidism: Can cause muscle aches, weakness, and stiffness. Certain Medications: Statins can cause muscle aches and stiffness. Electrolyte Imbalances: Magnesium or calcium deficiency. Distinguishing stiffness from weakness or pain is important for diagnosis.

column2: chills,cough,high fever,breathlessness,sweating,malaise,phlegm,chest pain,fast heart rate,rusty sputum
column11: A feeling of burning, stinging, or irritation in your eyes, as if something is irritating them.
column12: The sensation of eye burning or stinging is typically due to irritation or inflammation of the ocular surface, commonly involving the conjunctiva or cornea. Dry Eye Syndrome: Insufficient tear production or poor tear quality, leading to irritation, redness, and a burning sensation. Often worse with prolonged screen time or in dry environments. Allergies (Allergic Conjunctivitis): Exposure to allergens (pollen, dust mites, pet dander) causes itching, redness, watery discharge, and burning. Conjunctivitis ("Pink Eye"): Inflammation of the conjunctiva due to viral or bacterial infection, causing redness, discharge, and burning/grittiness. Environmental Irritants: Smoke, dust, chemical fumes, chlorine in swimming pools, strong winds. Eyestrain: From prolonged reading or computer use. Blepharitis: Inflammation of the eyelids, often at the base of the eyelashes, causing chronic irritation, burning, and redness. Corneal Issues: Corneal abrasion (scratch), foreign body sensation, or keratitis (corneal inflammation). Contact Lens Overuse/Misuse. Eyelid Malposition: Ectropion or entropion (eyelids turning out or in).

column2: chills,fatigue,high fever,breathlessness,sweating,malaise,phlegm,chest pain,fast heart rate,rusty sputum
column11: Your eyes don't move together smoothly, they might jump, twitch, or drift in different directions, or you have trouble controlling their movement. This can sometimes cause double vision.
column12: Abnormal eye movements (ophthalmoparesis, nystagmus, strabismus, or other oculomotor disorders) indicate dysfunction in the nerves, muscles, or brain regions that control eye movement. Strabismus (Cross-Eyed/Wall-Eyed): Misalignment of the eyes, where they don't look in the same direction simultaneously. Can be congenital or acquired. May cause double vision. Nystagmus: Repetitive, uncontrolled eye movements (jerking or oscillating), which can be horizontal, vertical, or rotational. Can be congenital, or acquired due to inner ear problems, brainstem/cerebellar lesions, or certain medications. Ophthalmoparesis/Palsies: Weakness or paralysis of one or more eye muscles, usually due to cranial nerve damage (e.g., third, fourth, or sixth cranial nerve palsy). Causes limited eye movement and often double vision. Neurological Disorders: Multiple sclerosis (MS), stroke, brain tumors, myasthenia gravis (autoimmune disorder affecting neuromuscular junction). Thyroid Eye Disease (Graves' Ophthalmopathy): Inflammation of eye muscles can restrict movement. Trauma: Orbital fracture or direct eye muscle damage. Any new onset of abnormal eye movements, especially with double vision, warrants urgent neurological and ophthalmological evaluation.

column2: chills,fatigue,cough,breathlessness,sweating,malaise,phlegm,chest pain,fast heart rate,rusty sputum
column11: Discomfort, tenderness, or aching in one or both breasts. It can range from mild tenderness to sharp, intense pain.
column12: Pain or soreness of the breast, known as mastalgia or mastodynia, is a common symptom in females and can be cyclical or non-cyclical. Cyclical Breast Pain (most common): Related to hormonal fluctuations during the menstrual cycle. Typically affects both breasts, often worse in the days leading up to a period, and resolves after menstruation. Non-Cyclical Breast Pain: Cysts: Benign fluid-filled sacs in the breast tissue. Can cause localized pain and tenderness, often palpable as a lump. Fibrocystic Breast Changes: Common, benign condition causing lumpy, tender breasts. Mastitis: Infection of breast tissue, common during breastfeeding, causing redness, warmth, swelling, pain, and often fever. Trauma: Injury to the breast. Medications: Certain hormonal therapies (e.g., birth control, hormone replacement therapy), some antidepressants. Referred Pain: From the chest wall, back, or shoulder (e.g., costochondritis, muscle strain). Less Common/Concerning: Breast cancer (though pain is rarely the sole symptom of cancer, and cancer-related pain is often persistent and localized rather than cyclical). Persistent, localized, or worsening breast pain, especially with a new lump, skin changes, or nipple discharge, should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.

column2: chills,fatigue,cough,high fever,sweating,malaise,phlegm,chest pain,fast heart rate,rusty sputum
column11: Any fluid, blood, or pus that comes out of the nipple when it's not related to breastfeeding.
column12: Nipple discharge can be a benign (non-cancerous) finding, but it can also be a sign of underlying pathology, particularly if it's spontaneous, bloody, or unilateral. Benign Causes (most common): Physiological Discharge: Often bilateral, milky, or multicolored (green, brown, yellow), and related to hormonal changes (e.g., pregnancy, oral contraceptives, perimenopause), or certain medications (e.g., antipsychotics, some blood pressure drugs) causing elevated prolactin (galactorrhea). Duct Ectasia: Widening of a milk duct behind the nipple, causing sticky, thick, often greenish or black discharge. Intraductal Papilloma: A small, benign growth in a milk duct, the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge, usually unilateral and from a single duct. Infections: Mastitis or abscess, leading to pus-like discharge. Malignant Causes (Concerning): Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS) or Invasive Ductal Carcinoma: Can cause bloody, serosanguinous (pink), or clear watery discharge, often spontaneous, persistent, and from a single duct. Paget's Disease of the Breast: A rare form of breast cancer affecting the nipple and areola, causing rash-like changes, itching, and sometimes discharge. Any nipple discharge that is spontaneous, bloody, unilateral, persistent, or associated with a palpable lump or skin changes warrants immediate medical evaluation. column11: Not having your menstrual period when you typically would, or never starting periods if you're past the usual age of onset.
column12: The absence of menstruation is known as amenorrhea. It can be primary (never having started menstruation by age 15-16) or secondary (periods stop for three or more consecutive months after having established cycles). Primary Amenorrhea Causes: Chromosomal/Genetic Abnormalities: Turner syndrome. Anatomical Abnormalities: Imperforate hymen, absent uterus/vagina. Hormonal Imbalances: Hypothalamic or pituitary disorders, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Secondary Amenorrhea Causes (most common): Pregnancy: Most common cause. Breastfeeding: Hormones produced during lactation can suppress ovulation. Menopause/Perimenopause: Natural cessation of periods, usually around age 50. Hormonal Imbalances: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): Common cause, often with irregular periods, acne, and excess hair growth. Thyroid Disorders: Both hypo- and hyperthyroidism can affect menstrual cycles. Hyperprolactinemia: Elevated prolactin levels. Excessive Exercise or Low Body Weight: Can disrupt hormonal balance (hypothalamic amenorrhea). Stress: Significant physical or emotional stress. Medications: Certain antidepressants, antipsychotics, some blood pressure medications. Chronic Illnesses: Can impact reproductive function.

column2: chills,fatigue,cough,high fever,breathlessness,sweating,phlegm,chest pain,fast heart rate,rusty sputum
column11: Any amount of bleeding from the vagina that occurs at least 12 months after your last menstrual period (i.e., after menopause has been established).
column12: Vaginal bleeding after menopause (postmenopausal bleeding) is not normal and always warrants prompt medical evaluation to rule out serious underlying conditions. Benign Causes (most common): Vaginal Atrophy (Atrophic Vaginitis): Thinning and drying of vaginal and endometrial tissues due to low estrogen levels, making them prone to bleeding, especially after intercourse. Polyps: Benign growths in the cervix or uterus. Endometrial Hyperplasia: Thickening of the uterine lining, which can be benign, pre-cancerous, or, less commonly, cancerous. Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT): Especially if not balanced or if dosage is adjusted. Cervical Lesions: Infection, inflammation, or benign growths on the cervix. Malignant Causes (Concerning): Endometrial Cancer: Cancer of the uterine lining, the most common gynecologic cancer causing postmenopausal bleeding. Cervical Cancer: Vaginal or Vulvar Cancer: Ovarian Cancer: Less common, but can present with bleeding. Diagnostic procedures often include a physical exam, transvaginal ultrasound, and endometrial biopsy.

column11: Discomfort, aching, or sharp pain felt in your ribs or the area of your chest wall where the ribs are located. It might worsen with breathing or movement.
column12: Rib pain can originate from the ribs themselves, the cartilage connecting them to the sternum, intercostal muscles, or be referred from other organs. Musculoskeletal Causes (most common): Costochondritis: Inflammation of the cartilage that connects the ribs to the breastbone. Causes sharp, localized pain, often reproducible by pressing on the affected area. Tietze's Syndrome: Similar to costochondritis but involves swelling. Muscle Strain: Injury to the intercostal muscles between the ribs, often from coughing, sneezing, or strenuous activity. Rib Fracture/Bruise: Due to trauma or severe coughing. Referred Pain: Gastrointestinal: GERD, ulcers, gallbladder issues, pancreatitis can refer pain to the ribs or back. Pulmonary: Pleurisy (inflammation of lung lining), pneumonia, or pulmonary embolism can cause sharp pain, often worse with breathing. Cardiac: Heart attack can present with chest pain that sometimes radiates to the ribs or back. Neurological: Intercostal neuralgia (nerve pain between ribs), often after shingles (postherpetic neuralgia). Other: Shingles (pain precedes rash), fibroma.

column11: Having frequent or intense outbursts of anger, irritability, or difficulty controlling your temper, disproportionate to the situation.
column12: Temper problems refer to recurrent behavioral outbursts representing a failure to control aggressive impulses. These can be part of broader emotional dysregulation or specific psychiatric conditions. Psychiatric Disorders: Intermittent Explosive Disorder: Characterized by recurrent behavioral outbursts involving verbal or physical aggression. Mood Disorders: Bipolar disorder (during manic or mixed episodes), severe depression (with irritability). Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder: Severe, recurrent temper outbursts in children. Personality Disorders: Borderline personality disorder, antisocial personality disorder. Oppositional Defiant Disorder/Conduct Disorder: In children/adolescents. Neurological Conditions: Brain Injury/Trauma: Especially affecting the frontal lobes. Dementia: As a symptom of cognitive decline. Epilepsy: Can occur during or after a seizure. Substance Use/Withdrawal: Alcohol or drug intoxication or withdrawal. Medical Conditions: Hormone imbalances (e.g., thyroid disorders), sleep deprivation, chronic pain, or severe stress. Developmental Disorders: ADHD, autism spectrum disorder.

column2: constipation,pain during bowel movements,pain in anal region,bloody stool,irritation in anus
column11: Aching, soreness, or tenderness in your muscles. This can be localized to a specific area or generalized throughout your body.
column12: Muscle pain, or myalgia, is a common symptom with various causes, ranging from benign to serious. Musculoskeletal (most common): Overuse/Strain/Injury: From strenuous activity, unaccustomed exercise, or direct trauma. Delayed Onset Muscle Soreness (DOMS): Pain and stiffness developing 12-72 hours after intense exercise. Fibromyalgia: Chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain, often with fatigue, sleep disturbances, and tender points. Polymyalgia Rheumatica: Inflammatory disorder causing widespread muscle pain and stiffness, predominantly in the shoulders and hips, in older adults. Infections: Viral infections (e.g., flu, common cold, COVID-19) often cause generalized muscle aches ("ache all over"). Bacterial infections can also cause localized muscle pain. Medications: Statins (cholesterol-lowering drugs) are a common cause of drug-induced myalgia. Electrolyte Imbalances: Low potassium, calcium, or magnesium. Autoimmune Diseases: Lupus, polymyositis, dermatomyositis. Thyroid Disorders: Both hypo- and hyperthyroidism can cause muscle pain or weakness. Chronic Fatigue Syndrome: Often accompanied by muscle pain. The pattern, onset, and associated symptoms help differentiate the cause.

column2: pain during bowel movements,pain in anal region,bloody stool,irritation in anus
column11: A feeling of stuffiness or fullness in your nose and face, often with pressure, making it difficult to breathe through your nose.
column12: Sinus congestion refers to the blockage or stuffiness of the nasal passages and sinuses, typically due to inflammation and swelling of the mucous membranes. Common Cold (Coryza): Viral infection causing inflammation of nasal passages and sinuses, leading to congestion, runny nose, and sneezing. Allergies (Allergic Rhinitis): Immune response to allergens (pollen, dust mites, pet dander) causing inflammation, congestion, sneezing, and runny nose. Sinusitis: Inflammation or infection of the sinuses, causing facial pain/pressure, headache, and thick nasal discharge. Can be acute or chronic. Nasal Polyps: Benign growths in the nasal passages that can obstruct airflow. Deviated Septum: Structural abnormality of the nasal septum. Vasomotor Rhinitis: Non-allergic rhinitis triggered by changes in temperature, humidity, or irritants. Hormonal Changes: Can cause nasal congestion (e.g., pregnancy). Medication Overuse: Overuse of decongestant nasal sprays can lead to rebound congestion (rhinitis medicamentosa).

column11: Discomfort, soreness, or throbbing pain felt in your gums, the soft tissues around your teeth.
column12: Gum pain (gingivalgia) is a common oral symptom often indicating inflammation, infection, or trauma to the gums. Gingivitis: Inflammation of the gums, usually due to plaque buildup, causing redness, swelling, and bleeding gums, often with mild pain. Reversible with good oral hygiene. Periodontitis: More severe gum disease where inflammation spreads to the deeper structures supporting the teeth, leading to bone loss and potential tooth mobility. Causes pain, swelling, and sometimes pus. Dental Abscess: An infection in a tooth or surrounding tissue that can spread to the gums, causing severe, localized pain and swelling. Tooth Eruption: In children (teething) or adults (wisdom teeth). Trauma: From hard foods, aggressive brushing, or dental procedures. Canker Sores/Mouth Ulcers: Can form on the gums. Oral Thrush (Candidiasis): Fungal infection causing soreness and white patches. Systemic Conditions: Diabetes, Crohn's disease, certain medications (e.g., calcium channel blockers causing gum overgrowth). Abscess of Periodontal Ligament: Localized pus collection.

column11: Feeling angry much more intensely, frequently, or for longer durations than typical, often leading to outbursts or difficulty controlling your emotional reactions.
column12: Excessive anger can be a symptom of various underlying psychological, psychiatric, neurological, or physiological conditions, similar to "temper problems" and "hostile behavior". Psychiatric Disorders: Mood Disorders: Bipolar disorder (especially during manic or mixed episodes), severe depression (with irritability). Anxiety Disorders: Chronic anxiety and frustration can lead to irritability and anger outbursts. Personality Disorders: Borderline, antisocial, narcissistic personality disorders. Intermittent Explosive Disorder: Primary feature is recurrent outbursts of aggression. Psychotic Disorders: Schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder (if associated with paranoia or delusions). Neurological Conditions: Brain Injury/Tumors: Affecting areas of emotional regulation (frontal, temporal lobes). Dementia. Epilepsy: Ictal or post-ictal aggression. Substance Use/Withdrawal: Intoxication with stimulants or alcohol, or withdrawal from alcohol/benzodiazepines. Medical Conditions: Hormonal imbalances (e.g., thyroid disorders), sleep deprivation, chronic pain, or severe stress.

column11: The skin of the penis appears red, inflamed, or irritated. It may or may not be accompanied by itching, pain, or discharge.
column12: Redness of the penis (balanitis if it affects the glans, or balanoposthitis if it also affects the foreskin) is a common inflammatory or infectious condition. Infections: Fungal Infection (Candidiasis): Often causes itching, redness, a rash, and sometimes a white discharge. Common in uncircumcised men, diabetics, or after antibiotic use. Bacterial Infection: Can cause redness, swelling, pain, and sometimes pus. Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs): Herpes (painful blisters/ulcers), gonorrhea, chlamydia, syphilis (chancre). Irritation/Allergies (Contact Dermatitis): From soaps, detergents, lubricants, condoms, or tight clothing. Poor Hygiene: Can lead to accumulation of smegma and subsequent irritation or infection. Psoriasis/Eczema: Can affect the skin of the penis. Lichen Sclerosus: A chronic inflammatory skin condition. Less Common: Certain types of skin cancer. Medical evaluation is recommended, especially if the redness is persistent, painful, associated with discharge, or non-resolving.

column11: Experiencing health issues, dependence, or social difficulties related to tobacco smoking.
column12: "Smoking problems" broadly refers to the adverse health, psychological, and social consequences associated with tobacco use, which is a leading cause of preventable death and disease. Addiction/Dependence: Nicotine is highly addictive, leading to compulsive use and withdrawal symptoms upon cessation. Respiratory Diseases: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD): Including chronic bronchitis (coughing up sputum) and emphysema, causing shortness of breath, wheezing, and chronic cough. Increased Risk of Respiratory Infections: Pneumonia, bronchitis. Asthma Exacerbation. Cardiovascular Diseases: Increased risk of heart attack, stroke, peripheral artery disease, and high blood pressure. Cancers: Significantly increased risk of lung cancer (most common), oral cancer, throat cancer, esophageal, bladder, kidney, pancreatic, cervical, and stomach cancer. Other Health Issues: Impaired wound healing, premature aging of skin, dental problems (gum disease), erectile dysfunction, reduced fertility, and weakened immune system. column11: The inability to get or maintain an erection firm enough for sexual intercourse. It is also known as erectile dysfunction (ED).
column12: Impotence, or erectile dysfunction (ED), is the consistent inability to achieve or maintain an erection sufficient for satisfactory sexual performance. It's a common condition with various potential underlying causes. Vascular Causes (most common): Conditions affecting blood flow to the penis, such as atherosclerosis (hardening of the arteries), high blood pressure, and high cholesterol. Often associated with cardiovascular disease. Neurological Causes: Nerve damage can interfere with the signals from the brain to the penis. Causes include diabetes, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, spinal cord injury, or prostate surgery. Hormonal Causes: Low testosterone levels (hypogonadism) can reduce libido and contribute to ED. Other hormonal imbalances like thyroid disorders can also play a role. Psychological Causes: Stress, anxiety, depression, relationship problems, or performance anxiety can contribute to or worsen ED. Medication Side Effects: Antidepressants, antihypertensives (especially beta-blockers and diuretics), antihistamines, and certain prostate medications. Lifestyle Factors: Smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, obesity, and lack of physical activity. Chronic Diseases: Kidney disease, liver disease.

column2: constipation,pain during bowel movements,pain in anal region,bloody stool,irritation in anus
column11: Your skin feels itchy, sensitive, sore, or appears red, flaky, or bumpy.
column12: Skin irritation refers to an inflammatory response of the skin, often characterized by redness, itching, burning, stinging, dryness, or a rash. Contact Dermatitis: An inflammatory skin reaction caused by direct contact with an irritant (e.g., detergents, soaps, chemicals) or an allergen (e.g., poison ivy, nickel, certain cosmetics). Eczema (Atopic Dermatitis): A chronic inflammatory skin condition causing itchy, red, dry, and sometimes oozing or crusting patches of skin. Dry Skin (Xerosis): Lack of moisture can lead to itching, flaking, and irritation. Infections: Fungal (e.g., ringworm, athlete's foot), bacterial (e.g., impetigo, folliculitis), or parasitic (e.g., scabies, lice). Psoriasis: Chronic autoimmune disease causing red, scaly, itchy plaques. Allergic Reactions: Hives (urticaria) from food, medication, or insect bites. Environmental Factors: Excessive heat, cold, or low humidity. Systemic Diseases: Kidney disease, liver disease, or diabetes can cause generalized itching or skin changes.

column2: vomiting,breathlessness,sweating,chest pain
column11: Seeing bright red blood coming from your rectum or mixed with your stool.
column12: Rectal bleeding (hematochezia) is the passage of bright red blood from the anus, usually indicating bleeding from the lower gastrointestinal (GI) tract (colon, rectum, anus). Hemorrhoids (most common): Swollen veins in the anus or lower rectum. Often cause painless bright red blood during or after a bowel movement, sometimes dripping into the toilet bowl or on toilet paper. Anal Fissure: A small tear in the lining of the anal canal, causing sharp pain during or after bowel movements, often with bright red blood. Diverticulosis/Diverticulitis: Small pouches that bulge out from the colon wall (diverticulosis) can bleed. If they become inflamed or infected (diverticulitis), it can cause pain and sometimes bleeding. Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD): Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis can cause bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and rectal bleeding. Infectious Colitis: Inflammation of the colon due to bacterial, viral, or parasitic infections. Polyps: Growths on the inner lining of the colon or rectum, which can bleed. Some polyps can be pre-cancerous. Colorectal Cancer: A significant concern, especially in older individuals or those with risk factors. Can cause rectal bleeding, change in bowel habits, and weight loss. Angiodysplasia: Abnormal blood vessels in the GI tract. Any rectal bleeding warrants medical evaluation to determine the cause.

column2: vomiting,breathlessness,sweating,chest pain
column11: Your lips feel parched, chapped, or rough, and may crack or peel.
column12: Dry lips (cheilitis or chapped lips) occur due to a lack of moisture in the delicate skin of the lips, leading to discomfort, cracking, and sometimes peeling or bleeding. Dehydration: Insufficient fluid intake is a common cause. Environmental Exposure: Cold, dry weather, wind, or excessive sun exposure. Lip Licking: A common habit that can worsen dryness, as saliva evaporates and removes natural oils. Medication Side Effects: Certain drugs can cause dry mucous membranes, including isotretinoin (for acne), some chemotherapy agents, and diuretics. Nutritional Deficiencies: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency can cause angular cheilitis (cracks at the corners of the mouth). Allergic Reactions: To lip products, toothpaste, or foods. Systemic Diseases: Sjogren's syndrome (autoimmune condition causing widespread dryness), thyroid disorders. Mouth Breathing: Due to nasal congestion or sleep apnea, leading to increased evaporation from the lips.

column2: breathlessness,sweating,chest pain
column11: Any abnormal spots, bumps, sores, or changes in color or texture on your tongue.
column12: Tongue lesions refer to any abnormal changes in the appearance, texture, or integrity of the tongue's surface. They can be indicative of various local or systemic conditions. Infections: Oral Thrush (Candidiasis): Fungal infection causing white, creamy patches that can be scraped off, revealing red, inflamed areas. Herpes Simplex Virus: Can cause painful blisters or ulcers. Geographic Tongue: Benign inflammatory condition causing map-like patterns of red patches with white borders, which can change location. Trauma: Accidental biting, burns, irritation from sharp teeth or dental appliances. Nutritional Deficiencies: Iron Deficiency Anemia: Can cause a smooth, red, painful tongue (atrophic glossitis). Vitamin B Deficiencies (B12, folate, riboflavin, niacin): Can cause glossitis or mouth sores. Autoimmune/Inflammatory Conditions: Lichen Planus: Can cause white, lacy patterns or painful erosions. Behçet's Disease: Recurrent oral ulcers. Systemic Diseases: Diabetes, thyroid disorders. Benign Growths: Fibromas, papillomas. Cancer: Persistent, non-healing sores, red or white patches, or lumps on the tongue, especially if associated with pain, difficulty swallowing, or neck lumps, require urgent evaluation for oral cancer.

column2: vomiting,sweating,chest pain
column11: Any unusual sounds when you breathe, such as wheezing, crackling, grunting, gasping, or noisy breathing.
column12: Abnormal breathing sounds indicate turbulent airflow or airway obstruction at various levels of the respiratory system. Wheezing: A high-pitched, whistling sound, typically on exhalation, caused by narrowed airways. Common in asthma, COPD, bronchitis, or allergic reactions. Stridor: A harsh, high-pitched, crowing sound, typically on inhalation, caused by upper airway obstruction (e.g., larynx or trachea). Can be a medical emergency (e.g., croup, foreign body aspiration, epiglottitis, severe allergic reaction). Crackles (Rales): Short, popping, crackling sounds, often heard on inhalation, indicative of fluid in the small airways or alveoli. Common in pneumonia, heart failure, or pulmonary fibrosis. Rhonchi: Low-pitched, rumbling sounds, often cleared with coughing, caused by secretions in larger airways. Common in bronchitis or pneumonia. Grunting: A low, short sound on exhalation, often indicating respiratory distress, especially in infants. Snoring/Apnea: Noisy breathing during sleep, sometimes with pauses in breathing. Stertor: Low-pitched, snoring-like sound caused by partial obstruction of the upper airway (e.g., pharynx). The type and timing of the sound provide clues to the underlying cause.

column2: vomiting,breathlessness,chest pain
column11: A persistent feeling of a lack of saliva in your mouth, making it feel sticky, and potentially causing difficulty speaking or eating.
column12: Mouth dryness (xerostomia) is the subjective sensation of insufficient saliva, often accompanied by actual reduced saliva flow (hyposalivation). Medication Side Effects (most common): Numerous medications can cause dry mouth, including antidepressants, antihistamines, decongestants, antihypertensives, and anticholinergics. Dehydration: Insufficient fluid intake. Systemic Diseases: Sjogren's Syndrome: An autoimmune disease causing chronic dry eyes and mouth. Diabetes Mellitus: Poorly controlled blood sugar can lead to dry mouth. HIV/AIDS. Cystic Fibrosis. Radiation Therapy: To the head and neck, damaging salivary glands. Mouth Breathing: Due to nasal congestion or sleep apnea. Smoking: Tobacco use can reduce saliva flow. Aging: Saliva production can naturally decrease with age. Anxiety/Stress: Can transiently reduce saliva flow. Chronic dry mouth can lead to dental problems, oral infections (thrush), and difficulty with speech and swallowing.

column2: vomiting,breathlessness,sweating
column11: Feeling unusually drowsy, tired, or having a strong urge to sleep during the day, even after adequate night's rest. It's more than just feeling fatigued.
column12: Sleepiness, or excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS), is the inability to stay awake and alert during the major waking episodes of the day, leading to unintended lapses into drowsiness or sleep. It differs from fatigue, which is a feeling of lack of energy. Insufficient Sleep (Sleep Deprivation): Most common cause. Not getting enough hours of quality sleep. Sleep Disorders: Sleep Apnea: Repeated pauses in breathing during sleep, leading to fragmented sleep and severe daytime sleepiness. Often associated with snoring and witnessed breathing pauses. Narcolepsy: A chronic neurological condition characterized by overwhelming daytime sleepiness and sudden attacks of sleep. Restless Legs Syndrome: Unpleasant sensations in the legs leading to an urge to move them, disrupting sleep. Insomnia: Difficulty falling or staying asleep, leading to daytime sleepiness. Medical Conditions: Hypothyroidism, anemia, chronic pain, kidney disease, liver disease, fibromyalgia. Medications: Antihistamines, sedatives, muscle relaxants, certain antidepressants, opioids. Neurological Disorders: Brain injury, tumors. Depression/Anxiety: Can manifest as excessive sleepiness.

column2: vomiting,breathlessness,sweating,chest pain
column11: Brief, repeated pauses in breathing, especially during sleep.
column12: Apnea refers to a temporary cessation of breathing. It is most commonly used in the context of sleep apnea. Sleep Apnea: The most common form, characterized by recurrent episodes of upper airway obstruction during sleep (obstructive sleep apnea, OSA) or a lack of respiratory effort from the brain (central sleep apnea, CSA). Symptoms of OSA: Loud snoring, witnessed breathing pauses, gasping or choking during sleep, excessive daytime sleepiness, morning headaches, and unrefreshing sleep. Risk Factors for OSA: Obesity, male gender, larger neck circumference, older age, family history. Complications of OSA: Increased risk of high blood pressure, heart attack, stroke, diabetes, and accidents due to daytime sleepiness. Infant Apnea: Pauses in breathing in infants, sometimes associated with prematurity or underlying medical conditions. Drug-Induced Apnea: Certain medications (e.g., opioids, sedatives) can suppress respiratory drive. Central Nervous System Disorders: Conditions affecting the brainstem's control of breathing. Sleep apnea is a serious condition that requires diagnosis and treatment, often with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).

column2: breathlessness,sweating,chest pain
column11: Discomfort, aching, or soreness in one or more of your joints (e.g., knees, hips, fingers, shoulders). It can range from mild to severe and may be associated with stiffness or swelling.
column12: Joint pain (arthralgia) is a common symptom with a wide range of causes, originating from the joint itself or surrounding structures. Arthritis (Inflammatory): Rheumatoid Arthritis: Chronic autoimmune disease causing symmetrical pain, swelling, and morning stiffness, often affecting small joints of hands and feet. Psoriatic Arthritis: Affects individuals with psoriasis, can involve various joints. Gout/Pseudogout: Acute, very severe pain and swelling, typically affecting one joint (e.g., big toe in gout). Ankylosing Spondylitis/Other Spondyloarthropathies: Primarily affects the spine, but can involve peripheral joints, causing stiffness and pain. Infectious Arthritis (Septic Arthritis): Severe pain, swelling, redness, and warmth in a single joint, often with fever. Medical emergency. Osteoarthritis (Degenerative Arthritis): "Wear and tear" arthritis, common with age, causing pain that worsens with activity and stiffness after rest. Injury/Trauma: Sprains, strains, fractures, ligament tears, meniscal tears. Bursitis/Tendinitis: Inflammation of fluid-filled sacs (bursae) or tendons around joints. Fibromyalgia: Widespread chronic pain, including joint pain, often with fatigue and stiffness. Systemic Diseases: Lupus, Lyme disease, viral infections (e.g., chikungunya). Overuse/Repetitive Stress. A thorough history and physical examination, along with imaging and blood tests, help in diagnosis. I will wait for your confirmation before providing the next set of symptoms. column2: vomiting,sweating,chest pain
column11: Any unusual change in the natural color of your skin, such as becoming too pale, too red, yellowish, bluish, or developing unusual patches of light or dark skin.
column12: Abnormal skin color can be a significant indicator of underlying systemic diseases or localized dermatological conditions. Pallor (Paleness): Reduced blood flow or low hemoglobin. Common causes include anemia (iron deficiency, B12 deficiency), shock, fainting, or vasovagal reactions. Erythema (Redness): Increased blood flow due to inflammation, infection (e.g., cellulitis), allergic reactions (e.g., hives, contact dermatitis), or fever. Cyanosis (Bluish/Purplish): Insufficient oxygen in the blood, often visible in lips, nail beds, and skin. Indicates respiratory or cardiac issues (e.g., heart failure, severe asthma, COPD). Jaundice (Yellowish): Buildup of bilirubin in the blood, indicating liver dysfunction, bile duct obstruction, or excessive red blood cell breakdown. Hyperpigmentation (Darkening): Increased melanin production. Causes include sun exposure, melasma, Addison's disease, or post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation. Hypopigmentation (Lightening): Reduced melanin. Causes include vitiligo (autoimmune), fungal infections (tinea versicolor), or post-inflammatory hypopigmentation. Rash/Lesions: Can present with specific color changes (e.g., purpura from bleeding under the skin).

column2: vomiting,breathlessness,chest pain
column11: Losing more hair than normal, leading to thinning of hair on your scalp or body, or developing bald patches.
column12: Hair loss, or alopecia, is a common complaint with diverse etiologies, affecting both males and females, and can be temporary or permanent. Androgenetic Alopecia (Pattern Baldness): Most common type, genetically determined, characterized by predictable patterns of hair thinning and loss on the scalp (receding hairline and crown thinning in men, diffuse thinning in women). Telogen Effluvium: Temporary, diffuse hair shedding often triggered by significant physiological or psychological stress (e.g., childbirth, severe illness, surgery, crash dieting, emotional stress). Hair usually regrows over months. Alopecia Areata: An autoimmune condition causing patchy, non-scarring hair loss that can affect any hair-bearing area. Tinea Capitis (Scalp Ringworm): Fungal infection causing scaly, itchy patches of hair loss on the scalp, often with broken hairs. Traction Alopecia: Hair loss resulting from prolonged or repetitive pulling force on the hair follicles (e.g., tight braids, ponytails, hair extensions). Thyroid Disorders: Both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism can cause diffuse hair thinning. Nutritional Deficiencies: Iron deficiency, zinc deficiency, protein deficiency, severe calorie restriction. Medications: Chemotherapy, blood thinners, certain antidepressants, retinoids, oral contraceptives. Trichotillomania: Hair-pulling disorder. Scarring Alopecias: Inflammatory conditions that permanently destroy hair follicles.

column2: fatigue,cramps,bruising,obesity,swollen legs,swollen blood vessels,prominent veins on calf
column3: lie down flat and raise the leg high
column11: Discomfort, aching, or sharp pain felt in or around your ear.
column12: Ear pain (otalgia) is a common symptom, particularly in children, and can originate from the ear itself (primary otalgia) or be referred from other head and neck structures (referred otalgia). Otitis Media (Middle Ear Infection): Most common cause in children. Causes pain, pressure, fever, and sometimes temporary hearing loss. Can lead to pus draining from the ear if the eardrum perforates. Otitis Externa (Swimmer's Ear): Infection of the outer ear canal, often from water exposure. Causes pain, itching, redness, and discharge. Pain often worsens with pulling on the earlobe. Earwax Impaction: Blockage by earwax can cause discomfort, muffled hearing, and sometimes pain. Foreign Body in Ear: Can cause pain and irritation. Trauma: Direct injury to the ear or eardrum. Referred Pain (from other areas): Dental Problems: Toothache, jaw pain (e.g., TMJ dysfunction), dental abscess. Throat Infections: Tonsillitis, pharyngitis, strep throat. Neck Problems: Muscle tension or cervical spine issues. Sinusitis: Sinus pressure can radiate to the ear. TMJ Dysfunction: Pain around the jaw joint can refer to the ear.

column2: fatigue,cramps,bruising,obesity,swollen legs,swollen blood vessels,prominent veins on calf
column3: lie down flat and raise the leg high
column11: Throwing up material that contains blood, which can appear bright red (fresh blood), dark red, or like coffee grounds (digested blood). This is a serious symptom.
column12: Vomiting blood (hematemesis) is the regurgitation of blood from the upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract (esophagus, stomach, or duodenum). The appearance of the blood indicates the source and duration of bleeding. Bright Red Blood: Indicates active, brisk bleeding, usually from an esophageal or gastric source, or a Mallory-Weiss tear. Coffee-Ground Emesis: Indicates bleeding that has been in contact with stomach acid, partially digesting the hemoglobin. Common with peptic ulcers. Causes of Upper GI Bleeding: Peptic Ulcers: Most common cause, open sores in the stomach or duodenum. Esophageal Varices: Enlarged veins in the esophagus, often due to severe liver disease (cirrhosis), which can rupture and cause massive bleeding. Mallory-Weiss Tear: A tear in the lining of the esophagus at the junction with the stomach, often caused by forceful or prolonged vomiting or retching. Gastritis/Esophagitis: Inflammation of the stomach or esophageal lining. Cancer: Esophageal or stomach cancer. Angiodysplasia: Abnormal blood vessels. Hematemesis is a medical emergency that requires immediate evaluation and management due to the potential for significant blood loss and hemodynamic instability.

column2: cramps,bruising,obesity,swollen legs,swollen blood vessels,prominent veins on calf
column3: lie down flat and raise the leg high
column11: Lymph nodes (small, bean-shaped glands) feel enlarged, tender, or visible, commonly in the neck, armpits, or groin.
column12: Swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) indicate an immune response to infection, inflammation, or malignancy. Lymph nodes contain immune cells that filter lymph fluid and trap pathogens or abnormal cells. Infections (most common): Viral Infections: Common cold, mononucleosis, HIV, measles, rubella. Often generalized or in the neck/jaw area. Bacterial Infections: Strep throat, skin infections (e.g., cellulitis near the affected area), cat scratch disease. Fungal/Parasitic Infections: Toxoplasmosis. Inflammatory/Autoimmune Conditions: Rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, sarcoidosis. Cancer (Malignancy): Lymphoma: Cancer originating in the lymph nodes themselves. Metastatic Cancer: Cancer that has spread from another part of the body (e.g., breast cancer spreading to axillary nodes, head and neck cancers spreading to cervical nodes). Other: Certain medications, benign cysts. Characteristics like size, tenderness, mobility, consistency, and associated symptoms help differentiate causes. Hard, fixed, non-tender nodes are more concerning for malignancy.

column2: fatigue,bruising,obesity,swollen legs,swollen blood vessels,prominent veins on calf
column3: lie down flat and raise the leg high
column11: Your skin appears flushed, inflamed, or has red patches. This can be localized or spread over a larger area.
column12: Skin redness (erythema) is a common dermatological sign resulting from increased blood flow to the skin due to inflammation or dilation of superficial blood vessels. Inflammation/Infection: Cellulitis: Bacterial infection of the skin, causing rapidly spreading redness, warmth, swelling, and pain. Erysipelas: A superficial form of cellulitis with well-demarcated borders. Folliculitis/Boils: Infection of hair follicles. Fungal Infections: Ringworm, athlete's foot. Viral Rashes: Measles, rubella, fifth disease. Allergic Reactions: Contact Dermatitis: Redness, itching, rash from contact with an irritant or allergen. Urticaria (Hives): Itchy, raised red welts. Drug Eruptions: Widespread redness after taking medication. Skin Conditions: Eczema, psoriasis, rosacea (facial redness, flushing). Sunburn: Acute inflammatory response to UV radiation. Heat/Fever: Generalized flushing. Autoimmune Diseases: Lupus (malar rash). Erythema Nodosum: Tender red nodules, often on shins.

column2: fatigue,cramps,obesity,swollen legs,swollen blood vessels,prominent veins on calf
column3: lie down flat and raise the leg high
column11: A decreased ability or complete inability to detect odors (anosmia) or a distorted sense of smell (parosmia).
column12: Loss of smell (anosmia) or a reduced sense of smell (hyposmia) is often due to conditions affecting the nasal passages or the olfactory nerves and brain centers. Upper Respiratory Infections (most common): Viral infections like the common cold, flu, or COVID-19 can cause temporary or prolonged loss of smell due to inflammation and damage to olfactory receptors. Nasal/Sinus Issues: Chronic Sinusitis/Rhinitis: Persistent inflammation, polyps, or congestion can block odor molecules from reaching the olfactory receptors. Nasal Polyps: Growths in the nasal passages. Deviated Septum: Structural blockage. Head Injury: Trauma to the head can damage the olfactory nerves as they pass through the skull base. Neurological Disorders: Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, multiple sclerosis (MS) can cause a loss of smell, sometimes as an early symptom. Aging: Natural decline in the sense of smell with age. Medications: Certain antibiotics, antihistamines, blood pressure medications. Exposure to Toxins: Chemical fumes. Congenital Anosmia: Born without a sense of smell.

column2: fatigue,cramps,bruising,swollen legs,swollen blood vessels,prominent veins on calf
column3: lie down flat and raise the leg high
column11: A pain or discomfort in your head or face, which can vary in intensity, location, and type (e.g., throbbing, dull, sharp, pressure).
column12: Headache (cephalalgia) is a common symptom with a vast differential diagnosis, ranging from benign to life-threatening conditions. Primary Headaches (not caused by an underlying condition): Tension Headache: Most common, dull, aching pain, often described as a tight band around the head. Migraine: Severe, throbbing pain, often unilateral, with sensitivity to light/sound, nausea, and vomiting. Cluster Headache: Severe, unilateral pain around the eye, with associated symptoms like tearing, nasal congestion, and eyelid drooping. Secondary Headaches (caused by an underlying condition): Infections: Sinusitis, flu, common cold, meningitis (severe headache with stiff neck, fever, confusion). Vascular Issues: Stroke, TIA, cerebral aneurysm (sudden, severe "thunderclap" headache). Head Injury/Trauma: Concussion, post-concussion syndrome. High Blood Pressure (Hypertensive Crisis). Medication Overuse Headache. Brain Tumor: Headaches that worsen over time, with new neurological symptoms. Glaucoma: Eye pain and headache. Temporomandibular Joint (TMJ) Dysfunction: Referred pain to the temples or jaw. "Red flag" symptoms (sudden onset, worst headache of life, fever/stiff neck, focal neurological deficits, worsening headache, headache after trauma) warrant urgent medical attention.
